and - “we,” “us,” “our,” “Howden,” the “Group” and similar terms refer to HGH Finance and its subsidiaries starting from January 25, 2022 and to HGH Limited and its subsidiaries prior to January 25, 2022. -----

Section Title: STABILIZATION
Subsubsection Text: IN CONNECTION WITH THE ISSUANCE OF THE NOTES, MORGAN SECURITIES LLC (THE “STABILIZING MANAGER”) (OR ANY PERSON ACTING ON BEHALF OF THE STABILIZING MANAGER) MAY OVER-ALLOT NOTES OR EFFECT TRANSACTIONS WITH A VIEW TO SUPPORTING THE MARKET PRICE OF THE NOTES AT A LEVEL HIGHER THAN THAT WHICH MIGHT OTHERWISE PREVAIL. HOWEVER, THERE IS NO ASSURANCE THAT THE STABILIZING MANAGER (OR ANY PERSON ACTING ON BEHALF OF THE STABILIZING MANAGER) WILL UNDERTAKE STABILIZATION ACTION. ANY STABILIZATION ACTION MAY BEGIN ON OR AFTER THE DATE ON WHICH ADEQUATE PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF THE TERMS OF THE OFFER OF THE NOTES IS MADE AND, IF BEGUN, MAY BE ENDED AT ANY TIME, BUT IT MUST END NO LATER THAN THE EARLIER OF 30 DAYS AFTER THE ISSUE DATE OF THE NOTES AND 60 DAYS AFTER THE DATE OF THE ALLOTMENT OF THE NOTES.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: We are the largest privately held (re)insurance intermediary by revenue outside of North America and the leading broker in the UK based on geographic footprint and the size of our product portfolio. Our mission is to provide best-in-class retail, specialty and wholesale broking services, reinsurance, risk management and capital markets expertise as well as highly reputable underwriting solutions. We serve clients all over the world with over $38 billion in gross written premiums placed as of September 30, 2023, combining the capabilities of a global brokerage firm with the personalized values of an employee-owned business supported by long term, growth oriented financial partners. Our global headquarters are in London, United Kingdom, and we have offices in more than 50 countries across Europe, Asia Pacific, the Middle East, Africa, the United States and Latin America, combined with a network of partners which enables us to cover over 100 countries and territories globally. We believe that we are one of the few players with an operating model that combines a global platform with strong local presence. Our personal, service-oriented approach, delivered through our office network, branches and digital and online channels, and backed-up by data and analytics, has led to high levels of client satisfaction, driving high retention rates and strong organic growth. In addition to the strong organic growth, we expanded our global network through a selective and disciplined acquisition program investing in likeminded, entrepreneurial insurance businesses. The successful execution of our combined organic growth and acquisition strategy has led to sustained and significant growth. We generated IFRS Revenue of £2,350.6 million, Adjusted Revenue of £2,442.8 million, Loss after tax of £328.8 million, and Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA of £780.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2023, compared with IFRS Revenue of £1,630.4 million, Adjusted Revenue of £1,841.2 million, Loss after tax of £92.1 million, and Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA of £598.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. See “Summary—Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data” for additional details.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Insurance Distribution Value Chain
Subsubsection Text: The insurance industry comprises the following functions: Retail Brokers:_ They assist clients, including individuals, businesses, and public institutions, to identify their insurance needs and secure appropriate insurance policies. The broking process involves negotiating policy terms and placing the client’s risk with a suitable insurer, either directly or via an underwriting agency or a wholesale broker. Wholesale Brokers:_ They function as intermediaries between retail brokers and insurance carriers, typically in specialty lines of insurance. Wholesale brokers focus on the more complex or high-risk coverage areas and typically do not have direct contact with the insured, and instead provide access to insurance carriers and products that a retail broker might otherwise not have. In some cases, wholesale brokers also serve as intermediaries between underwriting agencies and insurance carriers. Reinsurance Brokers:_ They facilitate the transfer of risk from an insurance carrier to a reinsurer, aiding in the diversification and management of the insurer’s risk exposure. Underwriting Agencies:_ They serve as intermediaries between insurance companies and brokers or customers. These agencies may act as MGAs, which issue and administer policies, handle claims, and oversee renewals on behalf of insurance companies. They carry out most of the traditional insurer activities, including underwriting and pricing, except for providing capital and incurring liabilities for claims. Their performance is measured by underwriting results. Their profitability may also be influenced by “loss-sharing” agreements with insurance companies, which are contingent on the agencies’ underwriting performance. The diagram below illustrates the entire insurance distribution value chain:

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: We provide retail insurance brokerage, wholesale insurance brokerage, reinsurance brokerage, and Managing General Agency (“MGA”) services as well as advisory and consulting service to businesses, individuals and insurance carriers across the world. We assist our clients in devising appropriate risk mitigation strategies through insurance products and enable the placement of insurance policies with insurance carriers and reinsurers. We do not assume underwriting risk for the insurance policies we assist in placing and the compensation model for our services typically involves commissions based on premium levels or fees for services rendered. Consequently, the performance of the insurance brokerage sector is dependent on the economic performance of the broader insurance and reinsurance markets, reflected in the premiums placed. The volume of premiums placed is dependent on the insurance rates and the underlying amount of coverage purchased. The amount of coverage purchased is typically correlated to the overall GDP level and macroeconomic factors underlying each specific client industry and/or risk class. Insurance rates are cyclical in nature and vary between “hard”markets, where premium rates are increasing, and “soft”markets, where rates are declining. -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Property and Casualty (“P&C”) Insurance
Subsubsection Text: P&C insurance encompasses a wide array of coverage options tailored to meet diverse commercial needs. It is generally categorized into traditional P&C and specialty lines. Traditional P&C lines include coverage for commercial property, general commercial liability, workers’ compensation, and other products that provide broad protection against common risks faced by businesses in various sectors. Specialty line products are tailored to mitigate risks faced in specific industries, such as natural resources, marine, energy, fleet, real estate, and construction, as well as complex functional risks, including cyber, financial lines, professional indemnity, directors and officers. Specialty lines also include transactional lines, which are designed to mitigate risks in business transactions, particularly in mergers and acquisitions, with products such as warranty and indemnity insurance, tax liability insurance, litigation buyout insurance, and contingent liability insurance. ----- _Personal Lines Insurance_ The personal lines sector of the insurance market caters to individuals, providing a range of non-life insurance products. This includes general coverage options such as accident and health, household, motor, travel, and personal accident insurance. Additionally, the market also addresses the needs of niche segments or individuals with unique risk profiles through specialist non-life insurance products, which cater to specific interests or higher-value assets such as jewelry, art, and vintage cars. _Reinsurance_ Reinsurance products help insurance underwriters, including carriers and MGAs, by securing protection from another insurer. It is designed to redistribute risk, thereby assisting insurers in managing large-scale claim liabilities. It is primarily categorized into treaty reinsurance and facultative reinsurance. Treaty reinsurance involves comprehensive agreements covering a broad range of risks under long-term contracts, offering consistent risk management over extended periods. Facultative reinsurance is tailored to specific, individual risks, providing customized solutions through detailed underwriting on a case-by-case basis. _Advisory and Consulting Services_ Advisory and consulting services offer specialized expertise in employee benefits, mortgage products and capital market advisory. These services include comprehensive advice in real estate and mortgage advisory, as well as strategic advice in mergers and acquisitions, capital raising, and insurance-linked securities for insurance carriers and insurance service companies. Employee benefits brokers and consultants provide businesses with access to medical, life, and disability insurance, along with retirement planning services. They advise on plan design and offer single-source solutions for program management and administration, allowing businesses, especially in the middle market, to outsource these functions effectively.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: A leading player in a large and resilient market
Subsubsection Text: Enduring demand for insurance products within both corporate and individual sectors, partially driven by regulatory imperatives, coupled with continued growth and increasing complexity of risks makes the insurance sector a large and resilient end market. As illustrated in the chart below, the P&C insurance market is large with $869 billion of direct premiums written in 2022, and has displayed resilience amidst economic fluctuations, growing at a CAGR of 4.4% from 1996 to 2022, with only two years of negative year-over-year growth. Notably, during the COVID-19 pandemic, the sector experienced a 9.5% annual growth rate. Source: S&P Global Market Intelligence We are the largest privately held (re)insurance intermediary by revenue outside of North America, having placed over $38 billion in written premiums annually as of September 30, 2023. Our global presence ----- encompasses offices across 50 countries, and in collaboration with our Howden One network, we maintain an extensive service network spanning over 100 countries and territories. In the growing insurance market, our market position has increased over time. According to AM Best, our rank improved from the 10[th] to the 6[th] largest private insurance intermediary by revenue between 2018 and 2022. We are at the forefront in the markets and sectors that we service, recognized as one of the largest MGAs outside North America, the number one independent broker in the London market, and the fourth-largest global reinsurance broker. Source: AM Best

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Independent with high employee ownership and entrepreneurial culture, attracting top industry talent
Subsubsection Text: Employee ownership has remained a fundamental pillar of our corporate ethos since our inception three decades ago, under the leadership of our founder David Howden. This entrepreneurial spirit and people-first approach have been instrumental in fostering a vibrant corporate culture. Out of a total workforce of approximately 15,500 individuals, about 4,500 employees are shareholders, and around 2,600 of them participate in equity incentive schemes. Together, they hold approximately one-third of the Group’s equity, establishing our workforce as the largest and most significant shareholder group. Attracting, nurturing, and retaining high-caliber talent is a core aspect of our operational strategy, resulting in a high producer retention rate. Our commitment to employee equity ownership has played a pivotal role in attracting and retaining industry-leading professionals. As of September 30, 2023, our team has grown to around 15,500 individuals across 50 countries. As at September 30, 2023, the numbers of employees in our New Initiatives totalled approximately 1,120 across a number of different geographies and product lines. They made up approximately 30% of the Group’s Organic Revenue Growth for the year ended September 30, 2023, contributing about 4% to the Group’s Organic Revenue Growth of 13% in this period.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Robust Organic Revenue Growth outperforming listed peers in recent years
Subsubsection Text: Over several years, we have consistently delivered high Organic Revenue Growth, driven by our entrepreneurial culture, industry and product specialisms, presence in high growth markets, strategic hiring of talented insurance professionals, cross-selling within our existing client base, and strong relationships with insurance carrier. This has led to a consistent outperformance versus our listed peers, underpinned by the success of our non-transactional business and New Initiatives. For example, for the years ended September 30, 2021, 2022 and 2023, our Organic Revenue Growth was 19%, 19% and 13%, respectively, compared to Organic Revenue Growth of 10%, 8% and 9%, respectively, of our listed peers (representing the weighted average organic growth rate of public intermediary peers: Marsh McLennan, Aon, Willis Towers Watson, Arthur J. Gallagher & Co., Brown & Brown Insurance, Baldwin Risk Partners and Ryan Specialty). ----- Source: Company information We have identified various growth drivers to maintain this level of Organic Revenue Growth, primarily through winning business from large U.S. global brokers, strategic global recruitment initiatives driven by our equity model and our global footprint, the exploration of new product lines, and the pursuit of untapped market segments.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Disciplined M&A strategy focused on cultural fit and complementing our footprint
Subsubsection Text: Our growth, particularly in new markets and product lines, has been accelerated by a selective and disciplined M&A strategy, focusing on acquiring firms that share our commitment to employee ownership and complement our culture. From October 1, 2015 through September 30, 2023, we completed over 100 Bolt-on Acquisitions and Transformational Acquisitions, accounting for approximately £1,040 million of acquired revenue. The majority of these transactions are the result of bilateral negotiations, although we also selectively participate in competitive auctions. The majority of our M&A activity by volume focuses on small to medium-sized bolt-on acquisitions that bolster our existing regional capabilities. From October 1, 2015 through September 30, 2023, our M&A approach resulted in the successful completion of 97 Bolt-on Acquisitions, with over 50% of these deals valued at less than £5 million whereas about 60% of acquired EBITDA comes from deals with multiples below 10x pricing EBITDA. See “Presentation of financial and other information—Non-IFRS Financial Measures.” Source: Company information ----- Large strategic deals for transformative growth have been focused on expanding geographical footprint and product capabilities. For example, the acquisitions of A-Plan Group and Aston Lark expanded our personal lines offering and products for micro SME, SME and mid-sized corporates within the UK. The recent acquisition of Marsh R.S. strengthened our position in southern Spain and improved our capabilities to cover large corporates in Spain. The acquisition of Assiteca significantly increased our presence in Italy by adding a further 20 offices. The acquisition of Align has moved DUAL to one of the largest MGAs globally. The acquisition of TigerRisk strengthened our position in the global reinsurance market, placing us among the world’s top reinsurance brokers. It also complemented our offering of facultative reinsurance by adding treaty reinsurance and capital advisory capabilities in the U.S. and the UK. During the financial year ended September 30, 2023, we enhanced our treaty reinsurance offering and improved our footprint in the Netherlands, France, Switzerland, Belgium and Denmark through strategic M&A activity. Acquired entities are integrated into the Group and generally rebranded to Howden to maximize the scale benefit and global coverage of our brand. This also delivers cultural and operational alignment and helps to achieve the anticipated synergies on a timely basis. Prior to completion, management and operational structures are agreed as well as targeted revenue and cost synergies. Whilst the bulk of anticipated synergies are revenue focused, we have been successful in achieving planned cost synergies. We often structure our acquisitions with incentives schemes, including “earn-outs”and company incentive shares for key management of the acquired firms to encourage alignment, retention and long-term commitment.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Diversified platform across geographies and routes to market supported by a strong specialty focus, capable of serving sophisticated clients globally
Subsubsection Text: Our diversified platform features a comprehensive suite of insurance products and services, including personal and commercial lines, wholesale distribution, and underwriting services. We serve a wide-ranging client base, which comprises SMEs as well as large corporations, ensuring that our business is not dependent on any single client segment. The geographic distribution of our Adjusted Revenue enhances our resilience, with operations across 50 countries and a network that covers over 100 countries and territories. As is illustrated in the figure below, for the year ended September 30, 2023, our Adjusted Revenue was well-distributed with 36% generated in the UK & Ireland, 27% in the Americas, 22% in Europe, and 15% in other regions. Source: Company information -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Highly recurring revenue and high cash flow conversion
Subsubsection Text: A key aspect of our financial strength is the highly recurring nature of our revenue streams, which are anchored by consistently high retention rates across our product lines. This predictability is a result of our commitment to superior client service and relationships. Our revenue retention rate has averaged around 90% for the year ended September 30, 2023. In addition, our business generates considerable Management Operating Cash flow, primarily driven by high Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA margins combined with limited requirements for working capital and Maintenance CapEx. In the year ended September 30, 2023, we delivered an Operating Cash Conversion rate of 83%, consistent with our historical rates when normalized for the TigerRisk acquisition.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Board consistency and experienced management team with aligned incentives through significant equity ownership
Subsubsection Text: Our Group is guided by a seasoned leadership team with consistent composition over the past 9 years and an entrepreneurial approach to business, led by our founder David Howden and supported by a board of directors and executive committee with significant industry experience. Our people first approach and entrepreneurial culture is further enriched by significant employee ownership, with approximately one-third of our shares held by around 4,500 employees, resulting in a high producer retention rate.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Conservative leverage profile and financial policy
Subsubsection Text: We have maintained a disciplined financial policy, evidenced by our conservative leverage profile which has remained in line with historical levels as we have grown our business through acquisitions. This has been achieved due to the strong EBITDA growth, the high cash conversion of our business, and the support of our institutional investors who backed our growth through additional equity funding five times since 2018. For the financial year ended September 30, 2023, shareholders invested approximately £1,000 million of equity to fund our M&A activities. Our strong organic growth has also helped to maintain our leverage profile. Despite active M&A activities, our gross leverage ratio improved from 6.6x for the financial year ended September 30, 2022, to 6.1x for the financial year ended September 30, 2023, and our net leverage ratio decreased from 5.6x to 5.1x, respectively.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Drive sustained Organic Revenue Growth
Subsubsection Text: Our Organic Revenue Growth strategy is multifaceted and designed to reinforce our presence across various markets and specialties and establishing our Group as a key competitor to the big 3 brokers. Howden UK & Ireland (“UK&I”), including UK&I Retail and Specialty, is our largest broking division with the broadest geographic footprint in the UK, providing services to corporates, personal lines clients and high net worth individuals. It offers diversified products, including P&C, employee benefits, and specialty products, backed by an extensive branch network for local service. In this region, our strategy involves working towards a fully integrated platform, which will service a wide range of clients and enable us to cross-sell services, particularly to legacy Aston Lark and A-Plan Group clients. Furthermore, we are expanding existing UK based specialisms into our businesses throughout Europe and increasing our presence in the large corporate sector. Additionally, there are opportunities to grow our consumer and commercial branch network, filling geographic gaps and extending our reach. In Europe, we have established a strong local presence in over 20 countries and mid-market corporate segments. Our European strategy emphasizes using our scale and expertise to win tenders, cross-selling specialty lines to clients via our pan-European retail operations, developing our large client segment, and attracting top industry talent. During the financial year ended September 30, 2023, we rolled out a single brand globally for most of our Group businesses to enhance global brand recognition and foster a cohesive identity. ----- A further key element of our growth strategy is to leverage our expertise in specialty product placement and access to the global insurance markets, especially the London market, to support our retail insurance brokerage clients. Our entrepreneurial team members actively seek opportunities to cross-sell specialty products to our clients across the globe. Howden Tiger ranks among the top four global reinsurance brokers, serving clients in over 30 countries. It emerged from the merger of Howden Re, specialized in facultative reinsurance and MGA services in the UK and Europe, and TigerRisk, which focused on treaty reinsurance in the US and Europe. For Reinsurance, our attention is centered on the seamless integration and realization of the synergies following the TigerRisk acquisition. We have become a credible alternative in the global reinsurance market for both talent and clients. DUAL, our underwriting division, is one of the largest international MGAs with a presence across 21 countries and 45 locations. We have built long-term relationships with more than 70 carriers globally. Our existing portfolio is extensive, encompassing financial lines, P&C, marine, energy, transactional risks, treaty reinsurance and specialist lines. Within our DUAL segment, our strategic focus includes attracting leading underwriting talent, establishing a presence in new geographies, and setting up new product lines or expanding product capabilities.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Expand through New Initiatives
Subsubsection Text: Our New Initiatives strategy focuses on lateral hiring to enter new markets and expand our capabilities in new product lines. We are an employer of choice for entrepreneurial talent, given our differentiated founder-led culture, significant employee ownership, global presence and access. We successfully on-boarded a significant number of employees in New Initiatives in recent years, totaling approximately 1,120 employees in New Initiatives as at September 30, 2023. These employees hold considerable growth potential that will be realized as they become fully integrated into Howden. For the year ended September 30, 2023, our New Initiatives made up approximately 30% of the Group’s Organic Revenue Growth, contributing about 4% to our Organic Revenue Growth of 13% in this period.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Execute disciplined M&A strategy
Subsubsection Text: Our disciplined M&A strategy has been an important element of our growth strategy. From October 1, 2015 through September 30, 2023, we completed over 100 acquisitions, accounting for approximately £1,040 million of acquired revenue. We will continue to focus on both Bolt-on and Transformational Acquisitions to build scale, enter new markets, or reinforce existing capabilities. We have been adept at identifying and reviewing M&A targets that match our entrepreneurial culture and have strong growth potential, as well as matching our strategic goals. We will maintain a disciplined approach in acquisitions, seeking to acquire targets at attractive valuations while aligning incentives through effective use of earn-outs and equity incentives, and seamlessly integrating acquired businesses.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Improve operational efficiencies
Subsubsection Text: To boost operational efficiency, we focus on leveraging technology and streamlining processes. Specifically, we are standardizing our trading platforms to generate efficiencies. We have also implemented Software-as-aservice (“SaaS”) applications for a scalable, global back-office system that improves reporting and control, as well as streamlining processes and costs. Our “On-Net” program is integrating group companies onto unified infrastructure to boost security and scalability. These investments are made with a disciplined approach to expense management, ensuring cost efficiency.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Concurrently with the Offering, we expect to enter into the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement to refinance the Refinanced Facilities and provide for the New Credit Facilities consisting of the New Revolving Credit Facility, the New Dollar Term Loan and New Euro Term Loan (the “Refinancing”). See also “Use of _Proceeds” and “Description of Other Indebtedness”._ ----- We refer to the Offering and the Refinancing (in each case, including the use of proceeds there from) as the “Transactions.”

See “Cautionary statement regarding forward-looking information” and “Risk factors” for a more complete discussion of certain of the factors that could affect our future performance and results of operations._ Since September 30, 2023, we have closed a number of acquisitions (“Recently Completed Acquisitions”), executed agreements for acquisitions the consummation of which are pending (“Acquisitions under SPAs”) and signed letters of intent to purchase several other targets in our pipeline which are expected to complete within three months following the date of this Offering Memorandum (“Acquisitions under LOIs”, and collectively with the Recently Completed Acquisitions and the Acquisitions under SPA, the “Near-Term Acquisitions”). Based on review and analysis of available materials which may include marketing documents, due diligence reports, financial statements and legal documentation with adjustments incorporated where appropriate based on our sector, financial, legal and professional expertise, we have estimated that the main impacts of the Near-Term Acquisitions on our financial results to be:

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: (i) The exchange rate used to convert USD and EUR-denominated figures for purposes of this table is the GBP:USD spot rate of 1.22 and the GBP:EUR spot rate of 1.16 as of September 30, 2023. The adjustments set forth above are based on the results of operations of the targets as provided by the sellers, which financial information may not have been prepared, adjusted or presented in line with that of the Group. (3) Reflects the actual cash expended for the Recently Completed Acquisitions or good faith estimates of management of the cash outflow that will be required in connection with the Acquisitions under SPAs and the Acquisitions under LOIs. (4) Reflects the actual amount of IFRS leases acquired from the Recently Completed Acquisitions or good faith estimates of management of the IFRS 16 leases that will be acquired from the Acquisitions under SPAs and Acquistions under LOIs, as ascertained from seller-provided data. _The estimated impact of the Near-Term Acquisitions on our financial results as set out in the table above has not been audited, reviewed, examined, compiled, nor have any agreed-upon procedures been applied with respect thereto by Ernst & Young LLP, our independent auditors. Accordingly, Ernst & Young LLP does not express an opinion or any other form for assurance with respect thereto. You should not place undue reliance on such unaudited preliminary financial information. The estimated impact of the Near-Term Acquisitions on our financial results are based upon the best available information and certain assumptions that management believes to be reasonable. The estimated impact of the Near-Term Acquisitions on our financial results is presented for informational purposes only and is not necessarily indicative of the consolidated results of operations that would have been realized had these Near-Term Acquisitions occurred as of 1 October 2022, nor is it meant to be indicative of any anticipated future results of operations of the Group in any future period._ In November 2023, we raised an incremental $585 million fungible add-on to the 2030 Dollar Term Loan (the “Incremental Term Loan”) to refinance $255 million of the SOFR + 525 bps tranche of the Existing Dollar Term Loans with a more attractively priced facility. The remaining balance of the Incremental Term Loan ----- proceeds, after fees and expenses, was used to fund an additional $316 million of cash to our balance sheet to support the Recently Completed Acquisitions and the Acquisitions under SPAs. As part of the Refinancing, we intend to fully repay the remaining balance on the SOFR + 525 bps tranche of the Existing Dollar Term Loans and reprice the 2030 Dollar Term Loan. See “Use of Proceeds”. In December 2023, HGH Midco 2 raised an additional €350 million PIK facility (the “Additional PIK Facility”) that is available for use, at HGH Midco 2’s sole discretion, in connection with the Near-Term Acquisitions, any further acquisitions and general corporate purposes, and HGH Midco 2 agreed a nine-year extension to the tenor of the existing PIK Notes that shall take effect on the earlier of: (i) March 8, 2024; (ii) the date on which the Additional PIK Facility is drawn; and (iii) the date on which HGH Midco 2, at its sole discretion, confirms by notice that the nine-year extension is effected. The PIK Notes and the Additional PIK Facility and any potential future drawings under it are not guaranteed by, and have not recourse to, the Group (see “Summary—Corporate Structure”). We refer to the Incremental Term Loan, the drawings under the Additional PIK Facility and the use of proceeds thereof for the purpose of funding the Recently Completed Acquisitions and the Acquisitions under SPAs as the “Events after the Reporting Date”.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: For the twelve month period ended December 31, 2023, our estimated Adjusted Revenue was between £2,515 million and £2,535 million, reflecting Organic Revenue Growth of approximately 10% and the impact of acquisitions completed since September 30, 2023. For the twelve month period ended December 31, 2023, our estimated Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA was between £795 million and £800 million, reflecting an Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA margin of approximately 32%. Our first fiscal quarter is generally a less active period as a result of the seasonality of our business (see “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of _Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Seasonality”)._ Our results were broadly in line with our expectations for that period and generally consistent with our full year 2023 results, including the impact of continuing headwinds in the transactional businesses and foreign exchange impacts. Our second fiscal quarter includes an important renewal period for our business, and current trends are in line with our expectations. _The unaudited preliminary financial information for the periods presented above are derived from our accounting records and has been calculated by management. This information has not been audited, reviewed, examined, compiled, nor have any agreed-upon procedures been applied with respect thereto by Ernst & Young LLP, our independent auditors. Accordingly, Ernst & Young LLP does not express an opinion or any other form for assurance with respect thereto. You should not place undue reliance on such unaudited preliminary financial information. This preliminary unaudited financial information is based upon a number of assumptions and judgments that are subject to inherent uncertainties and are subject to change and are not intended to be a comprehensive statement of our financial or operational results for the periods presented above. Consequently, upon finalization of our results for the three months ended December 31, 2023, we may report results that are materially different from the ones set forth in this section. See “Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors” elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum for a more complete discussion of certain of the factors that could affect our business, financial position and results of operations._

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: General Atlantic
Subsubsection Text: General Atlantic is a leading global growth investor with more than four decades of experience providing capital and strategic support for over 500 growth companies throughout its history. Established in 1980, the firm has approximately $83 billion in assets under management inclusive of all products as of December 31, 2023, and more than 280 investment professionals. With 16 locations across five global regions, the firm combines a collaborative global approach, sector specific expertise, a long-term investment horizon and a deep understanding of growth drivers to partner with great entrepreneurs and management teams to scale innovative businesses around the world. -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec
Subsubsection Text: Established in 1965, CDPQ is a global investment group managing funds for public pension and insurance plans. The group works alongside its partners to build enterprises that drive performance and progress. They are active in the major financial markets, private equity, infrastructure, real estate and private debt. As at June 30, 2023, CDPQ’s net assets totaled CA$424 billion. _CDPQ is a registered trademark owned by Caisse de dépôt et placement du Québec and licensed for use by its subsidiaries._

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Title: Hg
Subsubsection Text: Hg a leading investor in European and transatlantic software and services businesses. Hg supports the building of sector-leading enterprises that supply businesses with critical software applications or workflow services, delivering a more automated workplace for their customers. This industry is characterized by digitization trends that are in early stages of adoption and are set to transform the workplace for professionals over decades to come. Hg’s support combines deep end-market knowledge with world class operational resources, together providing compelling support to entrepreneurial leaders looking to scale their business – businesses that are well invested, enduring and serve their customers well. With a vast European network and strong presence across North America, Hg’s 400 employees and $65 billion in funds under management support a portfolio of more than 50 businesses, worth over $135 billion aggregate enterprise value, with over 100 thousand employees, consistently growing revenues at more than 20% annually. Additional information is available at www.hgcapital.com. -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: New Revolving **Limited[(10)]** **Refinance Plc[(3)]** **Refinance LLC[(3)]** **Limited[(10)] Credit Facility[(8)] Senior Secured Notes[(5)] GuarantorsSubsidiary[(10)]** **Non-Guarantor Subsidiaries[(11)]** 2030 Dollar Term Loan[(9)] **Hyperion RefinanceS.à r.l.[(10)]** New Dollar TermLoan[(7)] (1) As of September 30, 2023, approximately 68% of our share capital was owned by the Sponsors and 32% by management and employees, directly or indirectly. See “Security Ownership.” (2) The PIK Notes comprise the GBP-denominated 9.25% payment-in-kind floating rate notes and the EUR-denominated 8.50% payment-in-kind floating rate notes issued by HGH Midco 2. The PIK Notes are not guaranteed by, and have no recourse to, HGH Finance or any of its subsidiaries, but are secured by shares in HGH Finance, the top entity of the Restricted Group. In December 2023, HGH Midco 2 established the Additional PIK Facility that is available for use, at its sole discretion, in connection with the Near-Term Acquisitions, any further acquisitions and general corporate purposes, and agreed to extend the tenor of the existing PIK Notes to nine years from the earlier of: (i) March 8, 2024; (ii) when the Additional PIK Facility is drawn; and (iii) the date on which the issuer of the PIK Notes, at its sole discretion, confirms by notice that the 9 year extension is effective. See “Summary—Recent Developments”. (3) The SSN UK Issuer and the SSN US Co-Issuer (collectively, the “SSN Issuers”) will be the issuers of the Senior Secured Notes. The SSN Issuers will also guarantee the obligations pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement on a senior basis and will guarantee the Senior Notes on a senior subordinated basis. None of the SSN Issuers has any subsidiaries or revenue-generating operations of its own and no material obligations other than its obligations under the Notes and pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. (4) The SUN UK Issuer and the SUN US Co-Issuer (collectively, the “SUN Issuers”) will be the issuers of the Senior Notes. The SUN Issuers will also guarantee the obligations pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement and the Senior Secured Notes on a senior basis. None of the SUN Issuers has any subsidiaries or revenue-generating operations of its own and no material obligations other than its obligations under the Notes and pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. (5) The Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees will be: (i) senior secured obligations of the SSN Issuers and the SSN Guarantors; (ii) secured by senior priority liens (subject to the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement, the Agreed Security Principles and any limitations set out in the Security Documents) on the Collateral (subject to a shared lien of equal priority with the SSN and the SSN Guarantors’ obligations pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement and subject to other prior ranking liens permitted by the Senior Secured Notes Indenture); (iii) ranking equal in right of payment with all of the SSN Issuers’ and the SSN Guarantors’existing and future senior indebtedness; (iv) effectively senior to the SSN Issuers’and the SSN Guarantors’ existing and future unsecured indebtedness (including the Senior Notes) or indebtedness secured by a junior priority lien; (v) senior in right of payment to all of the SSN Issuers’ and the SSN Guarantors’ existing and future subordinated indebtedness; and ----- (vi) structurally subordinated to all of the existing and future indebtedness of our existing and future subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Senior Secured Notes. See “Description of Senior Secured Notes.” (6) The Senior Notes and the Senior Notes Guarantees will: (i) be, respectively, senior obligations of the SUN Issuers and senior subordinated obligations of the SUN Guarantors; (ii) be unsecured; (iii) with respect to the Senior Notes, rank equal in right of payment with all of the SUN Issuers’existing and future senior indebtedness; (iv) with respect to the Senior Notes Guarantees, rank subordinated in right of payment with all of the SUN Guarantors’ existing and future senior indebtedness; (v) be effectively subordinated to the SUN Issuers’ and the SUN Guarantors’ existing and future secured indebtedness or indebtedness secured by any lien; (vi) be junior in right of payment to all of the SUN Issuers’ and the SUN Guarantors’ existing and future unsubordinated indebtedness; and (vii) be structurally subordinated to all of the existing and future indebtedness of our existing and future subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Senior Notes. See “Description of Senior Notes.” (7) The New Term Loan Facilities are comprised of the New Euro Term Loan and the New Dollar Term Loan. The New Term Loan Facilities are guaranteed on a senior secured basis by the Issuers and the Shared Guarantors and, subject to the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement, the Agreed Security Principles and any limitations set out in the relevant security documents, secured by senior priority liens on the Collateral. See “Description of Other Indebtedness—First Lien Credit Agreement.” (8) The New Revolving Credit Facility will provide for borrowings up to £630 million for general corporate purpose, £75 million of which was drawn subsequent to September 30, 2023 for short-term working capital purposes but intended to be repaid shortly following the Issue Date. The New Revolving Credit Facility is guaranteed on a senior secured basis by the Issuers and the Shared Guarantors and, subject to the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement, the Agreed Security Principles and any limitations set out in the relevant security documents, secured by senior priority liens on the Collateral. See “Description of Other Indebtedness—First _Lien Credit Agreement”._ (9) Refers to the 2030 Dollar Term that will remain outstanding after the Refinancing. (10) Each of our restricted subsidiaries that will guarantee obligations pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement from time to time will jointly and severally guarantee the Notes. The Senior Secured Notes will be guaranteed on the Issue Date on a senior secured basis by the SUN Issuers and the Issue Date Guarantors. See “Description of Senior Secured Notes—Guarantees.” The Senior Notes will be guaranteed on the Issue Date on a senior subordinated basis by the SSN Issuers and the Issue Date Guarantors. See “Description of Senior Notes—Guarantees.” The remaining Post-Closing Guarantors will guarantee the Notes by no later than 120 days of the Issue Date (or such other date as agreed with the administrative agent under the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement) (the “Post-Closing Date”). Based on the relevant calculation method in the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement, we estimate that the Guarantors accounted for approximately 70% of our EBITDA for the year ended September 30, 2023. (11) Certain subsidiaries will not guarantee the Notes. As of September 30, 2023, subsidiaries that are not expected to guarantee the Notes had £107 million of outstanding third-party debt. See “Capitalization.” -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Senior Secured Notes On the Issue Date, subject to the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement, the Agreed Security Principles, any limitations set out in the Security Documents, as well as certain permitted liens and other exceptions, the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees will be secured on a senior priority basis by security interests (collectively, the “Issue Date Collateral”) in: - shares in the capital stock of each of the Issuers and the Issue Date Guarantors (other than HGH Finance); - subject to certain exceptions, the bank accounts of each of the Issuers and the Issue Date Guarantors; - customary all-asset security including, in certain cases, over intercompany loans, receivables (subject to certain exclusions) of the Issuers and the Issue Date Guarantors. On the Post-Closing Date, subject to the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement, the Agreed Security Principles, any limitations set out in the Security Documents, as well as certain permitted liens and other exceptions, the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees will also be secured on a senior priority basis by security interests (the “Post-Closing Collateral,” and, together with the Issue Date Collateral, the “Collateral”) in: - shares in the capital stock of each of the Post-Closing Guarantors; - subject to certain exceptions, the bank accounts of each of the Post-Closing Guarantors; - customary all-asset security including, in certain cases, over intercompany loans, receivables (subject to certain exclusions) of the Post-Closing Guarantors. See “Description of Senior Secured Notes—Security for the Notes.” The Collateral will also secure the obligations pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement on a senior priority basis. Senior Notes The Senior Notes and the Senior Notes Guarantees will be unsecured.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Senior Secured Notes The Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees will: - be senior secured obligations of the SSN Issuers and the SSN Guarantors; - be secured by senior priority liens (subject to the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement, the Agreed Security Principles and any limitations set out in the Security Documents) on the Collateral ----- (subject to a shared lien of equal priority with the SSN Issuers’ and the SSN Guarantors’ obligations pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement and subject to other prior ranking liens permitted by the Senior Secured Notes Indenture); - rank equal in right of payment with all of the SSN Issuers’ and the SSN Guarantors’ existing and future senior indebtedness; - be effectively senior to the SSN Issuers’and the SSN Guarantors’ existing and future unsecured indebtedness (including the Senior Notes) or indebtedness secured by a junior priority lien; - be senior in right of payment to all of the SSN Issuers’ and the SSN Guarantors’existing and future subordinated indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to all of the existing and future indebtedness of our existing and future subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Senior Secured Notes. Senior Notes The Senior Notes will: - be senior obligations of the SUN Issuers; - be unsecured; - rank equal in right of payment with all of the SUN Issuers’ existing and future senior indebtedness; - be effectively subordinated to the SUN Issuers’ existing and future secured indebtedness or indebtedness secured by any lien; - be senior in right of payment to all of the SUN Issuers’ existing and future subordinated indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to all of the existing and future indebtedness of our existing and future subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Senior Notes. Senior Notes Guarantees The Senior Notes Guarantees will: - be senior subordinated obligations of the SUN Guarantors; - be unsecured; - rank subordinated in right of payment with all of the SUN Guarantors’ existing and future senior indebtedness; - be effectively subordinated to the SUN Guarantors’ existing and future secured indebtedness or indebtedness secured by any lien; - be junior in right of payment to all of the SUN Guarantors’ existing and future unsubordinated indebtedness; and - be structurally subordinated to all of the existing and future indebtedness of our existing and future subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Senior Notes. -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: Senior Secured Notes Except as described below and under “Description of Senior Secured Notes,” we cannot redeem the Senior Secured Notes before_, 2027. Prior to, 2027 we may redeem the Senior Secured Notes, in whole or in part, at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof to be redeemed plus the make-whole premium described under “Description of Senior Secured Notes—Optional Redemption,” plus accrued and unpaid interest to, but excluding, the redemption date. On and after, 2027 we may redeem the Senior Secured Notes, in whole or in part, at the redemption prices (expressed as percentages of principal amount of the notes to be redeemed) listed under “Description of Senior Secured Notes—Optional Redemption,” plus accrued and unpaid interest thereon, if any, to, but excluding the applicable redemption date, subject to certain rights of holders of record of the Senior Secured Notes. Prior to, 2027 we may on any one or more occasions redeem during any twelve month period up to 10% of the original principal amount of the Senior Secured Notes originally issued under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture (including the original principal amount of any additional Senior Secured Notes), upon not less than 10 and not more than 60 days’ notice, at a redemption price of 103% of the principal amount of the Senior Secured Notes so redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but not including, the redemption date, subject to the right of Holders on the relevant record date to receive interest due on the relevant interest payment date. See “Description of Senior Secured Notes— _Optional Redemption.”_ Prior to, 2027 we may, on one or more occasions, redeem up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the Senior Secured Notes (including the aggregate principal amount of any additional Senior Secured Notes issued) at a redemption price equal to % of the principal amount of Senior Secured Notes so redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings so long as at least 50% of the original principal amount of the Senior Secured Notes (including any additional Senior Secured Notes), issued under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture remain outstanding. Senior Notes Except as described below and under “Description of Senior Notes,” we cannot redeem the Senior Notes before, 2027. Prior to, 2027 we may redeem the Senior Notes, in whole or in part, at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof to be redeemed plus the make-whole premium described under “Description of Senior Notes—Optional Redemption,” plus accrued and unpaid interest to, but excluding, the redemption date. On and after, 2027 we may redeem the Senior Notes, in whole or in part, at the redemption prices (expressed as percentages of principal amount of the notes to be redeemed) listed under “Description of Senior Notes—Optional Redemption,” plus accrued ----- and unpaid interest thereon, if any, to, but excluding the applicable redemption date, subject to certain rights of holders of record. Prior to, 2027 we may, on one or more occasions, redeem up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the Senior Notes (including the aggregate principal amount of any additional Senior Notes issued) at a redemption price equal to % of the principal amount of Senior Notes so redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, with the net cash proceeds from certain equity offerings so long as at least 50% of the original principal amount of the Senior Notes (including any additional Senior Notes), issued under the Senior Notes Indenture remain outstanding. Original Issue Discount:** The Notes offered hereby may be issued with original issue discount (“OID”) for United States federal income tax purposes. In such case, in addition to the stated interest on the Notes, a holder subject to United States federal income taxation will be required to include the OID in gross income (as ordinary income) as it accrues (on a constant yield to maturity basis) in advance of the receipt of the cash payment thereof and regardless of such holder’s regular method of accounting for United States federal income tax purposes. See “Tax _considerations—Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Considerations— Original Issue Discount.”_ Change of control:** If certain kinds of “change of control” events occur, we must offer to purchase the Notes at 101% of their principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest. For more details, you should read “Description _of Senior Secured Notes—Repurchase at the Option of Holders— Change of Control” and “Description of Senior Notes—Repurchase at the Option of Holders—Change of Control.”_ Asset sale proceeds:** If we or our restricted subsidiaries engage in asset sales, subject to certain material exceptions, we generally must either invest the net cash proceeds from such asset sales in our business within a specified period of time, repay certain senior secured debt or make an offer to purchase a principal amount of the Notes equal to the excess net cash proceeds. The purchase price of the notes will be 100% of their principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest. See “Description _of Senior Secured Notes—Repurchase at the Option of Holders—Asset Sales”and “Description of Senior Notes—Repurchase at the Option of Holders—Asset Sales.”_ Certain covenants:** The Senior Secured Notes Indenture and the Senior Notes Indenture will each contain certain covenants that, among other things, limit our ability and the ability of our restricted subsidiaries to: - pay dividends or distributions, repurchase equity, prepay junior debt and make certain investments; - incur additional debt or issue certain disqualified stock and preferred stock; - incur liens on assets; - merge or consolidate with another company or sell, assign, transfer, lease, convey or otherwise dispose of all or substantially all of its assets; - enter into transactions with affiliates; and ----- - allow to exist certain restrictions on the ability of restricted subsidiaries to pay dividends or make other payments to us. These covenants are subject to important exceptions and qualifications as described under “Description of Senior Secured _Notes—Certain Covenants” and “Description of Senior Notes— Certain Covenants.”Certain covenants will cease to apply to the Notes_ for so long as the Notes have investment grade ratings. Absence of established market for** The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no the Notes:** established market. Although certain of the Initial Purchasers have informed us that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are not obligated to do so, and may discontinue market making activities at any time without notice. Accordingly, we cannot assure you that a liquid market for the Notes will develop or be maintained. Listing:** Although application will be made to the Authority for the listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange, no assurance can be given that the Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the Notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained. Use of proceeds:** We expect to use the proceeds of the Transactions, after payment of our estimated fees and expenses, to refinance a portion of our Existing Dollar Term Loans, repay our Existing Euro Term Loans in full, repay our Second Lien Facility in full and for general corporate purposes. See “Use of Proceeds.” Risk factors:** Investing in the Notes involves substantial risks. In evaluating an investment in the Notes, prospective investors should carefully consider, along with other information in this Offering Memorandum, the specific factors set forth under “Risk Factors” for risks involved with an investment in the Notes. Listing Agent:** Ogier Corporate Finance Limited. -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsection Title: Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data
Subsubsection Text: _The following table sets forth our summary historical consolidated financial data as of the dates and for the periods indicated. On September 27, 2021, a new holding company, HGH Finance, was created and was subsequently inserted between HGH Limited and the operating subsidiaries of the Group on January 25, 2022 (the “HGH Finance Reorganization”). Therefore, as of and for the year ended September 30, 2021, the financial statements of the Group were consolidated and reported at the level of HGH Limited. The summary historical consolidated financial data have been derived from the 2023 Financial Statements and the 2022 Financial Statements, which have been audited by Ernst & Young LLP, our independent auditors, and the 2021 Financial Statements, which have been audited by Deloitte LLP, our independent auditors for that period with the exception of certain line items of the HGH Limited Consolidated Cash Flow Statement for the year ended September 30, 2021 which are being presented on a restated basis. Such restated amounts have therefore been extracted from the unaudited comparative column in the HGH Limited financial statements for the year ended September 30, 2022, such figures also being consistent with the equivalent figures in the 2022 Financial Statements. The restated Consolidated Cash Flow Statement for the year ended September 30, 2021 has not been audited by Deloitte LLP. The following tables also contain various measures and ratios that are not presented in accordance with IFRS (the “Non-IFRS Measures”). Such measures and ratios may not accurately reflect our performance, liquidity or our ability to incur debt, have limitations as analytical tools, and should not be considered as alternatives to operating profit or (loss)/profit for the year or any other performance measures derived from or in accordance with US GAAP, IFRS, SEC requirements or any other generally accepted accounting principles or as alternatives to cash flow from operating activities. Our Non-IFRS Measures may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures of other companies and have limitations as analytical tools and should not be considered in isolation or as a substitute for analysis of our operating results as reported under IFRS. Because of these limitations, our Non-IFRS Measures should not be considered as measures of discretionary cash available to us to invest in the growth of our business or as measures of cash that will be available to us to meet our obligations. You should compensate for these limitations by relying primarily on our financial statements and using these Non-IFRS Measures only supplementally to evaluate our performance. The historical results included below and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum are not necessarily indicative of our future performance and should be read in conjunction with “Selected Historical Financial Data,” “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations,” the Financial Statements and related notes included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum and the unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements and the related notes included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum._

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: ----- (i) Up to the year ended September 30, 2023 the Group had only two reporting segments: Howden Broking Group (which comprised of insurance and reinsurance broking) and DUAL. Howden Broking Group was removed as a reporting division from October 1, 2023. (ii) Includes head office and profit commission. Excluded from Organic Revenue Growth calculation. (1) We define Adjusted Revenue as IFRS Revenue adjusted for (i) the pre-acquisition revenue attributable to M&A during the year acquired, to present the run rate as if they had been made at the start of the applicable financial year, (ii) the pre-disposal results of entities that were disposed of or closed by the Group during the applicable fiscal year that do not qualify as discontinued operations under IFRS 5, to present the run rate as if they had been made at the start of the applicable financial year and (iii) other adjustments encompassing IFRS 15 impacts for M&A in the year which are non-run rate in nature, as well as some intercompany adjustments.

Section Title: SUMMARY
SUMMARY
SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: (2) “Organic Revenue” is defined as IFRS Revenue adjusted for (i) revenue attributable to M&A during the first 12 months of the Group’s ownership as if they had been made at the start of the financial year, adjusted to a constant average foreign exchange rate for the year in which the reconciliation is performed. The comparative is also restated for acquisitions made during the current year to include the pre-acquisition results for the preceding year so that the perimeter is constant for purposes of calculating Organic Revenue Growth, (ii) operations that were disposed of or closed by the Group during the fiscal year that do not qualify as discontinued operations under IFRS 5, to present the run rate as if they had been made at the start of the financial year, adjusted to a constant average foreign exchange rate for the year in which the reconciliation is performed, (iii) additional commissions which can be earned by DUAL that are contingent on the underwriting result of the underlying contracts. The income on the performance of an underwriting year can take a number of years to realize and is highly variable in both quantum and timing. Therefore, volatility of the DUAL profit contingent commissions does not aid in the understanding of the organic growth of the business, (iv) other foreign exchange adjustments to IFRS revenue to achieve a constant foreign exchange rate for the year in which the reconciliation is performed, (v) adjustment for the non-run rate elements of IFRS 15 and (vi) add-back for the insurance income as per the Statement of Profit or Loss. Industry peers provide similar supplemental information about their revenue performance, although they may not make identical adjustments.

Subsubsection Text: (a) Refers to the revenue attributable to recent acquisitions during the first 12 months under the Group’s ownership as if they had been made at the start of the financial year, adjusted to a constant average foreign exchange rate for the year in which the reconciliation is performed. The comparative is also restated for acquisitions made during the current year to include the pre-acquisition results for the preceding year so that the perimeter is constant for purposes of calculating Organic Revenue Growth. (b) Refers to operations that were disposed of or closed by the Group during the fiscal year that do not qualify as discontinued operations under IFRS 5, to present the run rate as if they had been made at the start of the financial year, adjusted to a constant average foreign exchange rate for the year in which the reconciliation is performed. (c) This relates to additional commissions which can be earned by DUAL that are contingent on the underwriting result of the underlying contracts. The income on the performance of an underwriting year can take a number of years to realize and is highly variable in both quantum and timing. Therefore, volatility of the DUAL profit contingent commissions does not aid in the understanding of the organic growth of the business. (d) Other foreign exchange adjustments to IFRS revenue to achieve a constant foreign exchange rate for the year in which the reconciliation is performed. (e) Adjustment for the non-run rate elements of IFRS 15. (f) Add-back for the insurance income as per the Statement of Profit or Loss. -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: The key items bridging from EBITDA to Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA are as follows: (a) Refer to EBITDA reconciliation in (2) above for bridge from loss after tax to EBITDA. (b) Adjustments relating to fair value movements on deferred and contingent consideration arrangements, put options held by non-controlling interests of certain subsidiaries and investments held at fair value through the income statement. (c) Adjustments relating to non-operating items such as gain/loss on disposal of operations and dividends from equity investments held at fair value. (d) This adjustment for New Initiatives refers to new hires from expansion into new territories or new product lines that do not yet generate profit and take time to reach run rate profitability as they build a client base. This adjustment relates to the add-back of EBITDA losses of these lateral hires incurred in the financial year during this growth phase and is calculated by investment. The increase year on year relates to various programs within Insurance, Reinsurance and DUAL, including new hires driven by market dislocation arising from M&A in the insurance market. (e) Represents costs which are not considered run-rate costs or relating to the underlying performance of the Group.

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: (i) Litigation costs refers to litigation costs, legal fees and provisions raised in respect of significant instances of litigation against the Group. See “Business—Legal Proceedings.” (ii) Lateral hires relates to set-up costs relating to sign-on and retention bonuses and other initial costs for new personnel hires resulting from expansion into new territories or new product lines. ----- (iii) Integration and restructuring costs relate to redundancy costs, re-organization costs and costs associated with onerous contracts following an acquisition or operational restructure. (iv) Group-wide transformation projects relate to projects which add new significant capabilities or are transformational to the Group. Examples include the creation of global front end trading systems for both Howden and DUAL, implementation of global IT platforms and implementation of global IT security standards. (v) Non-current assets impairments related to the charges taken in respect of goodwill and intangible assets. (vi) The Covid-19 adjustment relates to all incremental costs and income directly attributable to the Covid-19 pandemic. This ranges from items such as government cash grants in certain non-UK jurisdictions, travel cancellations, setting up employees to work from home and making office spaces Covid-19 safe in line with local requirements. (vii) Employee service post-business combination relates to the continuing provision of services rendered by employees of acquired businesses, which are performed in order to earn deferred or contingent consideration for an acquisition, or to fulfil vesting requirements of Howden shares issued as consideration as part of an acquisition. (viii) Other items relate to onerous contracts and other items considered not to be run-rate in nature. (f) Acquisition costs, which relate to professional and other incremental costs directly attributable to acquisitions and disposals of businesses and minority interests. (g) IFRS adjustments, which adjust for non-cash transactions required to be recognized in profit and loss under IFRS relating in particular to the reversal of: (i) IFRS 2 share based payment charges of £27.0 million (2022: £23.7 million, 2021: £9.1 million); (ii) transactional foreign exchange gains and losses arising on the revaluation of monetary items deemed non-financing in nature £31.4 million (2022: £44.7 million, 2021: £12.2 million); (iii) IFRS 15 gains of £3.4 million (2022: £6.9 million, 2021: £1.4 million) which are not run-rate in nature; and (iv) in 2022 only, intercompany interest charges from the parent company recorded in operating profit of £2.7 million. (h) Adjustments relating to the pre-acquisition EBITDA attributable to acquisitions (M&A) during the year acquired, to present the run rate as if they had been made at the start of the financial year. (i) Adjustment to remove the pre-disposal results of entities that were disposed of or closed by the Group during the fiscal year that do not qualify as discontinued operations under IFRS 5, to present the run rate as if they had been made at the start of the financial year. (j) Adjustments relating to the unrealized portion of identifiable cost reduction savings programs currently undertaken and the expected benefit that would have been realized if they were in effect from the beginning of the year. (4) We define Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA margin as Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA as a percentage of our Adjusted Revenue for the relevant period. (5) We define Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA excluding M&A and cost synergies as Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA, less pro forma results of M&A and closed operations, and less pro forma pre-acquisition results of cost synergy programs. Please refer to the subtotal in (3) above. (6) We define “Management Operating Cash” as cash generated from operations, adjusted for (i) cash outflows on the movement in insurance cash, (ii) cash inflows on investment in New Initiatives treated as an investment activity, (iii) cash inflows on exceptional items deemed non-run rate in nature, (iv) cash flows on Maintenance CapEx, (v) cash flows to pay for accrued transaction expenses on the Align acquisition, (vi) cash inflows on employee loans and (vii) other adjustments. We believe that Management Operating Cash provides relevant and useful information on the ability of the business to generate cash from its mature operations on an ongoing basis with improved comparability between periods and eliminates the impact of items that do not relate to ongoing operating cash generation of the business.

(7) We define Operating Cash Conversion as Management Operating Cash divided by Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA excluding M&A and cost synergies. (8) Pro Forma Adjusted Revenue represents adjustments to our Adjusted Revenue in connection with certain M&A activity following September 30, 2023, which, as a result, were not consolidated within our financial results. In particular, we have adjusted our Adjusted Revenue to reflect the estimated pro forma revenue contribution from Near-Term Acquisitions assuming each of the acquisitions had occurred on October 1, 2022 instead of the actual acquisition dates. The adjustments set forth below are based on the results of operations of the targets as provided by the sellers, which financial information may not have been prepared, adjusted or presented in line with that of the Group. Pro Forma Adjusted Revenue has been presented for illustrative purposes only and does not purport to show what our Adjusted Revenue would have actually been had the Near-Term Acquisitions occurred on the date assumed, nor does it purport to project our Adjusted Revenue for any future period or our financial condition at any future date. See “Presentation of Financial and Other _Information—Adjusted and Pro Forma Financial Information.”_ Although we believe the adjustments relating to the Near-Term Acquisitions to be accurate, the underlying information for such adjustments has been received from the sellers during the sale process and cannot be independently verified by our management, has not been independently reviewed or audited, may be prepared on a basis different than our own data and in some cases was based on estimated full year outturns. We cannot assure you that the financial statements of the Near-Term Acquisitions would not be materially different if such statements were audited or that the results of our Recently Completed Acquisitions match those shown below. Although there is no assurance that the Near-Term Acquisitions that have not closed as of the date of this Offering Memorandum will close or the timing thereof, we expect they will close within three months following the date of this Offering Memorandum and we expect to fund such acquisitions with cash on hand, including the net proceeds from the Transactions.

In particular, we have adjusted our Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA to reflect the estimated pro forma EBITDA contribution from entities (i) the acquisitions of which were completed after September 30, 2023 (the “Recently Completed Acquisitions”), (ii) for which acquisition agreements have been executed and consummation of the acquisitions pending (“Acquisitions under SPAs”) and (iii) the acquisitions of which are currently subject to letters of intent (“LOIs”) and expected to complete within three months ----- following the date of this Offering Memorandum (“Acquisitions under LOIs”) (the acquisitions described in (i), (ii) and (iii), collectively, the “Near-Term Acquisitions”) assuming each of the acquisitions had occurred on October 1, 2022 instead of the actual acquisition dates. The adjustments to Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA are based on good faith estimates of management of the pricing EBITDA of each entity, re-calculated on a post-IFRS 16 basis where needed, and aggregated for all of the Near-Term Acquisitions. Pricing EBITDA, in turn, is based on the results of operations of the targets as provided by the sellers, which financial information may not have been prepared, adjusted or presented in line with that of the Group. See “Capitalization.” (14) Pro Forma Adjusted Senior Secured Net Debt represents the Adjusted Senior Secured Debt less Pro Forma Adjusted cash and cash equivalents. (15) Pro Forma Adjusted Total Net debt represents Adjusted Total Debt less Pro Forma Adjusted cash and cash equivalents. (16) Adjusted cash interest expense assumes that all indebtedness shown in the “As Adjusted”column of the table under “Capitalization” was outstanding from October 1, 2022 to September 30, 2023. Adjusted financial interest expense excludes charges related to debt issuance costs. Adjusted financial interest expense has been presented for illustrative purposes only and does not purport to represent what our interest expense would have actually been had the Transactions occurred on the date assumed, nor does it purport to project our interest expense for any future period or our financial condition at any future date. -----

Section Title: SUMMARY
Subsubsection Text: _This summary highlights selected information about the Group and about the Offering contained elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, but it may not contain all of the information that is important to you. To better understand the Offering, and for a more complete description of the Offering, you should read this entire Offering Memorandum carefully, including the sections entitled “Risk Factors” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations” and the Financial Statements. Unless otherwise noted, references to “EBITDA,” “Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA,” “Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA excluding M&A and cost synergies,” “Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA margin,” “Adjusted Revenue,” “Management Operating Cash,” “Operating Cash Conversion,” “Organic Revenue,” “Organic Revenue Growth” and “Pro Forma Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA” have the meanings set forth under “—Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business and results of operations depend on decisions and actions by insurance carriers and trends in the general insurance industry, which are beyond our control.
Subsubsection Text: We are engaged in insurance brokerage and agency activities and derive revenue principally from commissions paid by insurance carriers. Historically, the results of companies in the insurance carrier industry have been subject to significant fluctuations and uncertainties. The industry’s profitability, and therefore the profitability of our own business, may be affected significantly by competition and consolidation, capital availability, cyclicality, historical and expected loss experiences, and volatile and unpredictable developments, including man-made, climate-related and other natural catastrophes. The demand for our insurance products varies significantly, closely tracking the fluctuations in overall economic activity. As economic activity intensifies, we generally observe an increase in demand for insurance products, which conversely declines during periods of economic downturn. Furthermore, client demand is influenced by specific dynamics within a particular industry or client segment, over which we exert no control. There is no assurance that the insurance industry will effectively adapt to changing consumer needs by providing suitable product lines or maintaining adequate access to capacity. Should the industry fail to promptly respond to these evolving demands, there is a considerable risk that consumers may increasingly resort to self-insurance or alternative risk mitigation methods. Such shift would result in a reduced overall need for traditional insurance products, thereby reducing the number of submissions and commissions and, therefore, may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. We also depend on the continued ability of insurance companies and other third parties to underwrite risk and provide coverage and capacity, which, in turn, is contingent on insurance carriers’ ability to procure reinsurance and therefore reinsurers’ ability to access capital. If the insurance companies we rely upon are unable to provide enough capacity for key risks, or if they fail to keep up with the fast changing risk environment, our clients may decide not to purchase these products or may forsake insurance entirely. For example, the demand and the scope of insurance products involving socio-political (war or terrorism coverage), climate (catastrophe coverage and energy transition risk), legal, and technology risks have changed frequently in the last years. As a result, we may not be able to procure the amount or type of coverage that our customers desire, or the coverage we are able to procure may be more expensive or limited. In addition, if a significant insurer fails or withdraws from writing certain lines of coverage that we offer to our clients, we could lose clients or be unable to place insurance coverage for certain risks for which we do not have alternative markets, which may adversely impact our business, results of operations and financial condition. Our relationships and agreements with insured clients, retail brokers, trading partners, including exclusive insurance carriers, are generally terminable on short notice by either party for any reason. In many cases, our counterparties have the ability to amend the terms of the agreements. Insurance carriers may be unwilling to allow us to sell their existing or new insurance products, limit our ability to distribute their products in certain geographies, amend our agreements with them to our detriment, or decide to rely on their own internal distribution channels. If any counterparty terminates or amends their relationship with us, we may lose a source of, or be paid reduced commissions for, future sales.
