Our business could also be harmed if we fail to develop new insurance carrier relationships. ----- Additionally, to the extent that reinsurance becomes scarce as a result of adverse economic conditions, consolidation or disintermediation, our commission rates and/or premiums may decline and may significantly affect our profitability. Similarly, retail brokers and other trading partners could develop their own wholesale distribution channels or choose to work with wholesale distributors other than us. This could reduce the number of submissions we receive which could result in reduced commissions and, therefore, may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. Our business could also be harmed if we fail to develop new relationships with retail brokers or other sources of business.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Competition in our industry is intense, and if we are unable to compete effectively, we may lose market share and our business may be materially adversely affected.
Subsubsection Text: We face competition in all markets in which we operate, primarily based on product breadth, innovation, quality of service, and price. Over the last several decades, large insurance brokerages, new private equitybacked brokerages, and publicly traded companies in the financial services industry have been acquiring small to medium-sized independent intermediaries to offer insurance products and services and to strengthen their market share. Some of these market participants may have greater resources than we do and, as a result, may identify and adapt to trends more quickly or withstand an economic downturn and/or declining premium rates better than we do. In certain markets we compete directly with locally owned insurance brokerages, many of which have existing relationships with insurance carriers. Since relationships between insurance brokerages and insurance carriers or customers are often local or regional in nature, we may be competitively disadvantaged in areas in which we do not have a significant local or regional presence. Various trends in the insurance industry toward alternative insurance markets have also emerged and are likely to continue. These alternatives to traditional insurance include, among other things, greater levels of selfinsurance, captives (i.e., arrangements where the policyholder owns the insurance company), rent-a-captives, risk retention groups and non-insurance capital markets-based solutions. Some insurance carriers are engaged in the direct sale of insurance, primarily to individuals, and do not pay commissions to agents and brokers on policies they sell directly. An increase in the use of alternative insurance markets may reduce our client base and, therefore, adversely impact our business, results of operations and financial condition. Recently, regulatory changes in the financial services industry have permitted, and may further permit, in the future, banks, securities firms, and insurance carriers to affiliate, causing increased consolidation in the insurance industry. If we are unable to compete effectively or if competition reduces the fees that we can obtain for our services, we will suffer a loss of market share, decreased revenues, and reduced operating margins, which in turn may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may experience unexpected fluctuations in our commission income because our commissions depend on premium rates charged by insurance carriers, which we do not control and which historically have varied and are difficult to predict, and we are less able to forecast profit commissions related to our underwriting business than premium-based commissions due to the link with variable insurance events and the inherent volatility this brings, which may negatively impact our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: Commissions related to our (re)insurance business are generally paid on the basis of a percentage of premiums paid by clients for insurance products. We have no control over the insurance premium rates on which these commissions are calculated. The amount of such commissions is therefore highly dependent on factors beyond our control. Premium rates may vary widely and are determined by insurance carriers based on a wide range of economic and specific market conditions. During the last 10 years, we have experienced a positive rating environment. During 2020, the net impact of rate and exposure had a moderately positive impact on our results. This trend continued with a moderately positive impact until the year ended September 30, 2023. Because we cannot determine the timing and the extent of premium rate changes, we may not be able to accurately forecast our commission income, including whether it will significantly decline. Any decline in ----- premiums or reduction in our commission rates may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. As a result, our budgets for future acquisitions, capital expenditures, debt service obligations and other expenditures may have to be adjusted to account for unexpected changes in revenue. Our underwriting division, which is granted delegated authority by insurance companies to underwrite risks within a defined category of business on their behalf, earns a commission for its services, along with a profit commission which represents a share of underwriting profits when the risks underwritten perform at or better than an agreed loss ratio. Profit commissions are typically dependent upon the profitability of the business placed with the insurer. We are less able to forecast profit commissions than premium-based commissions due to the link with variable insurance events and the inherent volatility this brings. As the profitability of our underwriting division is in part dependent upon the ratio of claims made to total underwriting business placed, catastrophic events, whether natural or otherwise, may affect the amount of claims being made and therefore the profitability of the business which we placed, and in turn may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business may be adversely affected by a challenging economic environment, inflation and geopolitical tensions.
Subsubsection Text: Our revenue by location of end-insureds is almost evenly split across the UK, Europe and North America. As a result, we are particularly affected by economic developments and regulatory and political changes in the Western economies and markets globally. Economic difficulties, increased competition between insurers due to an economic downturn and other factors may prevent increases in premiums or may even cause the premium rates on which commissions are based to decline. In addition, any significant reduction or delay by customers in purchasing insurance or making payment of premiums could have a negative impact on our business, results of operations and financial conditions. Factors such as declining business and consumer confidence, cost of living crisis, lower household income and consumer spending, downturns in the property market and other economic challenges could have a significant negative impact on the buying behavior of our commercial and individual customers. Insolvencies associated with continuing economic uncertainty could adversely affect our business through the loss of customers or by hindering our ability to place insurance. Due to their size, our small and medium enterprises (“SMEs”) business customers may be more vulnerable to an economic downturn and may be more prone to insolvency than larger commercial customers. Global markets are also experiencing volatility and disruption as a result of global inflationary pressures and monetary policy tightening, the ongoing military conflict in Ukraine, the recent events in the Middle East and the potential regional instability resulting from these events, and trade tensions between the United States and China. Capital markets have been and may continue to be impacted by inflation, which is currently the case in many of the jurisdictions in which we operate, and there are concerns that current inflationary pressures could result in significant macroeconomic deterioration, including, but not limited to, increased foreign exchange volatility and decreased GDP in the markets in which we operate. In addition, there are concerns that these events could push the Eurozone, the UK and/or the United States into an economic recession, any of which, were they to occur, would further destabilize the global financial markets. Any of the events described above may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. Any of the aforementioned factors, individually or in the aggregate, that negatively impact the insurance market, the economy, and the economic growth and stability of any of the jurisdictions we conduct our business in (including but not limited to the UK and the European Union) could increase our operating costs, impose additional regulatory burdens and may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. If a significant insurer fails or withdraws from writing certain insurance coverage that we offer our clients, overall underwriting capacity in the industry could be negatively affected, which could reduce our placement of certain lines and types of insurance. This or any other negative economic developments in any of the jurisdictions we conduct our business in could reduce customer confidence or limit the demand for our insurance products and as a result may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We may be unsuccessful in identifying and acquiring suitable acquisition candidates or integrating acquired companies, which could impede our growth and ability to remain competitive in our industry.
Subsubsection Text: Our strategic plan includes the regular and systematic evaluation and acquisition of companies in new and existing markets. Since our founding, we have partnered with and acquired firms with offices across 50 countries. We have sought and continue to seek individuals and companies that share our values and can seamlessly integrate into our Group, placing a strong emphasis on employee ownership. For example, our core broking business was expanded following the acquisition of A-Plan Group, one of the UK’s largest personal and commercial lines insurance brokers, thereby significantly broadening our retail distribution and specialist product capabilities in the UK and incorporating A-Plan Group’s best-in-class distribution model. We further expanded our broking business through the acquisition of Aston Lark, one of the UK’s largest independent insurance brokers specializing in complex commercial and private client insurance and employee benefit advice, which completed in April 2022. Further, our position in the (re)insurance market was strengthened following the acquisition of Align (one of the largest independent managing general agencies (“MGA”) in North America) in 2021, the acquisition of Assiteca (one of the largest insurance intermediaries in Italy) in 2022 as well as the acquisition of TigerRisk (the world’s fourth largest global reinsurance broker) in January 2023. We may not successfully identify suitable acquisition candidates in the future. Prospective acquisition candidates may not become available or we may not be able to complete an acquisition once negotiations have commenced. We may also fail to secure the financial resources, including through third party financing, to complete prospective acquisitions. We sometimes compete for acquisition and expansion opportunities with entities that have greater financial resources or are otherwise willing to pay more than we are and these entities may be able to outbid us for these acquisition targets. In addition, some of the acquisitions we may undertake in the future could substantially increase our size, either as a result of a single acquisition or multiple acquisitions. If the size of our Group increases due to current or future acquisitions, it may be difficult for us to properly integrate, manage and control each of our newly acquired divisions, branches and local projects, particularly in light of our decentralized structure. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to our Business and _Industry—Our decentralized organization may negatively affect our ability to implement and maintain our strategy, internal controls and more generally to carry out our business.”_ We also may fail to fully or timely integrate any acquired company into our Group. We completed 56 acquisitions in the year ended September 30, 2023, and over 100 acquisitions since 2016, and have hired a large number of lateral employees as part of our growth strategy. We have not yet completed integration efforts for all of these acquisitions and we may be unable to successfully integrate all of our recently acquired intermediaries or any insurance intermediaries that we may acquire in the future. The acquisition or integration of such acquisition involves a number of factors that may affect our operations. These factors include, but are not limited to: - distraction of management; - incurrence of significant amounts of additional debt; - tax and accounting issues, including the creation of significant future contingent liabilities relating to earn outs for acquisitions or other financial liabilities; - difficulties in the integration of acquired operations (which may include implementing or remediating controls, procedures, and policies at the acquired company, integration of the acquired company’s accounting, human resource, information technology and other administrative systems, and coordination of product, engineering, and sales and marketing functions, transition of operations, users, and customers onto our existing platforms) and retention of key personnel; - the degree to which the acquired company’s business is different from that of our core insurance intermediary business and the degree to which we understand and master the practices (including, without limitation to, the accounting practices) of non-intermediary businesses; and - unanticipated problems or legal liabilities and/or new legal or compliance obligations. Our continued growth is partly based on our ability to successfully integrate acquired companies and our failure to do so may cause us to fail to realize the anticipated benefits of such acquisitions or investments, ----- incur unanticipated liabilities, and harm our business generally, which in turn may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Launching new business initiatives and expanding into new business lines may expose us to new challenges and more risks, and we may not achieve the expected results.
Subsubsection Text: Our growth strategy involves a number of new business initiatives which serve to diversify our offering. These include, among others, launching new business ventures, such as Howden Ventures, a world-first insurance innovation hub with £500 million of delegated underwriting capacity. We also have recently expanded our catastrophe bond practice, as we now also act as initial purchasers in catastrophe bonds offerings. Additionally, from time to time, we seek selected opportunities to use the Group’s resources to support our underwriting capabilities. For instance, in 2020 we created Catalyst Capacity Vehicle, a vehicle we used until 2022 to support a specific retrocession binding authority agreement for Tamesis, a global specialty excess of loss treaty reinsurance business part of DUAL. Our lack of familiarity or experience with these and any future new businesses may make it more difficult for us to anticipate client demand and preferences, and we may encounter significant competition in business areas where we are less established. We may not be successful in the introduction, marketing or development of any new business initiatives and they may not perform in line with expectations. Our new business initiatives may also expose us to additional and new risks. For example, since we recently started acting as initial purchasers in catastrophe bonds offerings, we are now exposed to the remote risk that, if on the settlement date of a catastrophe bond where we have acted as initial purchaser, an investor fails to pay any amount due in connection with their investment, our Group may be required to buy out such investor’s position. We cannot guarantee that these and any future new ventures will ultimately prove successful or will not generate significant losses. Failure to successfully manage a new business initiative may adversely impact our brand image and reputation and negatively affect our existing business lines and the launch of future initiatives and, therefore, may have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. In addition, regardless of the revenue that we may derive from them, these and any future initiatives will require financial investments and will involve significant diversions of management’s time and attention, which may adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our decentralized organization may negatively affect our ability to implement and maintain our strategy, internal controls and more generally to carry out our business.
Subsubsection Text: We believe that our decentralized organizational structure in which our divisions and their managers retain substantial autonomy is a key element of our business model and an important element in maintaining our competitive position. However, this structure could cause difficulties in bringing the controls, accounting procedures and policies of the companies of our Group and the companies we acquire up to the standard of our Group’s controls and procedures in a timely manner, which could lead to inadvertent breaches of our existing policies as well as to inaccuracies or misstatements in our financial reporting. While we have adopted certain policies and rules that are applicable to each entity of our Group, we may not be able to efficiently monitor and enforce the compliance of each local team with such policies and rules. As decentralization necessarily places significant control and decision-making powers in the hands of each division of our Group and on their local business and branch managers, there is a risk that those local managers will not comply with our internal policies or processes, or that we will not successfully implement future compliance policies. Any failure to properly implement our internal policies and processes may cause a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. Our decentralized structure and acquisitive nature may also increase the risk of errors or malicious or fraudulent activity or delay our knowledge of potential errors or malicious or fraudulent activity. While a well-designed, operated, and tested control system may provide reasonable assurance that the objectives of the control system are met, our internal controls and procedures may not identify all errors or prevent certain ----- malicious or fraudulent activity and our knowledge of potential errors or malicious or fraudulent activity may be delayed. Additionally, controls can be circumvented by the individual acts of some persons, by collusion of two or more people, or by management override of a control, or may become inadequate over time. Because of these inherent limitations, misstatements due to error or fraud may occur and may not be detected, which may result in liabilities or reputational damages and, therefore, may adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. Additionally, our decentralized structure may cause difficulties in our awareness and responsiveness to adverse operating or financial developments at our insurance intermediaries. To implement and monitor our business plan and determine and report our operating results, we depend on timely and accurate reporting of business conditions, including legal, regulatory, and financial results, from our businesses. We have internal controls and communication procedures in place to receive ongoing communications from management as well as formal monthly and quarterly reporting from each of our businesses regarding their financial condition and operating results, and overall business conditions, including legal and regulatory compliance. However, if an adverse business or financial development occurs at one or more of our businesses, or if one or more of our businesses were to report inaccurate financial information, we may not become aware of the occurrence in a timely manner, which could make it more difficult for us to effectively respond to that development and could adversely affect our ability to mitigate our exposure and determine and report our financial results. There is also a risk that each division of our Group, and particularly newly acquired Group companies, may not swiftly implement or maintain efficient, reliable IT systems, or that newly acquired companies are not fully integrated within our Group’s IT infrastructure. Moreover, this structure may negatively affect or delay our ability to move cash within our Group and, therefore, comply with our financial obligations, including paying any amount due under the Notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We have experienced rapid growth in recent periods, and our recent growth rates may not be indicative of future growth. As our costs increase, we may not be able to generate sufficient revenue to achieve and maintain profitability.
Subsubsection Text: We have experienced significant revenue growth in recent periods but there is no certainty that we will be able to sustain such revenue growth. Our growth strategy focuses on driving organic growth and executing our growth initiatives. We believe that our revenue growth depends on a number of factors, including, but not limited to, our ability to: - execute our acquisition strategy and adequately expand, train, integrate and retain our insurance and reinsurance brokers and underwriters; - attract new talent and adequately train, integrate and retain new employees, and maintain or increase our sales force’s productivity; - sell insurers products effectively so that we are able to attract and retain clients without compromising our profitability; - attract new clients, successfully deploy and implement our products, obtain client renewals, provide our clients with excellent client support and implement cross-selling initiatives within our existing client base; - increase our network of insurer trading partners and maintain the ongoing dialogue with our network of insurance carriers; - enhance our information, training and communication systems to ensure that our employees are well coordinated and can effectively communicate with each other and clients; - improve our internal control over financial reporting and disclosure controls and procedures to ensure timely and accurate reporting of our operational and financial results; - successfully create new distribution channels; - successfully introduce new products and enhance existing products; - successfully introduce our products to new markets inside and outside of the UK; ----- - successfully compete against larger companies and new market entrants; and - increase awareness of our brand. We may not successfully accomplish any of these objectives, and as a result, it is difficult for us to forecast our future results of operations. Our historical growth rate should not be considered indicative of our future performance and may decline in the future. In future periods, our revenue may grow more slowly than in recent periods or decline for any number of reasons, including those outlined above. In addition, the additional expenses we will incur may not lead to sufficient additional revenue to maintain historical revenue growth rates and profitability. If our revenue growth does not increase to offset these anticipated increases in our operating expenses, our business, financial position and results of operations will be harmed, and we may not be able to achieve or maintain profitability. In particular, our acquisition strategy includes a disciplined approach to evaluating opportunities and integrating acquisitions and the use of contingent payments, or “earn outs” and equity incentive schemes to incentivize the acquired company’s management teams, encourage retention of key employees and further align interests. Our future growth depends, in large part, on our ability to successfully implement these strategies. If we fail to successfully implement these strategies, if new regulations impact their efficacy or if any of these strategies ultimately proves unsuccessful, we may not be able to compete effectively or achieve and maintain profitability, which may adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition. Additionally, companies that we have acquired may not be as profitable as we expected them to be. Since our founding in 1994, we have partnered with and acquired businesses with offices across 50 countries and have hired a large number of employees through lateral hiring as part of our growth strategy. Although we conduct due diligence with respect to the business and operations of each of the companies we acquire, we may not have identified all material facts and risks concerning these companies. Unanticipated events or liabilities relating to these companies may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. Furthermore, once we have integrated an acquired company, it may not achieve levels of revenue, profitability, or productivity comparable to our existing locations, or otherwise perform as expected. In addition, the companies we acquire may not provide a sufficient level of client service and satisfaction, which may negatively affect our reputation and result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. Our failure to integrate one or more acquired companies may prevent us from achieving our performance goals, which could adversely impact our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We rely on third party service providers to perform key functions of our business operations enabling our provision of services to our clients. These third parties may act in ways that could harm our business.
Subsubsection Text: We rely on third party service providers, and in some cases subcontractors, to provide services, data and information, support functions and administration that are critical to the operations of our business. As we do not fully control the actions of these third parties, we are subject to the risk that their decisions, actions or inactions may adversely impact us, and replacing these service providers may create significant delays and expenses. Any failure by third parties to comply with service-level agreements or regulatory or legal requirements in a high-quality and timely manner, particularly during periods of our peak demand for their services, may result in economic and reputational harm to us. Additionally, third parties may commit fraudulent actions, which could have a negative impact on our industry as a whole or directly harm our operations and our clients, thus negatively affecting our business, results of operations and financial condition. In addition, our third party service providers face their own technology, operating, business and economic risks, and any significant failures, service disruptions or unintended disruptions by them, including the improper use or disclosure of our confidential client, employee or company information, could cause harm to our business and reputation. An interruption in or the cessation of service by any service provider as a result of system failures, cybersecurity incidents, capacity constraints, financial difficulties or for any other reason could disrupt our operations, impact our ability to offer certain products and services, and result in contractual ----- or regulatory penalties, liability claims from clients or employees, damage to our reputation, and harm to our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business depends on a strong brand image and reputation, and any failure to build, maintain, protect and enhance our brand and reputation would hurt our ability to grow our business, particularly in new markets where we have limited brand recognition.
Subsubsection Text: We are developing a strong brand image and we believe that our brand and reputation contribute significantly to the success of our business. Maintaining, protecting and enhancing the Howden brand and reputation is critical to growing our business, particularly in new markets where we have limited brand recognition. If we do not successfully build and maintain a strong brand image and reputation, our business could be materially harmed. Maintaining and enhancing the quality of our brand and reputation may require us to make substantial investments in areas such as marketing and community relations. These investments may be substantial and there is no assurance that we will achieve the optimal range of traditional, online and social media advertising to achieve maximum exposure and benefit to the brand. If we fail to properly maintain and develop our brand image and reputation, we may fail to retain and attract new clients, which would in turn negatively affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. Additionally, unfavorable media reporting related to us or our shareholders, in particular our founder David Howden, or regarding our business practices or prospects could negatively affect our ability to secure and retain clients, as well as our relationships with our partners and service providers, and could therefore adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations, regardless of its accuracy or inaccuracy. In addition, since our brand name is now used in connection with a wider range of divisions of our Group, any negative media reporting related to any of the divisions of our Group may have a material adverse effect on the other divisions of our Group, regardless of whether the services provided by each of such divisions are related to one another, and may negatively affect the business, financial condition and results of operations of our Group.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: If we lose the services of our founder, David Howden, or fail to effectively provide for the orderly succession of his role, our business and operating results may be harmed
Subsubsection Text: Our success and future development depend in part on the continued involvement of our founder and namesake David Howden, who continues to be significantly involved in the management of our Group. If we are unable to effectively provide for the succession of David Howden, the loss of his services could harm our operations and impair our efforts to expand our business. Because competition for such skilled employees is intense, and the process of finding a qualified individual to replace David Howden could be lengthy and expensive, we believe that the loss of the services of David Howden may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business relies on our ability to recruit and retain qualified personnel in a highly competitive environment. The loss of members of our senior management could negatively affect our financial plans, growth, marketing and other objectives.
Subsubsection Text: We believe that our future success will depend in large part on our ability to attract and retain highly skilled and qualified personnel and to expand, train and manage our employee base. The (re)insurance brokerage industry continues to experience intense competition for the services of leading individual producers and brokerage teams. We are and may be subject to a number of claims or proceedings that arise as a result of recruitment practices focused on attracting key talent. While such practices are common in our industry, these claims, regardless of merit, may ultimately result in financial liability for our Group. For example, on October 10, 2023, HGH Limited (and certain other companies in our Group) and Guy Carpenter & Company Limited (and certain other companies within the Guy Carpenter/Marsh McLennan Group, (the reinsurance broking arm of Marsh McLennan Companies, Inc.)) reached an agreement for settlement in the amount of £56.5 million (inclusive of Guy Carpenter’s costs) in respect of claims commenced by Guy Carpenter against the Group in the High Court of England and Wales. The claims related to alleged breach of employment obligations (including post termination restrictive covenants) within the employment ----- and other agreements of 37 individual reinsurance brokers who ceased employment with Guy Carpenter and were recruited and employed by our Group. An adverse outcome or the cost of any settlement in connection with one or more of these matters may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. In addition, regardless of monetary costs, these matters could have a material adverse effect on our reputation and cause harm to our carrier, client or employee relationships, or divert personnel and management resources. The number of claims, actions and other proceedings arising as a result of our recruitment strategy (whether meritorious or not) may increase in the future, and thus we expect to be required to devote more resources to managing such claims and challenges in the future. Conversely, if key personnel were to end their employment with us, or if we experience significant turnover, it could negatively affect the execution of our business strategy, disrupt the relationships with our clients and/or insurance carriers, and our operations could be adversely affected until suitable replacements with appropriate experience can be found. In particular, if we fail to retain key personnel of our newly acquired companies, the value of those acquisitions itself could be materially affected and we may be unable to fully realize the anticipated benefits of such acquisitions or investments. In addition, if we are unable to effectively provide for the succession of senior management, our business, results of operations and financial condition may be materially adversely affected. Our equity ownership model is a key part of our proposition to retain existing and new employees. Should our equity ownership model cease to be attractive for any reason, including a change in the tax or fiscal treatment of shares or a decrease in share prices, it may have a negative impact on our ability to attract and retain qualified personnel and, therefore, may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We rely on the efficient, uninterrupted and secure operation of complex information technology systems and networks to operate our business. Any significant system or network disruption due to a breach in the security of our information technology systems could have a negative impact on our reputation, regulatory compliance status, operations, sales and operating results.
Subsubsection Text: All information technology systems are potentially vulnerable to damage, breakdown or interruption from a variety of sources, including, but not limited to, cyberattacks; ransomware; malware; security breaches; theft or misuse; unauthorized access or improper actions, by insiders or employees, sophisticated nation-state and nation-state-supported actors; natural disasters; terrorism; war; telecommunication and electrical failures or other compromises. We are at risk of attack by a growing list of threat actors through increasingly sophisticated methods of attack. Because the techniques used to infiltrate or sabotage systems change frequently, we may be unable to anticipate these techniques or implement adequate preventative measures. While we have implemented various measures to manage our risks related to system and network security and disruptions and some entities hold certifications for meeting certain security standards, we have been exposed in the past, and may be exposed in the future, to cyber incidents. For instance, in October 2023, three of the Group’s electronic platforms providing various services to brokers and the market were attacked and unavailable for a short time, causing some limited disruption. The Cyber response plan was activated and regulators notified as appropriate. If we are unable to maintain and upgrade our system safeguards, we may become more vulnerable to unauthorized access or be subject to security breaches, which could in turn cause extended disruptions in the functioning of our information technology systems, unexpected costs, thus damaging our reputation, causing us to lose clients and adversely impacting our business, results of operations and financial condition. Despite the various measures we have implemented to safeguard systems and data and to mitigate the impact of loss were it to occur, were a successful attack to occur, our information could be encrypted or otherwise unavailable to us. While we select our service providers and our third party vendors carefully, cyberattacks and security breaches at a client or vendor could adversely affect our ability to deliver products and services to our customers and otherwise conduct our business and could put our systems at risk. Additionally, we are an acquisitive organization and the process of integrating the information systems of the businesses we acquire is complex and exposes us to additional risk as we might not adequately identify weaknesses in the targets’ or their vendors’ information systems, which could expose us to unexpected liabilities or make our own systems more ----- vulnerable to attack. These types of incidents affecting us, our clients or our third party vendors could result in intellectual property or other confidential information being lost or stolen, including client, employee or company data. In addition, we may not be able to detect breaches in our information technology systems or assess the severity or impact of a breach in a timely manner. If we fail to properly protect and manage our information technology systems, we may face financial liabilities and reputational damages, which could hinder our ability to generate revenue and could result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to regulatory, business and economic risks associated with operating abroad and trading internationally.
Subsubsection Text: Doing business on a worldwide basis requires us to comply with the laws and regulations of various jurisdictions. We are subject to a variety of risks inherent to serving a global customer base and in maintaining offices abroad. These risks include but are not limited to: - political, social, or economic instability; - risks related to the legal and regulatory environment in foreign jurisdictions, including with respect to antitrust, privacy and data protection, and unexpected changes in laws, regulatory requirements, and enforcement; - risks that our IT systems or internal controls and procedures may not be adequate to support operations abroad; - potential damage to our brand image and reputation due to compliance with local laws, including potential censorship or requirements to provide user data to local authorities; - higher costs associated with doing business internationally, including increased taxes and fluctuations in currency exchange rates; - higher levels of credit risk or payment fraud; - burdens of complying with a variety of foreign laws and regulations; - reduced protection for intellectual property rights in some countries; - difficulties in staffing and managing global operations and the increased travel, infrastructure, real estate, and legal compliance costs associated with multiple international locations; - risks related to the tax regimes and the tax treatment or characterization of any of our transactions in foreign jurisdictions; - compliance with the United States Foreign Corrupt Practices Act 1977, the Bribery Act 2010 (“UK Bribery Act”), and similar laws in other jurisdictions, as well as other laws with extra-territorial effect; - compliance with relevant sanctions laws; - potential adverse tax consequences of doing business in certain jurisdictions; and - compliance with statutory equity requirements and management of tax consequences. The insurance and insurance intermediary industries have been subject to a significant level of scrutiny by various regulatory and governmental bodies concerning certain practices within the insurance industry. These practices include, without limitation, the receipt of supplemental and contingent commissions by insurance brokers and agents from insurance companies and the extent to which such compensation has been disclosed, the collection of broker fees, which we define as fees separate from commissions charged directly to clients for efforts performed in the issuance of new insurance policies and related matters. The approach taken by regulators regarding streams of income, such as commission income, may change from time to time and, notwithstanding the diversification of the business overall, this may adversely impact the reliability of income streams. We are subject to laws regarding money laundering, financing of terrorism and laws prohibiting us, our employees or intermediaries from making improper payments or offers of payment to foreign governments ----- and their officials and political parties for the purpose of obtaining or retaining business, across the jurisdictions we conduct our business in. This is includes, without limitation and by way of example, the UK’s Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 and the UK Bribery Act, The Fourth and Fifth European Union Anti-Money Laundering Directives. We also may be subject to sanctions administered by the United States Treasury Department’s Office of Foreign Assets Control (“OFAC”), the United Nations Security Council, the European Union, the UK Office of Financial Sanctions Implementation, the UK National Crime Agency, or other relevant sanctions authorities. The scope, sophistication and nature of the anti-corruption laws, regulation and levels of enforcement may vary significantly among the jurisdictions in which we conduct our business. As a result of our growing international presence, we may become subject to heightened regulatory scrutiny from competition and antitrust authorities. Failure to comply with any such laws could result in investigations, public censure, financial penalties, and liability and/or enforcement actions being brought against us. Additionally, any developments or changes in laws and regulations (including due to changes in fiscal policies and in the political framework in any of the jurisdictions we conduct our business in) could impair our ability to conduct our business or make our business model less attractive, and thus could have a negative impact on our reputation and may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. We cannot predict the manner in which existing laws or regulations might be administered or interpreted or the nature, scope or effect of future regulatory requirements to which we might be subject.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: If we fail to comply with regulatory requirements or guidelines, we may not be able to conduct business or may be subject to sanctions or substantial fines that may have a material adverse effect on our reputation, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: The regulation of our operations varies from country to country, often substantially, and ranges from nascent to sophisticated regimes, and may fall into the jurisdiction of one or more prudential and/or financial services regulators. Firms in our industry must maintain regulatory authorizations in most, if not all, the jurisdictions we conduct business. Some of the jurisdictions in which we conduct business, such as the UK, have an extensive set of rules that apply to our business, while in other jurisdictions the relevant regulators are or are planning to implement similar regimes. Our insurance intermediary activities must comply with prudential rules and guidelines in each relevant jurisdiction, which impose or may impose in the future, amongst other things, a high-level standard on the establishment and maintenance of proper systems and controls and minimum threshold conditions that must be satisfied for an insurance intermediary firm to remain authorized as well as rules on the conduct of business and treating customers fairly. For instance, in the UK, these rules impose minimum “threshold conditions” that must be satisfied as well as robust standards for the establishment and maintenance of proper systems and controls, notably for the conduct of business and the fair treatment of customers. These rules also impose upon us certain minimum capital and liquidity requirements. Our conduct obligations require us to demonstrate that we are consistently delivering fair outcomes to consumers and that senior management is taking responsibility for ensuring that we, and our employees at all levels, deliver the consumer outcomes relevant to our business by establishing an appropriate culture. Such rules oblige us to proactively identify and manage conflicts of interest fairly and we risk regulatory action if we do not do so. Furthermore, we often incur additional costs in order to comply with changes to the regulatory landscape. There is no assurance that we will continue to be able to fund such costs or that the incurrence of such costs will not have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. Similar sets of rules already exist or may be implemented in the future in the other jurisdictions we conduct our business in, such as Ireland, Australia and in Asia. Firms have an ongoing obligation to periodically provide regulators in each of the jurisdictions they operate in with certain information, such as their financial performance and customer outcomes. Regulators supervise firms’ activities to assess compliance with regulatory requirements, including client money rules. Regulators will seek additional information from firms via surveys, thematic reviews and formal risk assessments. Certain regulators have extensive investigative and disciplinary powers, including the power to impose fines and vary or cancel regulatory authorizations. While in the ordinary course of business we maintain an ongoing dialogue ----- with regulators across the jurisdictions where we operate, and while we endeavor a high standard of compliance, failure to comply with the rules and regulations imposed upon us may lead to disciplinary action, including requiring customers to be compensated for loss, the imposition of penalties or the partial or total revocation or variation of our authorizations to conduct business. In addition, individuals performing various controlled functions for regulated firms in some jurisdictions are required to be approved persons and to satisfy certain fitness and propriety criteria. Any disciplinary or enforcement action against these individuals by any regulator in any of the jurisdictions we conduct our business in, could prevent such persons from continuing to work for us. If these individuals are key personnel, this could have a material adverse effect on our business. Disciplinary or enforcement action against any individuals or against the business generally could result in damage to our brands and reputation which may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. We can also be affected indirectly by governmental regulation and the supervision of insurance companies. For instance, if we are providing our managing general underwriting services for an insurer, we may have to contend with regulations affecting our clients. Future changes in laws and regulations relating to our business, as well as any regulatory intervention or investigation with respect to our business or the industry more generally, could limit future activities and result in increased costs of regulatory compliance and increased management attention being required to be dedicated to compliance. The focus of regulatory attention may change, develop into new and different areas, or further deepen the areas already subject to regulatory attention, thereby necessitating a change in our business lines or business model. For example, changes in the area of anti-trust enforcement could impact our acquisition strategy or subject us to various acquisition-related legal investigations or proceedings. This may consequently result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. See “Regulation.”

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: A change in the regulatory approach to our commission-based earning model could have a significant adverse effect on our Group’s business.
Subsubsection Text: Insurance intermediaries have traditionally been remunerated by base commissions paid by insurance carriers in respect of insurance placements for clients, or by fees paid by clients. We derive a substantial portion of our revenue from commissions negotiated with, and paid for by, insurance carriers. This type of revenue has recently been subject to enhanced scrutiny by various regulators with respect to conflict of interest, anti-trust and unfair competition, in particular as our market share increases in certain jurisdictions, notably in the US, conduct and anti-bribery laws and regulations. For example, in 2021, the FCA has completed a market study into how general insurance firms charge their retail customers for home and motor insurance (the “FCA Market Study”). Based on the FCA Market Study, the FCA has introduced changes to the regulatory regime and provided, amongst other things, market-wide restrictions on renewal pricing exceeding the equivalent new business price, additional reporting requirements and an enhanced framework for the assessment of fair value. Some of the potential market scenarios that could emerge from the FCA Market Study and any similar findings by other regulators could have a significant impact on renewal profitability which, in the short term, may lead to a decrease in overall margins per policy. In May 2021, the FCA launched a consultation, “CP21/13: A new Consumer Duty,” on changes to its handbook of rules and guidance to set a higher level of protection for consumers in retail financial markets. The Consumer Duty imposes greater expectations on firms as regards consumer outcomes. The Consumer Duty is comprised of a ‘Consumer Principle’ that reflects the overall standards of behavior expected from firms, along with a set of rules and guidance which intended to amplify the Consumer Principle and which set out the detail of the FCA’s expectations for firms providing services to retail clients. The Consumer Principle sets higher expectations for the standard of care that firms provide to consumers. The rules for new and existing products came into force on July 31, 2023 and have been a key area of focus for the FCA in subsequent months. Although the rules and guidance are helpful, as with all new outcome-based regulatory frameworks, decisions of the regulators also play an integral part in interpretation of the same and there are, as yet, very few examples to draw on. ----- The theme of consumer-focused regulation being introduced by local regulators is a global risk for our Group, due to the nature of the highly regulated services being provided across numerous jurisdictions. Our Group monitors the risk this could pose to any of its existing business lines; however, it is likely that consumerfocused regulation will evolve and may diverge across these jurisdictions in future. To the extent the FCA or any other regulator adopts rules that reduce or eliminate the commissions payments we are able to receive from insurance carriers, our revenue could be reduced which, in turn, would negatively affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and prospects.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Rules and practices pertaining to trade between the United Kingdom and the European Union following the United Kingdom’s exit from the European Union continue to evolve and may adversely affect our ability to trade across borders and therefore impact our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: At 11 p.m. GMT on January 31, 2020, the UK officially withdrew from the European Union. To accommodate firms during the transition period, the FCA introduced a Temporary Permissions Regime which ended on December 30, 2023. From May 1, 2021, the relations between the European Union and the UK have been governed by the EU-UK Trade and Cooperation Agreement (the “Trade and Cooperation Agreement”). The Trade and Cooperation Agreement does not create a detailed framework to govern the cross border provision of regulated financial services from the UK into the European Union and from the European Union into the UK. We had historically relied on ‘passporting’rights under the Directive 2009/138/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 November 2009 to carry out our insurance business in certain EEA Member States from the UK. Following the withdrawal of the UK from the European Union, we provide our broking and underwriting services through entities that are authorized and regulated in the European Union, including through entities based in Luxembourg. Our continued ability to provide services through entities based in the European Union depends on the criteria set forth by the relevant regulators, which include establishing a presence in those jurisdictions. Establishing presence and substance in the relevant jurisdictions is an ongoing process, requiring a significant investment of resources. For instance, the relevant regulators may require that we hire senior employees with particular skill-set and experience or that we maintain a minimum headcount in each relevant jurisdiction. Additionally, the relevant regulators may change the requirements for us to conduct business in the European Union jurisdictions at any time. From time to time, we may receive enquiries from regulators with respect to our passporting and other arrangements. Any changes in the regulation of ‘passporting’rights and to the requirements set by the relevant authorities in the European Union, including any adverse interpretation of the ‘passporting’ requirements, may result in findings that have a detrimental effect to our business and may therefore result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. Additionally, delays in having arrangements approved by regulators across the European Union as well as in the UK could impact the speed with which arrangements are finalized.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our future acquisitions and other strategic transactions will likely be subject to significant governmental regulation and supervision, which may impose vetoes, conditions, undertakings and ultimately prevent us from completing those future transactions.
Subsubsection Text: Our future acquisitions or other strategic transactions may be subject to prior receipt of requisite approvals of governmental authorities (either at a country or, in the case of the European Union, European level), including customary competition law clearances by the relevant competition authorities as well as scrutiny and approval by the relevant insurance regulators. These authorities may veto, impose conditions or undertakings on, or delay the acquisition process which could result in a failure on our part to proceed with announced transactions on a timely basis or at all, thus hampering our opportunities for growth. There can be no assurance that we will receive the required governmental approvals and meet the other conditions required to consummate any future transaction. Accordingly, we may not be permitted to undertake certain future acquisition transactions, without remedies or undertakings, or at all. Any delay or denial with respect to our planned strategic transactions may negatively affect our growth strategy and, therefore, may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. ----- Additionally, in the event conditions to the completion of a transaction are imposed and we fail to meet them in a timely manner, the relevant governmental authority may impose fines and, if in connection with an acquisition or merger transaction, may require restorative measures, such as mandatory disposition of assets or divestiture of operations. Any such fines or restorative measures may cause financial liabilities and/or reputational damage to our Group, and, therefore, may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our results of operations, financial condition, cash flows and reputation may be materially adversely affected by legal proceedings, claims, and investigations.
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, we are involved in lawsuits as well as subject to various legal proceedings, claims, threats of litigation, and investigations in the ordinary course of business. See “Business—Litigation.” We have extensive global operations and are subject to various actual, threatened and potential claims, litigation and investigations in the ordinary course of business. These claims, litigation and investigations arise in various contexts, including in connection with the Group’s activities as an insurer, employer, investment adviser and taxpayer. In the course of conducting insurance business, the Group receives general insurance liability claims, and becomes involved in actual or threatened litigation arising therefrom including, amongst other things, claims that result from alleged errors and omissions related to the placement of insurance coverage on behalf of our clients. Notably, our acquisition strategy may give rise to claims, regulatory actions and other proceedings, whether meritorious or not, which could ultimately result in financial liability for our Group and, therefore, may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. Furthermore, we are and may be subject to a number of claims and other proceedings that arise as a result of recruitment strategy focused on attracting key talent. See “—Our business relies on our ability to _recruit and retain qualified personnel in a highly competitive environment. The loss of members of our senior management could negatively affect our financial plans, growth, marketing and other objectives.” We may also_ incur liabilities for the actions of our directors, employees, agents and representatives related to our business, including in relation to financial crime and fraudulent activities, which may expose us to liability for claims and proceedings that could have a negative effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. We currently have general liability insurance in place to cover liability to which we may be exposed from our business activities in amounts that we consider appropriate. Such policies are subject to certain limits and deductibles and do not include business interruption coverage and may not be covered by insurance in specific instances. While we seek to maintain appropriate levels of insurance, not all claims are insurable and we may experience major incidents of a nature not covered by insurance. As industry practices and legal, judicial and social conditions change, unexpected and unintended issues related to claims and coverage, including reinsurance coverage, may emerge. Our business, results of operations and financial condition may be adversely affected if in the future our insurance coverage proves to be inadequate or unavailable or there is an increase in liabilities for which we self-insure. Furthermore, our insurance costs may increase over time in response to any negative development in our Group’s claims history or due to material price increases in the insurance market in general. We may also experience higher deductibles and higher premiums based on our historical claims and loss experience. Insurance coverage may not be available in the future at current costs or on commercially reasonable terms, and the insurance proceeds received for any loss of, or any damage to, any of our facilities may not be sufficient to restore the loss or damage without resulting in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. While certain matters to which we are a party may specify the damages claimed, such claims may not represent reasonably possible losses (including non-financial loss). Given the inherent uncertainties of litigation, the ultimate outcome of these matters cannot be predicted at this time, nor can the amount of possible loss or range of loss, if any, be reasonably estimated.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our business, results of operations and financial condition may be materially adversely affected by errors and omissions that we may commit in our ordinary course of business.
Subsubsection Text: In conducting our business we may incur errors and omissions, including, for example, our employees or sub-agents failing, whether negligently or intentionally, to place adequate coverage or to notify insurance ----- carriers of claims on behalf of clients, to provide insurance carriers with complete and accurate information relating to the risks being insured or to appropriately apply funds that we hold for our clients on a fiduciary basis. It is not always possible to prevent and detect errors and omissions and the precautions we take may not be effective in all cases. Our clients may bring claims against us for any alleged or perceived errors or omissions on our part. Errors and omissions claims can involve significant defense costs and may result in large damage awards against us, harm our reputation or divert management resources away from operating our business. While we customarily take out insurance to cover errors and omissions risk, errors and omissions insurance coverage is subject to deductibles and numerous exclusions and restrictive terms and conditions which may preclude or limit the coverage available in certain instances. While we endeavor to purchase coverage that is appropriate to our assessment of risk, we are unable to predict with certainty the frequency, nature or magnitude of claims for direct or consequential damages. In addition, we may fail to retain insurance coverage, or insurance coverage at appropriate levels, for all applicable error and omission exposures. In addition, any perceived or actual error and omission, as well as the claims related thereto, may potentially harm our reputation or divert management resources away from operating our business. The success of our business is directly related to, and highly dependent upon, the trust and confidence our clients, carriers, employees, regulators and other stakeholders place upon us. Any impairment to our reputation could, among other things, make it difficult for us to retain existing clients, attract new clients and harm our employee and carrier relationships, each of which may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our handling of client funds exposes us to complex fiduciary regulations.
Subsubsection Text: We collect premiums from insured clients and, after deducting our commissions and fees, remit the premiums to insurers. We also collect claims or refunds from insurers or public bodies on behalf of insureds, which are remitted to those insureds. Consequently, at any given time, we may hold funds of our clients, insurer trading partners and taxes, and we are subject to various laws and regulations governing the holding, management and investing of these client and tax funds. Any loss, theft, mishandling or misappropriation of these funds, caused by employee or third party fraud, execution of unauthorized transactions, errors relating to transaction processing or other events could subject us, in addition to claims brought forth by insureds, insurers and insurance intermediaries, to regulatory investigations, fines, penalties and reputational risk as a result of fiduciary breach and adversely affect our results of operations. Depending on the applicable jurisdiction, we may not have any viable defense or mitigation to any perceived or actual mishandling of client funds, thus resulting in financial liabilities for our Group and which therefore may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. While we are in possession of client, insurer trading partner and tax funds, we may invest those funds in certain short-term high-quality securities. Since we remain liable for any shortfall, we could experience significant losses if those securities decline in value for any reason. Additionally, if the institution with which they are held experiences any illiquidity or insolvency event, we may not be able to access client funds timely, if at all, which could significantly affect our results of operations and financial condition and expose us to additional legal and regulatory fines or sanctions. Any shortfall in accessing our clients funds, even perceived, may hinder our reputation with our clients, insurer trading partners and tax funds, and may thus result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Infringement, misappropriation or dilution of our intellectual property could harm our business.
Subsubsection Text: We believe that our Howden and DUAL trademarks have significant value and that these and other intellectual property are valuable assets that are critical to our success. Unauthorized uses or other infringement of our trademarks or service marks could diminish the value of our brand and may adversely affect our business. Effective intellectual property protection may not be available in every jurisdiction. Failure to adequately protect our intellectual property rights could damage our brand and impair our ability to compete effectively. Even where we have effectively secured statutory protection for our trademarks and other intellectual property, our competitors and other third parties may misappropriate our intellectual property, such competitors and other third parties occasionally attempt to challenge the breadth of our ability to prevent others from using similar marks or designs. If such challenges were to be successful, less ability to prevent others from using ----- similar marks or designs may ultimately result in a reduced distinctiveness of our brand in the minds of consumers. Defending or enforcing our trademark rights, branding practices and other intellectual property could result in the expenditure of significant resources and divert the attention of management, which in turn may materially and adversely affect our business and operating results, even if such defense or enforcement is ultimately successful. In the future, we may be involved in adversarial claims in relation to the use or attempted use by third parties of our marks, or challenges to the validity of our trademarks. Any failure to effectively protect our intellectual property, as well as our involvement in intellectual property-related claims (whether meritorious or not), may negatively affect our reputation and the recognition of our brand and, therefore, may adversely affect our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our businesses are affected by the risk of data leakage and cybersecurity, which may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: Privacy, identity theft, and computer and internet security issues are matters of growing public concern and are subject to frequently changing rules and expanding regulations. We are subject to numerous UK, EU, local and international laws and regulations regarding privacy, data protection and cybersecurity that govern the collection, use, storage, retention, maintenance, processing, transfer, transmission, disclosure and protection (collectively, “Processing”) of certain data (including personal information and other regulated data). Such examples include the European Union General Data Protection Regulation (the “GDPR”) and the GDPR retained as domestic law in the UK. These laws and regulations are increasing in severity, complexity and number, change frequently, and increasingly conflict among the various jurisdictions in which we operate, which has resulted in greater compliance risk and cost for us. Our businesses are exposed to the risk that data could be wrongfully appropriated, including for ransomware attacks, lost or disclosed or processed in breach of data protection regulation, by us or on our behalf. Where our businesses fail to transmit customer information in a secure manner, or where any such loss of personal customer data or other cybersecurity breach occurs, legal claims or proceedings may be brought against us by our employees, customers, vendors and governmental authorities, and our businesses could face liability and fines under data protection laws. This could also result in the loss of the goodwill of our existing customers and deter new customers from using our services, which may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. Our businesses are also dependent on contractual relationships with third parties and their employees who manage databases of sensitive data. Any customer data protection and payment data failures by our businesses could result in sanctions by the relevant regulators, as well as damage to the reputation of our businesses in the eyes of customers, which may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Legislative or taxation changes or enforcement actions may have a material adverse impact on our business, results of operations and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to the taxation rules in our operating jurisdictions. Changes in legislation or regulations and actions by regulators, including changes in administration and enforcement policies, could from time to time require operational improvements or modifications, the conduct of reviews and audits or the cessation of certain business practices, product lines or income streams that could result in higher costs or restrict our ability to operate our business and, as a result, have a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. When establishing tax provisions, we make a number of judgments and interpretations about the application and interaction of these laws, and those interpretations may be subject to challenge by tax authorities. Tax authorities may also take enforcement actions against us which may result in fines, penalties and/or interest charges being imposed on us which may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: There is a global movement towards Economic, Social and Governance regulation. This includes compulsory reporting requirements and, in some jurisdictions, a commitment to move towards net zero operating models. Significant changes to the way in which businesses operate could impact the operations of our Group and our clients.
Subsubsection Text: There has been increased focus by customers, investors, employees, and other stakeholders, as well as by governmental organizations and regulators on environmental, social and governance (“ESG”) matters. ----- Governments and regulatory bodies around the world are increasingly focusing on ESG issues and implementing policies and regulations to address them, including by expanding mandatory and voluntary reporting, and disclosure topics such as climate change, sustainability, natural resources, waste reduction, energy, human capital and risk oversight. For example, companies across all industries have been subject to increasing ESG reporting requirements, such as the new requirements under the European Union Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (EU Directive 2022/2464), which will come into force in the European Union in 2024. While we have been making statements about our ESG goals and initiatives since the fiscal year ended September 30, 2023 through our reporting under the TCFD (Task Force on Climate-related Financial Disclosures) framework(including through periodic sustainability reports and information provided on our website and in our press releases and other communications), compliance with these regulations could require significant changes to our business practices, operations, and investments. There can be no certainty that we will manage such issues successfully, or that we will meet ESG expectations or any current or future ESG reporting requirements that are continuously evolving. In particular, we may not be able to efficiently collect and report data from each of the companies of our Group and, therefore, we may not be able to comply in a timely manner with any present or future ESG reporting requirements. Failure to comply with these regulations could result in significant financial penalties, legal liabilities, and reputational damage, which may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. Additionally, changes in regulations, laws, and policies around ESG factors and negative perceptions and media attention regarding the activities of some of our clients could have an adverse impact on the operations of our Group and our clients, as well as expose us to legal and financial risks, and thus may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are subject to risks associated with the current interest rate environment and to the extent we incur debt to finance our investments, changes in interest rates will affect our cost of capital and net investment income.
Subsubsection Text: As of September 30, 2023, approximately 94% of our Group’s indebtedness bears interest at variable rates. Our Existing Facilities bear interest at floating rates of interest per annum equal to EURIBOR or SOFR (LIBOR historically), as applicable, as adjusted periodically, plus a spread. These interest rates have recently risen in response to higher inflation and could rise significantly in the future, thereby increasing our interest expenses associated with these obligations, reducing cash flow available for capital expenditures and hindering our ability to make payments on the Notes. As for September 30, 2023, our Group estimates that, through the combination of the natural hedge and interest rate derivatives (swaps and cap), a weighted average of 67% (2022: 61%, 2021: 36%) of the notional amount of the Existing Term Loans is hedged for the period to March 2024. In the future, we may not be able to obtain such hedges, or replace such hedges, on terms that are acceptable to us, and any such hedge may not be fully effective, which would expose us to interest rate risk. Following allegations of manipulation of LIBOR, a measure of interbank lending rates, regulators and law enforcement agencies from a number of governments are conducting investigations into whether the banks that contribute data in connection with the calculation of daily EURIBOR or the calculation of LIBOR may have been manipulating or attempting to manipulate EURIBOR and LIBOR. In addition, LIBOR, EURIBOR and other interest rates or other types of rates and indices which are deemed to be “benchmarks” are the subject of ongoing national and international regulatory reform. Some of these reforms are already effective, while others are still being implemented.
