These benchmark reforms include the implementation of the IOSCO Principles for Financial Market Benchmarks (July 2013) and the European regulation on indices used as benchmarks in financial instruments and financial contracts or to measure the performance of investment funds (Regulation 2016/1011/EU), which forms part of UK domestic law by virtue of the EUWA. As a further example of the ongoing benchmark reforms, on March 5, 2021, the FCA confirmed that all LIBOR settings will either cease to be provided by any administrator or no longer be representative: (i) immediately after December 31, 2021, in the case of all sterling, euro, Swiss franc and Japanese yen settings, and the 1-week and 2-month U.S. dollar settings; and (ii) immediately after June 30, 2023, in the case of the remaining U.S. dollar settings. The elimination of the LIBOR benchmark or the potential elimination of any other benchmark, changes in the manner of administration of any benchmark, or actions by regulators or law enforcement agencies could result in changes to the manner in which EURIBOR or LIBOR is determined, which could require an ----- adjustment to the terms and conditions, or result in other consequences, in respect of any debt linked to such benchmark. Any such change, as well as manipulative practices or the cessation thereof, may result in a sudden or prolonged increase in reported EURIBOR, which may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our operations expose us to exchange rate fluctuations and various risks that could impact our business.
Subsubsection Text: We operate globally and as a result, are exposed to fluctuations in currency exchange rates. This exposure arises where revenue is received in currencies different from the currency of our costs. A significant amount of our revenue is denominated in GBP, USD and EUR. However, the majority of our costs are denominated in GBP, despite diverse currency exposures. Further, our debt service obligations are in USD and EUR, serviced by respective USD and EUR profits. While there is a hedging program to buy GBP-sell USD to give some certainty over cash flows, the USD and EUR profits are largely unhedged to act as economic hedge over our Group’s debt leverage given our Group’s debt is largely in USD or EUR. Therefore if the USD/EUR debt fluctuates in value in GBP due to foreign exchange, there is a compensating movement in the USD/EUR profits to maintain leverage. Moreover, sharp spikes in USD vs. GBP at a month end can cause leverage to increase as the USD debt is revalued higher (at the spot rate) without a corresponding adjustment in EBITDA, as EBITDA is calculated on a 12 month average basis, all of which may cause positive or negative fluctuations to the leverage ratio. As a consequence, our results of operations are impacted by currency exchange rate fluctuations and any unfavorable movement in currency exchange rates, including as a result of the devaluation of a currency in a particular country we operate in, may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of _Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Currency Fluctuations and Hedging.”_ Furthermore, we present our consolidated financial statements in GBP. As a result, we must translate the assets, liabilities, income and expenses of all operations that use a functional currency other than GBP. We translate into GBP at then-applicable exchange rates, exposing us to translation risk (i.e., the risk that exchange rates will impact the value of our income, assets, liabilities and expenses reported in GBP even if the value has not changed in the underlying currency). Currency translations could significantly affect the comparability of our results between financial periods and could result in significant changes to the carrying value of assets, liabilities and shareholders’ equity. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and _Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Currency Fluctuations and Hedging.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our substantial leverage and debt service obligations, which may increase in the future, could materially adversely affect our business, financial position and results of operations and preclude us from satisfying our obligations under the Notes and the Guarantees.
Subsubsection Text: After completion of the Transactions, we will be highly leveraged and have significant debt service obligations. As of September 30, 2023, on a pro forma basis after giving effect to the Transactions, our Total Debt would be in the amount of £5,603 million (equivalent), including $1,250 million in aggregate principal amount outstanding under the Notes, $3,435 million in aggregate principal amount under the New Dollar Term Loan, €660 million in aggregate principal amount under the New Euro Term Loan and $1,083 under the 2030 Dollar Term Loan, and excluding up to £630 million available for drawing under the New Revolving Credit Facility. See “Capitalization,” “Description of Other Indebtedness,” “Description of Senior Secured Notes” and “Description of Senior Notes.” Furthermore, we may incur substantial additional debt in the future. Although the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement and the Indentures contain restrictions on the incurrence of additional indebtedness, these restrictions are subject to a number of significant qualifications and exceptions, and under certain circumstances, the amount of indebtedness that could be incurred in compliance with these restrictions could be substantial. If new debt is added to our existing debt levels, the related risks that we now face would increase. Increases in our total indebtedness could also lead to a downgrade of the ratings assigned to the Group or the Notes, which could negatively affect their trading price. In addition, the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement and the Indentures do not prevent us from incurring obligations that do not constitute indebtedness under those agreements. Our current or future leverage could prevent us from generating sufficient cash to pay the principal, interest or any other amounts that become due and payable under our ----- indebtedness, including the Notes. The terms of the Indentures and the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement will permit, under certain circumstances, the incurrence of substantial additional indebtedness by the Group and the proceeds from such indebtedness may be used, among others, to finance shareholder dividends reducing our liquidity while increasing our leverage. Our significant leverage could have important consequences for our business and operations including, but not limited to: - result in our inability to maintain one or more of the financial ratios under our debt agreements, which could trigger the early maturity of part or all our debt; - place us at a competitive disadvantage compared to competitors with lower leverage and better access to third-party financing sources; - increase the costs of current and future loans; - limit our capacity to access new debt and promote necessary investment, or our ability to withstand adverse market conditions; or - force us to increase our capital stock or to divest specific strategic assets to service our debts or comply with the commitments under such debts. Pro forma for the Transactions, most of the principal amount of our financial debt will fall due in 2031 as a single payment upon the maturity of the Senior Secured Notes and the New Term Loan Facilities and there can be no assurance that we will at such time be able to refinance or otherwise repay such principal amount in full, and therefore holders of the Notes are exposed to the risk that we may be unable to raise the financing that we require. Other significant amounts of debt are expected to mature prior to the Senior Secured Notes and the Senior Notes include the New Revolving Credit Facility.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to credit and liquidity risk which may have an adverse impact on our business, cash flow, results of operation, and financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: Our ability to obtain liquidity is essential to our capacity to meet both anticipated and unanticipated financial obligations in a manner that does not prejudice our day-to-day operations. We expect that, following the completion of the Transactions, our primary sources of liquidity will be cash flows from operating activities and borrowings under our debt facilities, including our New Revolving Credit Facility, £75 million of which was drawn subsequent to September 30, 2023 for short-term working capital purposes but intended to be repaid shortly following the Issue Date. Our ability to arrange financing generally and our cost of capital depends on numerous factors, including general economic conditions, the availability of credit from banks and in capital markets and our general financial performance. However, we may not be able to obtain sufficient financing on satisfactory terms and conditions as certain of our debt agreements contain covenants that, among other things, require us to maintain certain financial ratios and restrict our ability to incur additional debt. Moreover, substantially all of our existing and potential future assets are pledged as collateral under our existing financing. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Liquidity and _Capital Resources—Contractual Obligations.”_ We currently have, and, following the completion of the Transactions, will continue to have, substantial debt, which exposes us to financial market risk (including refinancing risk) resulting from, among other things, changes in interest rates and conditions in the credit and capital markets. Additionally, we have a number of employees who may retire or otherwise leave during the term of the Notes in circumstances that entitle them to a fair market value payment on the value of their vested shares, who hold significant equity, outstanding put options and guaranteed bonuses, and that may engage in share buybacks, which could cause a strain on our liquidity. Volatility in credit and capital markets may create additional risks to our businesses in the future. We seek to mitigate our refinancing risk by having an appropriately balanced debt maturity profile. Moreover, the incurrence of additional debt could lead to a rating downgrade by rating agencies which could in turn result in revenue or cash pressure. If market conditions were adverse for an extended period, if there were a general economic downturn, if our credit standing were to decline or if we were unable to access the ----- market to meet our liquidity requirements, such factors individually or in the aggregate may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: If we are unable to collect our receivables, our results of operations and cash flows could be adversely affected.
Subsubsection Text: Our business depends on our ability to obtain payment from our clients or insurer trading partners of the amounts they owe us for the work we perform. As of September 30, 2023, our insurance receivables for our commissions and fees were £429.2 million, or 20% of our revenue of our fees and commissions, and the total expected credit loss provision on insurance receivables as of September 30, 2023 was £23.3 million (2022: £21.6 million, 2021: £12.4 million). Macroeconomic or political conditions could result in financial difficulties for our clients, which could cause clients to delay payments to us, request modifications to their payment arrangements that could increase our receivables balance or default on their payment obligations to us and, in turn, may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Potential future impairments of our goodwill and other intangible assets could have a material adverse effect on our results of operation.
Subsubsection Text: Our goodwill is a significant asset. As of September 30, 2023, the book value of our goodwill amounted to £3,564.9 million while our total intangible assets amounted to £1,769.5 million. In accordance with IFRS, we annually test whether goodwill and other assets with indefinite useful lives have suffered any impairment. Other assets are also reviewed for impairments whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of the asset exceeds its recoverable amount. The recoverable amount of an asset or a cash generating unit is determined based on the higher of fair value less costs to sell and a value in use calculation based on management’s assumptions and estimates. A decrease in expected cash flows of our Group of cash generating units, changes in market conditions, loss of key customers and a change in our imputed cost of capital may indicate potential impairment of recorded goodwill. Weakness in the global economy may also cause us to make impairment charges, which, depending on the amounts impaired, may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Our derivative instruments may be ineffective or may not be implemented correctly.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to the risk of changes in exchange rates and their impact on our derivative instruments. Hedging arrangements entered into at historic rates may become unfavorable in future. There is a risk that bank credit lines are exceeded which may cause us to be barred from taking out new derivatives. We also face counterparty risk where the hedging bank might fail to honor the hedging transactions. An inability to enter into hedging arrangements on favorable terms may result in us not receiving sufficient GBP to meet contractual obligations as they fall due. We do not plan to enter into cross-currency swaps to mitigate exposure to foreign currency risk on the Notes. Any of these events could cause losses and may result in a material adverse effect on our business, results of operations and financial condition.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks related to our Business and Industry
Subsubsection Title: Changes in our accounting estimates and assumptions could negatively affect our financial position and results of operations.
Subsubsection Text: We prepare our consolidated financial statements in accordance with IFRS, as adopted by the UK. These accounting principles require us to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of our consolidated financial statements. We are also required to make certain judgments that affect the reported amounts of revenue and expenses during each reporting period. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and _Results of Operations—Liquidity and Capital Resources—Critical Accounting Policies and Judgments.” We_ continually evaluate these estimates, which are based on historical experience and on assumptions that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances. These estimates form the basis for our judgments about the carrying values of the assets and liabilities for which values are not readily apparent from other sources. Actual results could differ from these estimates, which could materially affect our consolidated statements of operations, comprehensive income, financial position, shareholders’ equity, and cash flows. Changes in accounting standards (such as new standards relating to revenue recognition and leases) could also have an adverse impact on our future consolidated financial statements. These changes can be hard to predict and can ----- materially impact how we record and report our financial condition and results of operations. In some cases, we could be required to apply a new or revised standard retroactively, resulting in the restatement of prior period financial statements.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: Upon issuance on the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes will only be secured by the Issue Date Collateral and guaranteed by the Issue Date Guarantors.
Subsubsection Text: On the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes will only be secured, subject to the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement, the Agreed Security Principles, any limitations set out in the Security Documents and the applicable perfection requirements, by the Issue Date Collateral. Subject to the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement, the Agreed Security Principles, any limitations set out in the Security Documents and the applicable perfection requirements, within 120 days from the Issue Date the Senior Secured Notes and the Guarantees in relation to Senior Secured Notes, will be secured by the Post-Closing Collateral. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Security for the Notes.”Furthermore, on the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes will only be obligations of the SSN Issuers and the Issue Date Guarantors and will not be guaranteed by the Post-Closing Guarantors. Within 120 days from the Issue Date, the Senior Secured Notes will be guaranteed by the Post-Closing Guarantors. There can be no assurance, however, that we will be successful in procuring such security interests or Guarantees within the time periods specified, the failure of which would result in an “event of default” under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The value of the Collateral securing the Senior Secured Notes and the SSN Guarantees may not be sufficient to satisfy our obligations under the Senior Secured Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The obligations under the Senior Secured Notes will be secured, together with the obligations pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement, by first-priority liens on the Collateral (subject to certain thresholds, exceptions and permitted liens). No appraisal of the value of the collateral has been made in connection with this Offering, and the fair market value of the Collateral will be subject to fluctuations based on factors that include, among others, changing economic conditions, competition and other future trends. By its nature, some or all of the Collateral may be illiquid and may have no readily ascertainable market value. In the event of a foreclosure, liquidation, bankruptcy or similar proceeding, the lenders under the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement, the holders of the Senior Secured Notes and the holders of any other pari passu first lien indebtedness will be entitled to be repaid in full from the proceeds of the Collateral before any payment is made in respect of any other indebtedness that is secured by a junior lien on such Collateral or that is unsecured (see also “—The rights of holders of the Senior Secured Notes in some of the Collateral may be _adversely affected by such security interests being second-ranking”)._ Moreover, the lenders under the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement and the holders of any other indebtedness secured by a first-priority lien on the Collateral will share the proceeds of the Collateral ratably with the holders of the Senior Secured Notes (see also “—The rights of holders of the Senior Secured Notes in _some of the Collateral may be adversely affected by such security interests being second-ranking”), thereby_ diluting the Collateral coverage available to holders of the Senior Secured Notes. As a result, the fair market value of the Collateral may not be sufficient to repay the holders of the Senior Secured Notes upon any foreclosure, liquidation, dissolution, reorganization, bankruptcy or similar proceeding. There also can be no assurance that the Collateral will be saleable, and even if saleable, the timing of its liquidation would be uncertain. Accordingly, the Collateral may not be sold in a timely or orderly manner, and the proceeds from any sale or liquidation of the Collateral may not be sufficient to pay all or any of the amounts due on the Senior Secured Notes. Any claim for the difference between the amount, if any, realized by holders of the Senior Secured Notes from the sale of the Collateral and the obligations under the Senior Secured Notes will rank equally in right of payment with all of our unsecured unsubordinated indebtedness and other obligations, including trade payables. In addition, the holders of the Senior Secured Notes would not be entitled to receive post-petition interest or applicable fees, costs, expenses or charges to the extent the amount of the obligations due under the Senior Secured Notes exceeded the value of the Collateral (after taking into account all other debt secured by first-priority liens on the Collateral, including the obligations pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement), or any “adequate protection” on account of any undersecured portion of the Senior Secured Notes. See also “—In the event of bankruptcy proceedings in the United States following our ----- _bankruptcy, the holders of the Senior Secured Notes may be deemed to have an unsecured claim to the extent that our obligations in respect of the Senior Secured Notes exceed the fair market value of the Collateral.”_ All of our indebtedness pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement is secured by the Collateral on a first-priority lien basis and will be entitled to payment out of the proceeds of any sale of the Collateral on an equal and ratable basis with the holders of the Senior Secured Notes (see also “—The rights of holders of _the Senior Secured Notes in some of the Collateral may be adversely affected by such security interests being second-ranking.”). Under the terms of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, we will be permitted to incur_ additional secured indebtedness on an equal and ratable basis, which may further dilute the Collateral and limit recovery from the realization of the Collateral available to satisfy the holders of the Senior Secured Notes. Although the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement and the Senior Secured Notes Indenture will contain restrictions on the incurrence of additional secured indebtedness, these restrictions are subject to a number of qualifications and exceptions and the indebtedness incurred in compliance with these restrictions could be substantial. For example, we and the SSN Guarantors will be permitted to incur debt secured by certain prior ranking liens, such as finance lease obligations, that will rank effectively senior to the liens securing the notes with respect to the assets that are subject thereto. Any such secured indebtedness may further dilute the Collateral coverage and limit the recovery from the realization of the collateral available to satisfy holders of the notes. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on _Liens.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: Sales of assets by the SSN Issuers and the SSN Guarantors could reduce the Collateral and the SSN Guarantees.
Subsubsection Text: The Security Documents will generally allow us and the SSN Guarantors to remain in possession of, retain exclusive control over, freely operate and collect, invest and dispose of any income from, the Collateral, subject to the terms of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture. Therefore, without any release or consent by the Senior Secured Notes Trustee or Notes Collateral Agent, the pool of assets constituting the Collateral will change from time to time, and its fair market value may decrease from its value on the date the Senior Secured Notes are originally issued. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes” for more details.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The imposition of certain permitted liens will, under certain circumstances, permit the liens on the related assets securing the Senior Secured Notes and the SSN Guarantees to be either subordinated to such permitted liens or released. There are also certain other assets that are excluded from the Collateral.
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes Indenture that will govern the Senior Secured Notes will permit liens in favor of third parties to secure additional debt, including purchase money indebtedness and finance lease obligations, and, in the case of certain of such liens, the liens on the related assets securing the Senior Secured Notes and the SSN Guarantees may, under certain circumstances, be either subordinated to such permitted liens or released. Our ability to incur additional debt and liens securing such additional debt in favor of third parties is subject to limitations as described herein under the headings “Description of Senior Secured Notes.” In addition, certain assets are excluded from the Collateral securing the Senior Secured Notes and the SSN Guarantees, as discussed under “Description of Senior Secured Notes—Security for the Senior Secured Notes.” If an event of default occurs and the maturity of the Senior Secured Notes is accelerated, the Senior Secured Notes and the SSN Guarantees will rank pari passu with the holders of other unsecured or senior indebtedness of the relevant obligor with respect to such excluded assets. As a result, if the value of the assets pledged as security for the Senior Secured Notes is less than the value of the claims of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes, those claims may not be satisfied in full before the claims of our unsecured creditors are paid.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The claims of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes will be effectively subordinated to the rights of our existing and future secured creditors to the extent of the value of the assets securing such creditors which do not also secure the Senior Secured Notes as part of the Collateral.
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes will be secured only to the extent of the value of the Collateral at the time of enforcement. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Security for the Notes.” Not all of our assets secure the Senior Secured Notes. In addition, the Senior Secured Notes Indenture allows HGH Finance and its Restricted Subsidiaries (as defined in “Description of the Senior Secured Notes”) to secure any future Indebtedness (as defined in the Senior Secured Notes Indenture) permitted to be incurred under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture (which may be structurally senior to the Senior Secured Notes and the Guarantees) ----- with certain property and assets that do not secure the Senior Secured Notes. As of September 30, 2023, as adjusted to give effect to the Transactions, non-Guarantor subsidiaries had £107 million of third-party debt outstanding which was secured over assets other than the Collateral. The value of such assets and property that do not secure the Senior Secured Notes could be significant. In the event of any enforcement, foreclosure, dissolution, winding up, liquidation, reorganization, administration or other bankruptcy or insolvency proceeding of any SSN Issuer or any SSN Guarantor, the Senior Secured Notes and the SSN Guarantees will not benefit from the assets securing other secured debt and will rank equally with the holders of other unsecured indebtedness of HGH Finance and its restricted subsidiaries with respect to any property or assets excluded from the Collateral securing the Senior Secured Notes. The assets remaining after repayment of such secured indebtedness may not be sufficient to repay all amounts owing in respect of the Senior Secured Notes, or the SSN Guarantees. As such, the claims of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes will be effectively subordinated to the rights of such other secured creditors to the extent of the value of the assets securing such other indebtedness. While the Senior Secured Notes Indenture creates certain obligations to provide additional guarantees and grant additional security over assets, or a particular class of assets, whether as a result of the acquisition or creation of future assets or subsidiaries or otherwise, such obligations are subject to the Agreed Security Principles. The Agreed Security Principles set out a number of limitations on the rights of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes to be granted security or guarantees in certain circumstances. The operation of the Agreed Security Principles may result in, among others, the amount recoverable under any Collateral provided being limited or security not being granted over a particular type or class of assets. Accordingly, the Agreed Security Principles may affect the value of the Collateral or the SSN Guarantees provided by the SSN Guarantors. Although the Collateral securing the obligations pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement is currently expected to be the same as the Collateral securing the Senior Secured Notes (see also “—The rights _of holders of the Senior Secured Notes in some of the Collateral may be adversely affected by such security interests being second-ranking”), this may not continue to be the case and circumstances may arise in the future_ in which lenders under the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement may be granted the benefit of additional security or guarantees which are not otherwise permitted to be granted in favor of holders of the Senior Secured Notes due to the application of the Agreed Security Principles and, ultimately, financial assistance and corporate benefit rules in the respective jurisdictions of the SSN Guarantors. Accordingly, in such circumstances holders of the Senior Secured Notes would have no direct claim for payment against any such additional guarantor nor any rights as a secured party with respect to any such additional collateral. In addition, in certain jurisdictions, including England and Wales, under mandatory proceeds distribution waterfalls, payments or distributions to certain groups of creditors of a company following an enforcement, foreclosure, dissolution, winding up, liquidation, reorganization, administration, other bankruptcy or insolvency proceeding or other similar process against such company may be subordinated to certain other unsecured indebtedness (such as certain bank debt, court, legal and current costs, taxes and impositions, state related obligations, personal injury claims and moral damage claims, severance benefits, copyright royalties or employee wages and other privileged claims). See “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees _and the Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.” As a result, holders of the Senior_ Secured Notes may receive less, ratably, than holders of certain types of secured indebtedness and/or of certain types of unsecured indebtedness of the SSN Issuers or the SSN Guarantor.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The security interests in the Collateral will not be granted directly to the holders of the Senior Secured Notes and the ability of the Notes Collateral Agent to enforce the Collateral may be restricted by local law.
Subsubsection Text: The security interests that will secure the respective obligations of the SSN Issuers under the Senior Secured Notes and the obligations of the SSN Guarantors under the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees will not be granted directly to the holders of the Senior Secured Notes but to the Notes Collateral Agent. As a consequence, holders of the Senior Secured Notes will not have direct security interests and will not be entitled to take enforcement action in respect of the Collateral, except through the Senior Secured Notes Trustee, who will, subject to the provisions of the Senior Secured Notes Indenture and the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement, provide instructions to the Notes Collateral Agent in respect of the Collateral. By accepting a Senior Secured Note you will be deemed to have agreed to these restrictions. As a result of these restrictions, ----- holders of the Senior Secured Notes will have limited remedies and recourse against us in the event of a default. See “Description of Other Indebtedness—Intercreditor Agreement.” The Collateral will be subject to exceptions, defects, encumbrances, liens and other imperfections permitted under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture and the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement, whether on or after the date the Senior Secured Notes are first issued. The existence of such exceptions, defects, encumbrances, liens and other imperfections could adversely affect the value of the Collateral, as well as the ability of the Notes Collateral Agent to realize or foreclose on such Collateral. Furthermore, the first-priority ranking of security interests can be affected by a variety of factors, including the timely satisfaction of perfection requirements, statutory liens or re-characterization under applicable law (see also “—The rights of _holders of the Senior Secured Notes in some of the Collateral may be adversely affected by such security interests being second-ranking”). The Collateral may be subject to practical problems generally associated with the_ realization of security interests in collateral. The Notes Collateral Agent may also need to obtain the consent of a third-party to enforce a security interest. The Notes Collateral Agent may not be able to obtain any such consents. Accordingly, the Notes Collateral Agent may not have the ability to foreclose upon those assets, and the value of the Collateral may significantly decrease. Furthermore, because the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, the Senior Secured Notes, the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement and the security interests in the Collateral will be affected or governed, as applicable, by the laws of a number of different jurisdictions, respective realization and enforcement may be further delayed by court proceedings being taken in multiple jurisdictions. In addition, the ability of the Notes Collateral Agent or the Senior Secured Notes Trustee, as applicable, to enforce the security interests is subject to mandatory provisions of the laws of each jurisdiction in which security interests over the Collateral are taken (see also “—The rights of holders of the Senior Secured Notes in _some of the Collateral may be adversely affected by such security interests being second-ranking”). For example,_ in certain circumstances, the laws of certain jurisdictions may not allow for the appropriation of certain pledged assets, but require a sale through a public auction and certain waiting periods may apply. There might be some uncertainty under the laws of certain jurisdictions as to whether obligations to beneficial owners of the Senior Secured Notes that are not identified as registered holders in, nor are directly parties to, a security document will be validly secured and/or can be enforced; this area of law is untested in the courts of certain jurisdictions. In certain jurisdictions, due to the laws and other jurisprudence governing the creation and perfection of security interests and the enforceability of such security interests, the Senior Secured Notes Indenture provides for the creation of “parallel debt”obligations in favor of the relevant Notes Collateral Agent (“Parallel Debt”) mirroring the obligations of each Issuer and Guarantor owed to holders of the Notes under or in connection with the Indentures, as applicable (“Principal Obligations”). All or part of the pledges and other security interests in such jurisdictions will be granted to the Notes Collateral Agent as security interests for the Parallel Debt and will not directly secure the Principal Obligations. The Parallel Debt will be at all times in the same amount and payable at the same time as the Principal Obligations and any payment in respect of the Principal Obligations shall discharge the corresponding Parallel Debt and any payment in respect of the Parallel Debt shall discharge the corresponding Principal Obligations. In respect of the security interests granted to secure the Parallel Debt, the holders of the Senior Secured Notes will not have direct security interests and will not be entitled to take enforcement actions in respect of such security interests except through the Notes Collateral Agent. Therefore, the holders of the Notes will bear the risk of insolvency or bankruptcy of the Notes Collateral Agent. In addition, the Parallel Debt construct has not been tested under law in certain of these jurisdictions and to the extent that the security interests in the Collateral created under the Parallel Debt construct are deemed not to have been validly granted, are unenforceable or are successfully challenged by other parties, holders of the Notes will not receive any proceeds from an enforcement of such security interests in the Collateral. See “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests _and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The granting of the security interests in the Collateral may create hardening periods for such security interests in accordance with the laws applicable in certain jurisdictions.
Subsubsection Text: The granting of security interests to secure the Senior Secured Notes or any other debt may create hardening, claw-back or voidance periods for such security interests in certain jurisdictions. The applicable hardening ----- period will run as from the moment each new security interest has been granted, perfected, extended or recreated, including those security interests created on a subsequent date pursuant to an undertaking or promise to create the relevant security interest by the relevant mortgagor or pledgor. In addition, the granting of a shared security interest to secure future debt may require the releasing and retaking of security or otherwise restart or reopen hardening periods in certain or all of the jurisdictions of the SSN Guarantors or security providers, and the Senior Secured Notes Indenture will permit the release and retaking of security granted in favor of the Senior Secured Notes in certain circumstances, including in connection with the incurrence of future debt. The applicable hardening period for these new security interests will run from the moment each new security interest has been granted or perfected. If the security interest granted were to be enforced before the end of the applicable hardening period, the security interest may be declared void or ineffective and it may not be possible to enforce it under certain circumstances and subject to certain requirements. If the provider of such security interest were to become subject to a bankruptcy or winding-up proceeding after the relevant collateral grant date, any security interest in Collateral delivered after the Issue Date would face a greater risk than security interests in place on the Issue Date of being voided by the security provider or by its trustee, receiver, liquidator, administrator or similar authority, or otherwise set aside by a court, as a preference under insolvency law. To the extent that the grant of any security interest is voided, holders of the Senior Secured Notes would lose the benefit of the security interest. The same rights and risks also will apply with respect to future security interests granted in connection with the accession of further subsidiaries as additional guarantors and the granting of security interests over their relevant assets and equity interests for the benefit of holders of the Senior Secured Notes. Furthermore, the Senior Secured Notes Indenture will provide that the Collateral may be released and retaken in several circumstances, including in connection with a public offering of shares of common stock or other common equity interest and certain “permitted reorganizations.” In certain jurisdictions such a release and retaking of Collateral may give rise to new hardening periods in respect of the relevant security interests in the Collateral that are granted, perfected or released and retaken, and the security interests in the relevant Collateral would be subject to the same risks described herein. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Security for the _Notes.”_ For a summary on hardening periods and actions for rescission in the jurisdictions of the SSN Guarantors or security providers in force as at the date of this Offering Memorandum see “Limitations on Validity and _Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: Even though the holders of the Senior Secured Notes will benefit from a first-priority lien on the Collateral, the Bank Collateral Agent will initially control actions with respect to that collateral pursuant to the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement.
Subsubsection Text: The rights of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes with respect to the Collateral that will secure the Senior Secured Notes on a first-priority basis will be subject to the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement among all holders (or their representatives) of obligations secured by that Collateral on a first-priority basis, including the obligations pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement (see also “—The rights of holders of _the Senior Secured Notes in some of the Collateral may be adversely affected by such security interests being second-ranking”). Under the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement, any actions that may be taken with_ respect to such Collateral, including the ability to cause the commencement of enforcement proceedings against such Collateral and to control such proceedings, will be at the exclusive direction of the Bank Collateral Agent until the Controlling Collateral Agent Change Date. At any time that the Bank Collateral Agent does not have the right to direct the actions with respect to the Collateral pursuant to the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement, the right to direct such actions will pass to the authorized representative of holders of the then largest outstanding principal amount of indebtedness secured by a first-priority lien on the collateral. If we have, at such time, outstanding indebtedness that is secured by the Collateral on an equal and ratable basis with the Senior Secured Notes and has a greater outstanding principal amount than the outstanding aggregate principal amount of the Senior Secured Notes, then the authorized representative for such indebtedness would be next in line to exercise rights under the ----- Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement, rather than the Notes Collateral Agent. Accordingly, the Notes Collateral Agent may never have the right to control remedies and take other actions with respect to the Collateral. Also, under the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement, in the event that the holders of the Senior Secured Notes obtain possession of any part of the Collateral or realize any proceeds or payment in respect of any Collateral at any time prior to the discharge of each of the other first-priority obligations, then such holders will be obligated to hold such Collateral, proceeds or payment in trust for the other holders of first-priority obligations and promptly transfer such Collateral, proceeds or payment, as the case may be, to the Controlling Collateral Agent, to be distributed in accordance with the provisions of the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement among all the holders of first priority obligations. Thus, the holders of the Senior Secured Notes may be obligated to turn over to the other holders of the first-priority obligations any collateral, proceeds or payments they may receive.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The rights of holders of the Senior Secured Notes in some of the Collateral may be adversely affected by such security interests being second-ranking.
Subsubsection Text: Depending on the relevant SSN Guarantor or security grantor jurisdiction, the Collateral for the Senior Secured Notes may be granted by means of supplemental debentures to, and confirmation agreements of, existing security agreements or by means of a second layer of security documents. As such, in certain circumstances, the Collateral may be second-ranking in a particular jurisdiction and only be deemed and treated as security interests ranking pari passu with the security interests securing the obligations pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement pursuant to the application of the provisions of the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement. If the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement or the relevant provisions thereof were avoided or held to be unenforceable for any reason, holders of the Senior Secured Notes would not benefit from such first-priority treatment and be subordinated, with respect to such security interests, to senior security interests over the same Collateral securing the obligations pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: Rights of holders of the Senior Secured Notes in the Collateral may be adversely affected by U.S. bankruptcy proceedings.
Subsubsection Text: The right of the Notes Collateral Agent to foreclose upon, repossess and dispose of the Collateral located in the United States is likely to be significantly impaired (or at a minimum delayed) by U.S. federal bankruptcy law if bankruptcy proceedings are commenced by or against us or the SSN Guarantors prior to, or possibly even after, any collateral agent has repossessed and disposed of the Collateral. Under the U.S. bankruptcy code, a secured creditor, such as the Notes Collateral Agent, is prohibited from foreclosing upon or repossessing its security from a debtor in a bankruptcy case, or from disposing of security previously repossessed from a debtor, without prior bankruptcy court approval (which may not be given under the circumstances or which could be materially delayed). Moreover, the U.S. bankruptcy code permits the debtor to continue to retain and use collateral, and the proceeds, products, rents and profits of the collateral, even though the debtor is in default under the applicable debt instruments, provided that the secured creditor is given “adequate protection.” The meaning of the term “adequate protection” may vary according to the circumstances, but it is intended in general to protect the value of the secured creditor’s interest in its collateral and may include cash payments or the granting of additional or replacement security, if and at such time as the court in its discretion determines, for any diminution in the value of the collateral as a result of the automatic stay of repossession or disposition or any use of the collateral by the debtor during the pendency of the bankruptcy case. A bankruptcy court may determine that a secured creditor may not require compensation for a diminution in the value of its collateral if the value of the collateral exceeds the amount of debt it secures. In view of both the lack of a precise definition of the term “adequate protection” under the U.S. bankruptcy code and the broad discretionary powers of a bankruptcy court, it is impossible to predict how, whether or when payments under the Senior Secured Notes could be made following the commencement of a bankruptcy case, the length of the delay in making any such payments or whether any such payment will be made at all or in what form, whether or when the Notes Collateral Agent could or would repossess or dispose of the Collateral, the value of the Collateral as of the commencement date of any bankruptcy proceedings or any other relevant time, or whether or to what extent or in what form holders of the notes would be compensated for any delay in payment or loss of the value of the Collateral through the requirements of “adequate protection.” ----- Furthermore, a bankruptcy court may decide to substantively consolidate us and some or all of our subsidiaries in a bankruptcy proceeding. If a bankruptcy court substantively consolidated us and some or all of our subsidiaries, the assets of each entity would become subject to the claims of creditors of all entities. Such a ruling would expose holders of the Senior Secured Notes not only to the usual impairments arising from bankruptcy, but also to potential dilution of the amount ultimately recoverable because of the larger creditor base. Furthermore, a forced restructuring of the notes could occur through the “cramdown” provisions of the U.S. bankruptcy code. Under those provisions, the Senior Secured Notes could be restructured over holders’ objections as to their interest rates, maturities and other general terms. Also, any disposition of the Collateral during a bankruptcy case outside of the ordinary course of business would also require approval from the bankruptcy court (which may not be given under the circumstances or which could be materially delayed). In addition, the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement will impose certain limitations on the ability of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes to object to a proposed debtor-in-possession financing unless the authorized agent for the lenders under the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement opposes or objects thereto.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: In the event of bankruptcy proceedings in the United States following our bankruptcy, the holders of the Senior Secured Notes may be deemed to have an unsecured claim to the extent that our obligations in respect of the Senior Secured Notes exceed the fair market value of the Collateral.
Subsubsection Text: In any bankruptcy proceeding with respect to the SSN Issuers or the SSN Guarantors taking place in the United States, it is possible that the bankruptcy trustee, the debtor-in-possession or competing creditors will assert that the fair market value of the Collateral on the date of the bankruptcy filing was less than the then-current principal amount of the Senior Secured Notes and all of our other outstanding obligations secured by a first-priority lien on the Collateral (see also “—The rights of holders of the Senior Secured Notes _in some of the Collateral may be adversely affected by such security interests being second-ranking”). Upon a_ finding by the bankruptcy court that the Senior Secured Notes are under-collateralized, the claims in the bankruptcy proceeding with respect to the Senior Secured Notes would be bifurcated between a secured claim and an unsecured “deficiency”claim, and the unsecured claim would not be entitled to the benefits of security in the Collateral. In such event, the secured claims of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes would be limited to the value of the Collateral. The consequences of a finding of under-collateralization would include, among other things, a lack of entitlement on the part of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes to receive post-petition interest, fees, and expenses and a lack of entitlement on the part of the unsecured portion of the Senior Secured Notes to receive “adequate protection” under the U.S. bankruptcy code, as discussed above. In addition, if any payments of post-petition interest had been made at the time of such a finding of under-collateralization, those payments could be re-characterized by the bankruptcy court as a reduction of the principal amount of the secured claim with respect to the notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: There may be restrictions or limitations on foreclosure.
Subsubsection Text: Our obligations under the Senior Secured Notes and the SSN Guarantors’ obligations under the Senior Secured Notes Guarantees are secured only by the Collateral. The Notes Collateral Agent’s ability to foreclose on the Collateral on behalf of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes may be subject to perfection and/or priority issues, state law requirements, applicable bankruptcy law, and practical problems associated with the realization of the Notes Collateral Agent’s security interest in or lien on the Collateral, including cure rights, foreclosing on the collateral within the time periods permitted by third parties or prescribed by laws, obtaining third-party consents, making additional filings, statutory rights of redemption and the effect of the order of foreclosure (see also “—The rights of holders of the Senior Secured Notes in some of the Collateral may be _adversely affected by such security interests being second-ranking”). We cannot assure you that the consents of_ any third parties and approvals by governmental entities or courts of competent jurisdiction will be given when required to facilitate a foreclosure on such assets. These requirements may limit the number of potential bidders for certain Collateral in any foreclosure or other auction and may delay any sale, either of which events may have an adverse effect on the sale price of the Collateral. Therefore, we cannot assure you that foreclosure on the Collateral will be sufficient to make all payments on the Senior Secured Notes. -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: State or local national law may limit the ability of the Notes Collateral Agent to foreclose on the real property and improvements included in the Collateral.
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Secured Notes may be secured by, among other things, liens on owned real property and improvements located in several states in the United States or in other jurisdictions. The laws of these states or jurisdictions may limit the ability of the Notes Collateral Agent and the holders of the Senior Secured Notes to foreclose on the real property Collateral located in any of these states or jurisdictions. Applicable laws may impose procedural requirements for foreclosure that are different from and that require a longer time period for completion than the requirements for foreclosure of security interests in personal property. Debtors may have the right to reinstate defaulted debt (even if it is has been accelerated) before the foreclosure date by paying the past due amounts and a right of redemption after foreclosure. Governing laws may also impose security first and “one form of action”rules which can affect the ability to foreclose or the timing of foreclosure on real and personal property collateral regardless of the location of the Collateral and may limit the right to recover a deficiency following a foreclosure. In addition, the holders of the Senior Secured Notes and the Notes Collateral Agent may be limited in their ability to enforce a breach of the lien covenant that will be set forth in the Senior Secured Notes Indenture governing the Senior Secured Notes. See “Description of Senior Secured Notes—Certain Covenants— _Limitation on Liens.” Some decisions of state courts have placed limits on a lender’s ability to accelerate debt_ secured by real property upon breach of covenants prohibiting the creation of certain junior liens or leasehold estates, and a lender may need to demonstrate that enforcement is reasonably necessary to protect against impairment of the lender’s security or to protect against an increased risk of default. Although the foregoing court decisions may have been preempted, at least in part, by certain federal laws, the scope of such preemption, if any, is uncertain. Accordingly, a court could prevent the Senior Secured Notes Trustee and the holders of the Senior Secured Notes from declaring a default and accelerating the notes by reason of a breach of such covenant, which could have a material adverse effect on the ability of holders of the Senior Secured Notes to enforce the covenant.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: Rights in the Collateral may be adversely affected by the failure to perfect security interests in the Collateral
Subsubsection Text: The collateral securing the Senior Secured Notes and the SSN Guarantees will include substantially all of our and the SSN Guarantors’ tangible and intangible assets, whether now owned or acquired or arising in the future. These assets will also secure our and such guarantors’ indebtedness pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. Applicable law requires that a security interest in certain tangible and intangible assets can only be properly perfected and its priority retained through certain actions undertaken by the Notes Collateral Agent. The security interests in the Collateral may not be perfected if we are not able to take the actions necessary to perfect any of these security interests. Our obligation to perfect the security interest for the benefit of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes in specified Collateral is limited and neither the Senior Secured Notes Trustee for the notes nor the Notes Collateral Agent has any duty to take any actions to perfect the security interests. To the extent a security interest in certain Collateral is not properly perfected, such security interest might be avoidable in bankruptcy, which could impact the value of the Collateral. In connection with any Collateral located in the United States, if additional material wholly-owned domestic restricted subsidiaries are formed or acquired and become SSN Guarantors under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, additional financing statements would be required to be filed to perfect the security interest in the assets of such SSN Guarantors. Applicable law requires that certain property and rights acquired after the grant of a general security interest can be perfected only at the time such property and rights are acquired and identified. Depending on the type of the assets constituting such collateral, additional action may be required to perfect the security interest in such assets. Neither the Senior Secured Notes Trustee nor the Notes Collateral Agent will be responsible to monitor, and there can be no assurance that we will inform the Senior Secured Notes Trustee or the Notes Collateral Agent of, the future acquisition of property and rights that constitute Collateral, or that the necessary action will be taken to properly perfect the security interest in such collateral. Neither the Senior Secured Notes Trustee nor the Notes Collateral Agent will be responsible to monitor perfection or take any actions to perfect or maintain the perfection of any security interest. Similarly, the Bank Collateral Agent will have no obligation to monitor the acquisition of additional property or rights that constitute Collateral or the perfection of any security interests therein. Any failure to monitor may result in the loss of the security interest in such collateral or the priority of the security interest in favor of the Senior ----- Secured Notes and the SNN Guarantees against third parties. Even if the Notes Collateral Agent does properly perfect liens on collateral acquired or arising in the future, such liens may potentially be voidable as a preference or otherwise in any bankruptcy proceeding under certain circumstances. The Senior Secured Notes Indenture and the Security Documents entered into in connection with the governing the Senior Secured Notes will not require us to take a number of actions that might improve the perfection or priority of the liens of the Notes Collateral Agent for the benefit of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes. As a result of these limitations, the security interest of the Notes Collateral Agent for the benefit of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes in a portion of the collateral may not be perfected or enforceable (or may be subject to other liens) under applicable law.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: Lien searches may not reveal all liens on the Collateral.
Subsubsection Text: We cannot guarantee that the lien searches on the Collateral that will secure the Senior Secured Notes and the SSN Guarantees will reveal any or all existing liens on such Collateral. Any such existing lien, including undiscovered liens, could be significant, could be prior in ranking to the liens securing the Senior Secured Notes and the SSN Guarantees and could have an adverse effect on the ability of the Notes Collateral Agent to realize or foreclose upon the collateral securing the notes and guarantees thereof.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: The disposal of pledged assets under the laws of certain jurisdictions will be subject to certain statutory restrictions and may be substantially delayed.
Subsubsection Text: Appropriation or direct sale of pledged assets by the pledgee upon the occurrence of an enforcement event is generally not permitted under the laws of certain jurisdictions. As a result, the enforcement of a share pledge governed by the laws of such jurisdictions typically requires the sale of the relevant Collateral through a formal disposal process involving a public or notarial auction or other similar procedures. No assurance can be given that any such disposal process would be successful and any such steps may result in substantial waiting periods, notice requirements, legal costs and expenses that may not be recoverable from the SSN Issuers or through the enforcement of the Collateral. See “Service of Process and Enforcement of Civil _Liabilities,” and “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”_ In addition, upon the foreclosure of a share pledge where not all the share capital is pledged, the remaining shareholders and the company may have pre-emption rights under the laws of certain jurisdictions (although not under English law, as explained below) in the case of private limited liability companies or as set out in the bylaws of the company in the case of both private and public limited liability companies, where applicable, over the shares that are being foreclosed. This may delay the enforcement process or affect the value of the shares. Under English law, the collateral taker may be able to exercise rights of appropriation with respect to financial collateral within the meaning of the Financial Collateral Arrangements (No. 2) Regulations 2003 (the “Financial Collateral Regulations”), which, notably, includes unlisted shares in private companies (unlike many other jurisdictions which have adopted Directive 2002/47/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 6 June 2002 on financial collateral arrangements). Such rights may be exercised provided that (i) the document granting the collateral constitutes a financial collateral arrangement within the meaning of the Financial Collateral Regulations; (ii) the security document expressly includes a power to appropriate the financial collateral; (iii) the collateral taker values the appropriated financial collateral in accordance with the terms of the security document and, in any event, in a commercially reasonable manner; and (iv) there is an overt act by the collateral taker evidencing its intention to exercise the power of appropriation (e.g. by written notice to the collateral-provider). More generally, pledged assets may be sold by the pledgee as a mortgagee in possession, a receiver appointed under the relevant security documents or an administrator without the need for a public or notarial auction or other similar procedures (although subject to certain legal duties and other safeguards). See also “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests _and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations” for a summary of the appointment and role of receivers under_ English law.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Senior Secured Notes
Subsubsection Title: There are circumstances other than repayment or discharge of the Senior Secured Notes under which the Collateral securing the Senior Secured Notes and the SSN Guarantees will be released automatically, without your consent or the consent of the Notes Collateral Agent.
Subsubsection Text: Under various circumstances, the Collateral and the SSN Guarantees will be released automatically, including: ----- - upon a sale, transfer or other disposition of such Collateral in a transaction not prohibited under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture; - with respect to property and other assets of a SSN Guarantor that constitutes Collateral, upon the release of such guarantor from its relevant guarantee in accordance with the Senior Secured Notes Indenture; - with respect to Collateral that is capital stock, upon (i) the dissolution or liquidation of the issuer of that capital stock that is not prohibited by the Senior Secured Notes Indenture, or (ii) upon the designation of such issuer of capital stock as an unrestricted subsidiary under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture; - with respect to any Collateral that becomes an “Excluded Asset” (as defined in “Description of the Senior Secured Notes”), upon it becoming an Excluded Asset; - to the extent the liens on the Collateral securing obligations pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement are released (other than any release by, or as a result of, payment of the obligations under the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement), upon the release of such liens; and - in connection with any enforcement action taken by the Controlling Collateral Agent in accordance with the terms of the Equal Priority Intercreditor Agreement. Such release of the Collateral will not require the consent of holders of the Senior Secured Notes or the consent of the Notes Collateral Agent. The aggregate value of the Collateral that will secure the Senior Secured Notes will be reduced to the extent of the value of the released Collateral. The value of any released Collateral could be significant and there can be no assurance that the value of the remaining Collateral (if any) would be sufficient to satisfy all obligations owed by us to holders of the Senior Secured Notes and the holders of any additional secured indebtedness that ranks equal and ratable with the Senior Secured Notes with respect to such remaining Collateral, including the lenders under the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Senior Notes
Subsubsection Title: The right of the holders of the Senior Notes to receive payment under the SUN Guarantees is contractually subordinated to senior ranking debt of the Guarantors.
Subsubsection Text: The obligations of the SUN Guarantors in relation to the Senior Notes are general senior obligations of the SUN Guarantors and will be contractually subordinated in right of payment to the prior payment in full of all existing and future obligations in respect of senior ranking debt of the SUN Guarantors. Such debt includes the SSN Guarantees or, in the case of the SSN Issuers, their obligations under the Senior Secured Notes, as well as the obligations pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. Although the Senior Notes Indenture will contain restrictions on the ability of the SUN Guarantors to incur additional debt, any additional debt incurred may be substantial and may rank senior to the Guarantees in respect of the Senior Notes. Upon any payment or distribution to creditors of a SUN Guarantor under the Senior Notes Indenture in respect of an insolvency event, the holders of senior ranking debt of such SUN Guarantor will be entitled to be paid in full from the assets of such SUN Guarantor before any payment may be made pursuant to such SUN Guarantees. Until the senior ranking debt of such SUN Guarantor is paid in full, any distribution to which holders of the Senior Notes would be entitled shall be made to holders of senior ranking debt of such SUN Guarantor as their interests may appear. As a result, in the event of insolvency of a SUN Guarantor, under the Senior Notes Indenture, holders of senior ranking debt of such SUN Guarantor may recover more, ratably, than the holders of Senior Notes in respect of such SUN Guarantor’s SUN Guarantee. The Senior Notes Indenture will also provide that, except under very limited circumstances, only the Senior Notes Trustee will have standing to bring an enforcement action in respect of the Senior Notes and the SUN Guarantees. Moreover, the Senior Notes Indenture will restrict the rights of holders of the Senior Notes to initiate insolvency proceedings or take legal actions against each of the SUN Guarantors under the Senior Notes Indenture, and by accepting any Senior Note, each such holder will be deemed to have agreed to these restrictions. As a result of these restrictions, holders of the Senior Notes will have limited remedies and recourse under the SUN Guarantees in the event of a default by the SUN Issuers or a SUN Guarantor under the Senior Notes Indenture (for further details, please see the section entitled “Description of the Senior _Notes—Ranking”)._ -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsection Title: Risks Relating to the Senior Notes
Subsubsection Title: Upon issuance on the Issue Date, the Senior Notes will be unsecured and only guaranteed by the Issue Date Guarantors.
Subsubsection Text: The Senior Notes will be unsecured. Furthermore, on the Issue Date, the Senior Notes will only be obligations of the SUN Issuers and the Issue Date Guarantors and will not be guaranteed by the Post-Closing Guarantors. Within 120 days from the Issue Date, the Senior Notes will be guaranteed by the Post-Closing Guarantors. There can be no assurance, however, that we will be successful in procuring such Guarantees in respect of the Senior Notes within the time periods specified, the failure of which would result in an “event of default” under the Senior Notes Indenture.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Each of the Issuers is a finance subsidiary that has no revenue-generating operations of its own and will be dependent on cash flows from certain intercompany loan notes or other payments or distributions from the Group to service the relevant series of Notes.
Subsubsection Text: None of the Issuers has any subsidiaries or revenue-generating operations of its own and no material assets other than its respective rights and claims under the Notes and pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement, as further described under “Summary—Corporate Structure.” The Issuers’ ability to make payments pursuant to the respective Notes and Guarantees is therefore dependent on the interest or other payments they receive from the operating subsidiaries. If, for whatever reason, such payments are not sufficient, for example, in the event that any withholding taxes are imposed, or otherwise deducted by the relevant borrower, in respect of any payments, the Issuers may not have other sources of funds available to them such that would permit them to make payments pursuant to the relevant Notes and will be dependent upon the cash flow from the Group in the form of intercompany loans or other distributions or payments to make payments pursuant to the Notes. In addition, HGH Finance and HGH Midco 3 Limited, which are the direct parent companies of the SUN Issuers and the SSN Issuers, respectively, are holding companies and have no revenue-generating operations of their own and no material assets other than the equity interests in their respective subsidiaries. Therefore, their ability to make direct or indirect payments or other distributions to the Issuers will be subject to the availability of profits or funds for such purpose which, in turn, will depend on the future performance of the Group which, to a certain extent, is subject to general economic, financial, competitive, legislative (including with respect to taxation), regulatory and other factors that may be beyond their control, and on the ability of the relevant Group companies to pay dividends or make other payments or distributions to HGH Finance and HGH Midco 3 Limited. In addition, certain of our subsidiaries may be or become subject to restrictions on the payment of dividends or the making of other distributions to their respective parent companies (including HGH Finance and HGH Midco 3 Limited) or the Issuers pursuant to their financing arrangements, and such financing arrangements may actually prohibit the ability of these subsidiaries to otherwise move cash within the restricted group. There can be no assurance that our subsidiaries will generate sufficient profits or cash flow from operations or that alternative sources of financing will be available at any time in an amount sufficient to enable these subsidiaries to service their indebtedness and to fund their other liquidity needs and also make payments to the Issuers to allow the Issuers to meet all payment obligations under the Notes. In such circumstances, holders of either series of Notes would have to rely upon their respective claims for payment under the relevant Guarantees and, as applicable, enforcement of the security interest over the Collateral, which are subject to the risks and limitations described herein. See also “—The Guarantees of the _Notes and the Collateral securing the Senior Secured Notes will be subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability.”_ In addition, financial assistance or corporate benefit restrictions may further prevent upstream loans, dividends or other distributions being made, directly or indirectly, to the relevant Guarantors by the Group subsidiaries to enable them to service their respective obligations to the Issuers, as applicable, and the Issuers to service their respective obligations under the Notes (or the Guarantors under the relevant Guarantees, as applicable). In particular, the ability of the Group subsidiaries to pay dividends will generally be limited to the amount of distributable reserves available to each of them and the ability to pay their debt when due. Although the Indentures limit the ability of the Group subsidiaries to enter into future consensual restrictions on their ability to pay dividends and make other payments to the Issuers and the Guarantors, there are significant ----- qualifications and exceptions to these limitations. For instance, goodwill impairment and other non-cash charges in our profit or loss account, as well as charges recognized directly in equity, if incurred, could potentially reduce our subsidiaries’ reserves available for distribution and thus reduce or prevent upstream dividend payments directly or indirectly to the Issuers.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: The Notes will be structurally subordinated to the indebtedness or obligations of non-Guarantor subsidiaries.
Subsubsection Text: Not all of our subsidiaries will guarantee the Notes and the Notes will be structurally subordinated to the future liabilities of the Group subsidiaries (other than the SSN Issuers or the SUN Issuers, as the case may be) that are not, or do not become, Guarantors and to the liabilities of any Guarantor to the extent that such liabilities exceed the principal amount of the relevant series of Notes that can be guaranteed or secured by such Guarantor. Generally, claims of creditors, including depositors, trade creditors and preferred stockholders (if any), of non-Guarantor subsidiaries of the Group, including the Post-Closing Guarantors prior to the granting of the Post-Closing Guarantees, are entitled to payments of their claims from the assets of such subsidiaries before these assets are made available for distribution to their respective parent entity or the creditors of the Issuers or any Guarantor, as the case may be. Accordingly, in the event that any nonGuarantor subsidiary, including the Post-Closing Guarantors prior to the granting of the Post-Closing Guarantees, becomes insolvent, is liquidated, reorganized or dissolved or is otherwise wound up other than as part of a solvent transaction: - the creditors of the Issuers or any Guarantor, as the case may be, including the holders of the Notes, will have no right to proceed against the assets of such non-Guarantor subsidiary; and - creditors of such subsidiary, including depositors, trade creditors and preferred stockholders (if any) will generally be entitled to payment in full from the sale or other disposal of the assets of such subsidiary before the Issuers or any Guarantor, as a direct or indirect shareholder (as applicable), will be entitled to receive any distributions from such subsidiary. Based on the relevant calculation method in the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement, we estimate that the Guarantors accounted for approximately 70% of our EBITDA for the year ended September 30, 2023. As of September 30, 2023, as adjusted to give effect to the Transactions, non-Guarantor subsidiaries had £107 million of third-party debt outstanding, none of which was secured over the Collateral, and £180.9 million of lease liabilities. In addition, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, the Notes will share the Guarantees with lenders under the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement. Furthermore, the Indentures will, subject to certain limitations, permit the Issuers, HGH Finance and their respective subsidiaries, including subsidiaries that are not Guarantors, to incur substantial additional indebtedness without such incurrence constituting a default under the Indentures, and such indebtedness may also be secured. See “—Our substantial leverage and significant _debt service obligations could adversely affect our financial condition and our ability to fulfill our obligations and operate our business.” The lenders under the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement have the discretion to_ release any guarantors in a variety of circumstances, which will cause those guarantors to be released from their guarantees of the Senior Notes and the Senior Secured Notes and the liens on the Collateral in favor of the holders of the Senior Secured Notes to automatically be released.
