While any obligations pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement remain outstanding, any Guarantee of the Notes may be released without action by, or consent of, any holder of the Notes, the Senior Notes Trustee or the Senior Secured Notes Trustee, as applicable, under the Indentures, at the discretion of lenders under the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement, if the relevant Guarantor is no longer a guarantor of obligations pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement or any other indebtedness (other than in connection with a repayment in full of the New Credit Facilities or Refinanced Facilities). See “Description of the Senior Notes,” “Description of the Senior Secured Notes” and “Description of Other _Indebtedness.” The lenders under the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement have the discretion to release_ guarantees in a variety of circumstances. You will not have a claim as a creditor against any subsidiary that is no longer a Guarantor of the Notes, and the indebtedness and other liabilities, including trade payables of those subsidiaries will effectively be senior to claims of the holders of the Notes. In addition, in connection with the Senior Secured Notes, the liens on the assets of any such subsidiary that is released as a guarantor will automatically be released without the consent of any holder of the Senior Secured Notes or the Senior Secured Notes Trustee. -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: The Guarantees of the Notes and the Collateral securing the Senior Secured Notes will be subject to certain limitations on enforcement and may be limited by applicable law or subject to certain defenses that may limit their validity and enforceability.
Subsubsection Text: Enforcement of any of the Guarantees against any Guarantor or security interest against any security provider will be subject to certain defenses available to Guarantors or security providers in the relevant jurisdiction. Although laws differ among these jurisdictions, these laws and defenses generally include those that relate to corporate purpose or benefit, fraudulent conveyance or transfer, voidable preference, insolvency or bankruptcy challenges, financial assistance, preservation of share capital, thin capitalization, capital maintenance or similar laws, regulations or defenses affecting the rights of creditors generally. See “Limitations on Validity and _Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.” If one_ or more of these laws and defenses are applicable, a Guarantor or security provider may have no liability or decreased liability under its Guarantee or security interest depending on the amounts of its other obligations and applicable law. Limitations on the enforceability of judgments obtained in New York courts in such jurisdictions could limit the enforceability of any Guarantee against any Guarantor or of the Collateral against any security provider. Although laws differ among various jurisdictions, in general, under bankruptcy or insolvency law and other laws, a court could (i) avoid or invalidate all or a portion of a Guarantor’s or security provider’s obligations under its Guarantee or security interest, (ii) direct that the holders of the relevant series of Notes return any amounts paid under a Guarantee or security interest to the relevant Guarantor or security provider or to a fund for the benefit of the Guarantor’s or security provider’s creditors or (iii) take other action that is detrimental to you, typically if the court found that: - the relevant Guarantee or security interest was incurred with actual intent to give preference to one creditor over another, hinder, delay or defraud creditors or shareholders of the Guarantor or security provider or, in certain jurisdictions, when the granting of the Guarantee or security interest has the effect of giving a creditor a preference or the creditor was aware that the Guarantor or security provider was insolvent when the relevant Guarantee or security interest was given; - the Guarantor or security provider did not receive fair consideration or reasonably equivalent value or corporate benefit for the relevant Guarantee or security interest and the Guarantor or security provider was: (i) insolvent or rendered insolvent because of the relevant Guarantee or security interest; (ii) undercapitalized or became undercapitalized because of the relevant Guarantee or security interest; or (iii) intended to incur, or believed that it would incur, indebtedness beyond its ability to pay at maturity; - the relevant Guarantee or security interest was held to exceed the corporate objectives of the Guarantor or security provider or not to be in the best interest or for the corporate benefit of the Guarantor or security provider; - the amount paid or payable under the relevant Guarantee or security interest was in excess of the maximum amount permitted under applicable law; or - the amount of the Guarantee or security interest would exceed the amount of distributable funds available for distribution to the shareholders of the Guarantor or security provider. These or similar laws may also apply to any future guarantee or security interest granted by any of our subsidiaries pursuant to the Indentures, as applicable. See “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the _Guarantees and the Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”_ We cannot assure you which standard a court would apply in determining whether a Guarantor was “insolvent” at the relevant time or that, regardless of method of valuation, a court would not determine that a Guarantor was insolvent on that date, or that a court would not determine, regardless of whether or not a Guarantor was insolvent on the date its Guarantee was issued, that payments to holders of the Notes constituted preferences, fraudulent transfers or conveyances on other grounds. The liability of each Guarantor under its Guarantee or security provider under the relevant Security Document, will be limited to the amount that will result in such Guarantee or security interest not constituting a preference, fraudulent conveyance or improper corporate distribution or otherwise being set aside. However, there can be no assurance as to what standard a court will apply in making a determination of the maximum liability of each Guarantor or security ----- provider. There is a possibility that the entire Guarantee or security interest may be set aside, in which case the entire liability may be extinguished. If a court decided that a Guarantee or security interest was a preference, fraudulent transfer or conveyance and voided such Guarantee or security interest, or held it unenforceable for any other reason, you may cease to have any claim in respect of the relevant Guarantor or security provider and would be a creditor solely of the relevant Issuer and of any other Guarantor or security provider under the relevant Guarantee or security interest which has not been declared void. In the event that any Guarantee or security interest is invalid or unenforceable, in whole or in part, or to the extent the agreed limitation of the Guarantee or security interest obligations apply, the Notes would be effectively subordinated to all liabilities of the applicable Guarantor or security provider.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: The insolvency laws of England and Wales may not be as favorable as insolvency laws in other jurisdictions.
Subsubsection Text: HGH Finance, HGH Midco 3 Limited and the UK Issuers are incorporated under the laws of England and Wales, the US Co-Issuers are incorporated under the laws of Delaware, and the Shared Guarantors are incorporated under the laws of certain other jurisdictions. In the event that the Issuers, the Guarantors, any third-party security providers or any other subsidiaries of HGH Finance experienced financial difficulty, it is not possible to predict with certainty in which jurisdiction or jurisdictions insolvency or similar proceedings would be commenced, or the outcome of such proceedings. Any enforcement of the Guarantees or security after bankruptcy or an insolvency event will be subject to the insolvency laws of the relevant entity’s jurisdiction of organization or other jurisdictions. The insolvency and other laws of England and Wales and other applicable jurisdictions may be materially different from, or in conflict with, U.S. bankruptcy laws, including in the areas of rights of secured and other creditors, the ability to void preferential transfers, priority of governmental and other creditors, ability to recover post-petition interest and duration of the proceeding. The application of these laws, or any conflict among them, could call into question whether any particular jurisdiction’s laws should apply, adversely affect your ability to enforce your rights under the Guarantees or the Collateral in these jurisdictions and limit any amounts that you may receive. For more information, see “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests and Certain Insolvency _Law Considerations.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Transfers of the Notes are restricted, which may adversely affect the value of the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes are being offered and sold pursuant to an exemption from registration under the Securities Act and applicable state securities laws of the United States. The Notes have not been, and will not be, registered under the Securities Act or any U.S. state securities laws. Therefore, you may not transfer or sell the Notes in the United States except pursuant to an exemption from, or a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the Securities Act and applicable state securities laws, or pursuant to an effective registration statement, and you may be required to bear the risk of your investment in the Notes for an indefinite period of time. The Notes and the Indentures will contain provisions that restrict the Notes from being offered, sold or otherwise transferred except pursuant to the exemptions available pursuant to Rule 144A and Regulation S, or other exemptions under the Securities Act. In addition, the Notes will not be made available in denominations less than $200,000. Furthermore, the Issuers have not registered the Notes under any other country’s securities laws. It is your obligation to ensure that your offers and sales of the Notes within the United States and other countries comply with applicable securities laws. See “Book-Entry, Delivery and Form—Transfers” and “Notice _to Prospective US Investors.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Additional Senior Secured Notes or Additional Senior Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S may not be fungible with Senior Secured Notes or Senior Notes, as applicable, for U.S. federal income tax purposes.
Subsubsection Text: Additional Senior Secured Notes or Additional Senior Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S from time to time may be issued with the same ISIN, Common Code, CUSIP or other securities identification number as the applicable series of notes previously issued under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture or the Senior Notes Indenture, as applicable, without being fungible with such series of notes for U.S. federal income tax purposes. If you are a U.S. holder (as defined in “Certain Tax Considerations—Certain United States Federal Income Tax _Considerations”) considering the purchase of Senior Secured Notes or Senior Notes sold pursuant to_ Regulation S as part of this offering of Senior Secured Notes and Senior Notes or in the secondary market, you should consult your tax advisors concerning the particular U.S. federal income tax consequences to you of the purchase, ownership and disposition of such series of Notes, including with respect to the potential ----- issuance of Additional Senior Secured Notes or Additional Senior Notes that are not fungible with the applicable series of initial notes issued under the Senior Secured Notes Indenture or the Senior Notes Indenture, as applicable, for U.S. federal income tax purposes, but which nevertheless are not capable of being separately identified. In the event Additional Senior Secured Notes or Additional Senior Notes are issued pursuant to Regulation S that bear the same ISIN, Common Code, CUSIP or other securities identification number as Senior Secured Notes or Senior Notes, as applicable, belonging to the same series previously issued, without being fungible with such series of initial Senior Secured Notes or Senior Notes, as applicable, for U.S. federal income tax purposes, Book-Entry Interests in the relevant Regulation S Global Notes that form part of that series, including in respect of investors that hold Book-Entry Interests in such Regulation S Global Notes on or prior to the date of issuance of such Additional Senior Secured Notes or Additional Senior Notes, as applicable, will not be eligible for transfer to Book-Entry Interests in a 144A Global Note (if any) representing Senior Secured Notes or Senior Notes, as applicable, of that same series. Such a restriction could adversely impact the liquidity of sales of Book-Entry Interests in the relevant Regulation S Global Notes. See “Book_Entry, Delivery and Form—Transfers,” “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Additional Notes” and _“Description of the Senior Notes—Additional Notes.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: The Notes are or will initially be held in book-entry form, and therefore you must rely on the procedures of the relevant clearing systems to exercise any rights and remedies.
Subsubsection Text: Owners of the book-entry interests will not be considered owners or holders of the Notes unless and until Notes in registered definitive form (the “Definitive Notes”) are issued in exchange for book-entry interests. Instead, DTC or its nominee will be the sole holder of the Global Notes representing the Notes. Payments of principal, interest and other amounts owing on or in respect of the Global Notes will be made to the Paying Agent, which will make payments to DTC. Thereafter, such payments will be credited to DTC participants’ accounts that hold book-entry interests in the Global Notes and credited by such participants to indirect participants. After payment to DTC, none of us, the relevant Trustee, the Transfer Agent, the Registrar or the Paying Agent will have any responsibility or liability for any aspect of the records relating to or payments of interest, principal or other amounts to DTC, or to owners of book-entry interests. Accordingly, if you own a book-entry interest, you must rely on the procedures of DTC, and if you are not a participant in DTC, on the procedures of the participant through which you own your interest, to exercise any rights and obligations of a holder of any Notes under the Indentures. Owners of book-entry interests will not have the direct right to act upon our solicitations for consents or requests for waivers or other actions from the holders of the Notes, including enforcement of the Collateral. Instead, if you own a book-entry interest, you will be permitted to act directly only to the extent you have received appropriate proxies to do so from DTC, or, if applicable, from a participant. We cannot assure you that procedures implemented for the granting of such proxies will be sufficient to enable you to vote on any requested actions or to take any other action on a timely basis. See “Book-Entry, Delivery and Form.”

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We cannot assure you that an active trading market will develop for the Notes, in which case your ability to sell the Notes will be limited.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes will be new securities for which there is no market. We cannot assure you as to: - the liquidity of any market that may develop for the Notes; - your ability to sell your Notes; or - the prices at which you would be able to sell your Notes. Future trading prices of the Notes will depend on many factors, including, among others, prevailing interest rates, our operating results and the market for similar securities. Historically, the market for non-investment grade securities has been subject to disruptions that have caused substantial volatility in the prices of securities similar to the Notes. The liquidity of a trading market for the Notes may be adversely affected by a general decline in the market for similar securities and is subject to disruptions that may cause volatility in prices. It is possible that the market for the Notes will be subject to disruptions. Any such disruption may have a negative effect on you, as a holder of the Notes, regardless of our prospects and financial performance. Certain of the Initial Purchasers have advised the Issuers that they currently intend to make a market in the Notes. However, ----- the Initial Purchasers are not obliged to do so, and they may discontinue any market making activities in respect of any series of Notes at any time without notice. As a result, there is no assurance that an active trading market will develop for the Notes. If no active trading market develops, you may not be able to resell your Notes at a fair value, if at all. In addition, recent amendments to Rule 15c2-11 under the Securities Act and regulatory interpretations thereof may restrict the ability of brokers and dealers to publish quotations on the Notes on any interdealer quotation system or other quotation medium after January 4, 2025. Although an application will be made to the Authority for the listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange, we cannot assure you that such permission to deal will be granted or that the Notes will be or remain listed. Although no assurance is made as to the liquidity of the Notes as a result of the admission to trading on the Official List of the Exchange, failure to be approved for listing or the delisting (whether or not for an alternative admission to listing on another stock exchange) of the Notes from the Official List of the Exchange may have a material effect on a holder’s ability to resell the Notes, as applicable, in the secondary market. In addition, the Indentures will allow us to issue additional notes in the future, which could adversely impact the liquidity of the Notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: You may be unable to recover in civil proceedings for U.S. securities laws violations.
Subsubsection Text: Each of the UK Issuers and the majority of the Guarantors are incorporated outside the United States and some of the directors and executive officers of such Issuers and Guarantors are non-residents of the United States and all or a majority of their assets are located outside the United States. As a result, it may not be possible for investors to effect service of process within the United States upon the UK Issuers and such Guarantors or their respective directors and executive officers, or to enforce any judgments obtained in U.S. courts predicated upon civil liability provisions of the U.S. securities laws. Additionally, there is doubt as to the enforceability in many foreign jurisdictions of civil liabilities based on the civil liability provisions of the federal or state securities laws of the United States against ourselves, the Guarantors, the directors, controlling persons and management and any experts named in this Offering Memorandum who are not residents of the United States. See “Service of Process and Enforcement of Civil Liabilities.”

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: The Notes may not become, or remain, listed on the Official List of the Exchange.
Subsubsection Text: Although we will agree in the Senior Secured Notes Indenture and the Senior Notes Indenture to use commercially reasonable efforts to have the Notes listed on the Official List of the Exchange and to maintain such listing as long as the Notes are outstanding, we cannot assure you that the Notes will become or remain listed. If we are unable to or can no longer maintain the listing on the Exchange, we may cease to make or maintain such listing, provided that we will use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain and maintain the listing of the Notes on another “recognized stock exchange,” although there can be no assurance that we will be able to do so. Although no assurance is made as to the liquidity of the Notes as a result of listing on the Exchange or another recognized listing exchange for high yield issuers in accordance with the Indentures, failure to be approved for listing or the delisting of the Notes from the Exchange or another listing exchange in accordance with the Indentures may have a material adverse effect on a holder’s ability to resell Notes in the secondary market. A failure to list or maintain the listing of the Notes may also have adverse tax consequences. See “Certain Tax _Considerations—United Kingdom Tax Considerations.” Under the Indentures, the Issuers will be required to_ gross up payments to investors which are subject to withholding tax, subject to certain exceptions. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Withholding Taxes” and “Description of the Senior Notes— _Withholding Taxes.” In cases where the relevant Issuer is required to gross up payments to a holder of the_ relevant series of Notes, this will reduce the available funds of such Issuer and therefore may reduce the ability of such Issuer to comply with its payment obligations in respect of the relevant series of Notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: We may not have the ability to raise the funds necessary to finance an offer to repurchase the Notes upon the occurrence of a change of control as required by the Indentures, and the change of control provision contained in the Indentures may not necessarily afford you protection in the event of certain important corporate events.
Subsubsection Text: Upon the occurrence of certain events constituting a “change of control” under the Indentures, the Issuers will be required to offer to repurchase all outstanding Notes at a purchase price in cash equal to 101% of the ----- principal amount thereof on the date of purchase plus accrued and unpaid interest to (but not including) the date of repurchase. If a change of control were to occur, we cannot assure you that we would have sufficient funds available at such time, or that we would have sufficient funds to provide to the Issuers to pay the purchase price of the outstanding Notes or that the restrictions in the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement or our other existing contractual obligations would allow us to make such required repurchases. A change of control may also result in a mandatory prepayment pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement and agreements governing any future indebtedness and may result in the acceleration of such indebtedness (even if such change of control pursuant to the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement may be deemed not to be a change of control for the purposes of the Indentures). The ability of the Issuers to receive cash to allow them to pay cash to the holders of the Notes following the occurrence of a change of control may be limited by our then existing financial resources. Sufficient funds may not be available when necessary to make any required repurchases. If an event constituting a change of control occurs at a time when we are prohibited from providing funds to the Issuers for the purpose of repurchasing the Notes, we may seek the consent of the holders or lenders under such indebtedness to the purchase of the Notes or may attempt to refinance the borrowings that contain such prohibition. If such a consent to repay such borrowings is not obtained, the Issuers will remain prohibited from repurchasing any Notes. In addition, we expect that we would require additional financing to make an offer to repurchase the Notes upon the occurrence of a change of control, and we cannot assure you that we would be able to obtain such financing or that such financing would be on acceptable terms. Any failure by any Issuer to offer to repurchase the relevant series of Notes if so required would constitute a default under the relevant Indenture, which could, in turn, constitute a default under the other Indenture, the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement and certain other indebtedness. See “Description of the Senior _Secured Notes—Repurchase at the Option of Holders—Change of Control” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Repurchase at the Option of Holders —Change of Control.”_ The change of control provision contained in the Indentures may not necessarily afford you protection in the event of certain important corporate events, including a reorganization, restructuring, merger, recapitalization or other similar transaction involving us that may adversely affect you, because such corporate events may not involve a shift in voting power or beneficial ownership or, even if they do, may not constitute a “change of control” as defined in the Indentures. Except as described under “Description of the Senior Secured Notes— _Repurchase at the Option of Holders—Change of Control” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Repurchase at the Option of Holders—Change of Control,” the Indentures do not contain provisions that would require_ the Issuers to offer to repurchase or redeem the Notes in the event of a reorganization, restructuring, merger, recapitalization or similar transaction. In addition, in connection with certain tender offers for the Notes, if holders of not less than 90% in aggregate principal amount of the applicable outstanding Notes of the relevant series validly tender and do not withdraw such Notes in such tender offer and the relevant Issuer, or any third-party making such a tender offer in lieu of the relevant Issuer, purchases, all of the Notes of the relevant series validly tendered and not withdrawn by such holders, the relevant Issuer or such third-party will have the right to redeem the Notes of the relevant series that remain outstanding in whole, but not in part, following such purchase at a price equal to the price offered to other holders of Notes of such series. See “Description of the Senior Secured Notes—Optional _Redemption” and “Description of the Senior Notes—Optional Redemption.”_

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: The term “all or substantially all” in the context of a change of control has no clearly established meaning under relevant laws and is subject to judicial interpretation such that it may not be certain that a change of control has occurred or will occur.
Subsubsection Text: The definition of “change of control” in the Indentures will include (with certain exceptions) a disposition of all or substantially all of the assets of HGH Finance and its restricted subsidiaries (taken as a whole), to any person. Although there is a limited body of case law interpreting the phrase “all or substantially all,” it has no clearly established meaning under relevant law, varies according to the facts and circumstances of the subject transaction and is subject to judicial interpretation. Accordingly, in certain circumstances, there may be a degree of uncertainty in ascertaining whether a particular transaction would involve a disposition of “all or substantially all” of the assets of a person, and therefore it may be unclear whether a change of control has occurred and whether the relevant Issuer is required to make an offer to repurchase the Notes. -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Certain of the covenants in the indenture that governs the notes will not apply during any period in which the Notes have Investment Grade Ratings.
Subsubsection Text: Certain of the covenants in the Indentures that govern the Notes will not apply to us during any period in which the Notes have Investment Grade Ratings (as defined in the Indentures), provided at such time no default or event of default has occurred and is continuing. Such covenants restrict, among other things, our ability to pay distributions, incur debt and enter into certain other transactions. There can be no assurance that the Notes will ever have Investment Grade Ratings, or that if they have Investment Grade Ratings, that the Notes will maintain these ratings. However, suspension of these covenants would allow us to engage in certain transactions that would not be permitted while these covenants were in force. To the extent the covenants are subsequently reinstated, any such actions taken while the covenants were suspended would not result in an event of default under the indenture governing the notes. See “Description of Senior Secured _Notes—Certain Covenants” and “Description of Senior Notes—Certain Covenants”._

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: Negative changes in our credit ratings or the credit ratings assigned to the Notes may have a material adverse effect on our financial condition.
Subsubsection Text: The credit ratings assigned to the Notes are an assessment by the relevant rating agencies of our ability to pay our debts when due, which is, in respect of payment obligations under the Notes, dependent upon dividends, other distributions and other payments from our subsidiaries. Consequently, real or anticipated changes in our or the Notes’ credit ratings may generally affect the market value of the Notes. Ratings may not reflect the potential impact of all risks relating to structure, market and additional factors discussed in this Offering Memorandum, and other factors not discussed herein may affect the value of the Notes. A credit rating is not a recommendation to buy, sell or hold securities and may be revised or withdrawn by the rating agency at any time. An explanation of the significance of such rating may be obtained from the applicable rating agency. There is no assurance that such credit ratings will be issued or remain in effect for any given period of time or that such ratings will not be lowered, suspended or withdrawn entirely by the rating agencies, if, in the applicable rating agency’s judgment, circumstances so warrant. It is also possible that such ratings may be lowered in connection with the application of the proceeds of this offering or in connection with future events, such as future acquisitions. Holders of the Notes will have no recourse against us or any other parties in the event of a change in or suspension or withdrawal of such ratings. Any lowering, suspension or withdrawal of such ratings may have an adverse effect on the market price or marketability of the Notes. A downgrade in our credit rating may negatively affect our ability to obtain future financing to fund our operations and capital needs, which may affect our liquidity. It may also increase our financing costs by increasing the interest rates of our outstanding debt or the interest rates at which we are able to refinance existing debt or incur additional debt. Our credit rating may be impacted by a number of factors, including the effects of the economic conditions in the countries in which we operate or may operate in the future and any future rating downgrades of the sovereign debt of these countries, as well as changes in the legal framework or taxation applicable to our activities. Any adverse developments with respect to our credit ratings could have a material adverse impact on our business, financial condition, results of operations and ability to make payments on the Notes and on the trading price of the Notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: If the Notes are redeemed early, an investor may not be able to reinvest such proceeds in a comparable security.
Subsubsection Text: In the event that the Notes are redeemed early in accordance with “Description of the Senior Secured Notes— _Optional Redemption” or “Description of the Senior Notes—Optional Redemption,” as applicable, and_ depending on prevailing market conditions at the time, an investor who receives proceeds due to such an early redemption may not be able to reinvest such proceeds in a comparable security at an effective interest rate as high as that carried by the relevant series of Notes.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: You may face currency exchange risks or adverse tax consequences by investing in the Notes denominated in currencies other than your reference currency.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes are or will be, as applicable, denominated and payable in U.S. dollar. If you are a sterling or other non-U.S. dollar investor, an investment in the Notes will entail foreign exchange related risks due to, among ----- other factors, possible significant changes in the value of the U.S. dollar relative to sterling or other relevant currencies because of economic, political or other factors over which we have no control. Depreciation of the U.S. dollar against the euro, sterling or other relevant currencies could cause a decrease in the effective yield of the Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss to you when the return on the Notes is translated into the currency by reference to which you measure the return on your investments. Investments in the Notes may also have important tax consequences as a result of foreign currency exchange gains or losses, if any.

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Title: The Notes may be issued with original issue discount for U.S. federal income tax purposes.
Subsubsection Text: If the stated principal amount of the Notes exceeds their issue price (as determined for U.S. federal income tax purposes) by an amount equal to or more than a statutorily defined de minimis amount, the Notes will be issued with original issue discount (“OID”) for U.S. federal income tax purposes. In such event, investors in the Notes subject to U.S. federal income taxation generally will be required to include such OID in their gross income for U.S. federal income tax purposes as it accrues, in advance of the receipt of cash payments attributable to such income, using the constant yield method. See “Certain Tax considerations—Certain U.S. _federal income tax considerations—Original issue discount.”_ -----

Section Title: RISK FACTORS
Subsubsection Text: _An investment in the Notes involves a significant degree of risk. You should carefully consider the following risk factors, together with all of the other information included in this Offering Memorandum, before you decide whether to purchase the Notes. The risks and uncertainties described below are not the only risks and uncertainties facing us or related to an investment in our Group. Additional risks and uncertainties not currently known to us or that we currently deem immaterial also may impair our financial condition and business operations. If any of the following risks actually occur, our business’s financial condition and operating results would suffer. The risks discussed below also include forward-looking statements and our actual results may differ substantially from those discussed in those forward-looking statements. See “Cautionary Statement Regarding Forward-Looking Information.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are the largest privately held (re)insurance intermediary by revenue outside of North America and the leading broker in the UK based on geographic footprint and the size of our product portfolio. Our mission is to provide best-in-class retail, specialty and wholesale broking services, reinsurance, risk management and capital markets expertise as well as highly reputable underwriting solutions. We serve clients all over the world with over $38 billion in gross written premiums placed as of September 30, 2023, combining the capabilities of a global brokerage firm with the personalized values of an employee-owned business supported by long term, growth oriented financial partners. Our global headquarters are in London, United Kingdom, and we have offices in more than 50 countries across Europe, Asia Pacific, the Middle East, Africa, the United States and Latin America, combined with a network of partners which enables us to cover over 100 countries and territories globally. We believe that we are one of the few players with an operating model that combines a global platform with strong local presence. Our personal, service-oriented approach, delivered through our office network, branches and digital and online channels, and backed-up by data and analytics, has led to high levels of client satisfaction, driving high retention rates and strong organic growth. In addition to the strong organic growth, we expanded our global network through a selective and disciplined acquisition program investing in likeminded, entrepreneurial insurance businesses. The successful execution of our combined organic growth and acquisition strategy has led to sustained and significant growth. We generated IFRS Revenue of £2,350.6 million, Adjusted Revenue of £2,442.8 million, Loss after tax of £328.8 million, and Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA of £780.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2023, compared with IFRS Revenue of £1,630.4 million, Adjusted Revenue of £1,841.2 million, Loss after tax of £92.1 million, and Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA of £598.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. See “Summary—Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data” for additional details.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key factors affecting results of operations
Subsubsection Title: Fees and Commissions
Subsubsection Text: As a (re)insurance intermediary, we derive our revenue primarily from commission and fees. Our commission income is generally based on insurance premiums and negotiated commission rates, and fees are paid for claims administration or other individual services based on negotiated amounts. We derive a small portion of our commission income from profit commission agreements with our insurers. Profit commissions are typically dependent upon the underwriting profitability of the business placed with the insurer, which is a function of premiums earned less commission paid, claims costs, insurer expenses and the target financial returns for the insurer. We are less able to forecast profit commissions than premium based commissions due to the link with variable insurance events and the inherent volatility this brings. Furthermore, ----- catastrophic events, whether natural or otherwise, can have a significant effect on the number and value of claims being made, and therefore a significant effect on the profitability of the business we place with the insurance company. Changes in profit commissions are largely attributable to economic and market conditions that are outside of our control and that affect premium prices and lead to increases or decreases in overall claims. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to our Business and Industry—We may experience unexpected fluctuations in _our commission income because our commissions depend on premium rates charged by insurance carriers, which we do not control and which historically have varied and are difficult to predict, and we are less able to forecast profit commissions related to our underwriting business than premium-based commissions due to the link with variable insurance events and the inherent volatility this brings, which may negatively impact our business, results of operations and financial condition.”_

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key factors affecting results of operations
Subsubsection Title: Acquisitions
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations during the periods under review have been affected by certain acquisitions which may make it more difficult for investors to evaluate the historical performance of our business by comparing period over period results. Some of our material acquisitions for the three-year period ended September 30, 2023 include the acquisition of A-Plan during the year ended September 30, 2021, Align, Aston Lark and Assiteca during the year ended September 30, 2022 and TigerRisk and March R.S. during the year ended September 30, 2023. See “—Factors Affecting Comparability of Results” below for an explanation of how acquisitions during the periods under review have affected the comparability of our results across these periods. Acquisitions impact our financial position and results of operations in a variety of ways. First, our consolidated results for the period during which an acquisition takes place are affected by the inclusion of the results of the acquired business. As acquired businesses are included in our consolidation perimeter from the date of completion of each relevant acquisition, their full impact is only reflected in our financial statements in the subsequent period. The acquisitions of subsidiaries are accounted for using the acquisition method. The consideration transferred is measured as the fair value of assets given, liabilities incurred or assumed, and equity instruments issued by the Group at the date of exchange. Any costs directly attributable to the business combination are booked to the income statement as incurred. Identifiable assets acquired and liabilities and contingent liabilities assumed, meeting the conditions for recognition under IFRS 3, are recognized at their fair value at the acquisition date, irrespective of the extent of any non-controlling interest. The excess of the consideration transferred over the fair value of the Group’s share of the identifiable net assets acquired is recorded as goodwill. Subsequent changes in the fair value of consideration transferred or identifiable assets, liabilities and contingent liabilities assumed are adjusted where they qualify as measurement period adjustments. The measurement period is the period from the date of acquisition to the date the Group obtains complete information about facts and circumstances that existed as of the acquisition date and is subject to a maximum of one year. All other subsequent changes in the fair value of contingent consideration classified as an asset or liability are accounted for in accordance with the applicable IFRS. For some acquisitions, we have structured acquisitions to include contingent payments, or “earnouts,” to the acquired company’s management team to incentivize them and encourage retention of key employees. These earnouts are generally contingent on maintaining or achieving specified revenue, earnings or other financial performance measures in future periods and range in duration but typically up to three years after the completion date of the acquisition. Other measures to incentivize both growth and retention of key employees in acquisitions are equity incentive schemes put in place post-completion and typically are four or five years in duration. Finally, equity in the form of Howden Group shares issued as consideration to the acquired company’s management forms another key retention strategy given the shares are relatively illiquid and have strict leaver provisions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key factors affecting results of operations
Subsubsection Title: Insurance Cycle
Subsubsection Text: The general insurance cycle is an insurance market phenomenon that is driven by supply of and demand for insurance and can be particularly pronounced in reinsurance and industrial lines insurance. The insurance market cycle is defined as “softening”and “hardening.”“Soft”periods are characterized by falling or stagnant premium rates and are driven normally by excessive supply of capital from insurance companies and other ----- market participants competing for available business. Soft markets on average result in low profitability for the insurers and as a result lower commissions for brokers. In a soft market, insurance buyers in the small- and mid-sized markets tend to reduce deductibles, increase their limits of coverage, and purchase new coverage. “Hard” periods can be precipitated by catastrophes, such as natural disasters, or similar significant losses, for example, severe credit market losses, that result in insurers’ capital becoming depleted or some insurers no longer being able to participate in the market. The lack of capital and decreased competition drives up premium rates, thereby the potential for greater profitability for the remaining insurers. Additionally, catastrophes or similar significant losses may also precipitate increased customer demand for insurance policies, driving demand for capital and further hardening the market. Hard and soft markets may also be affected by broad-based trends or by factors affecting individual insurance product lines or specific geographic areas. From 2016 to 2019, we were in a soft market with retractions in premium rates across the carriers. Beginning in 2019, rates and exposures began to increase and the market continued to harden in certain areas, particularly, catastrophe-exposed property and upper layers of management liability exposure in 2020 and 2021. The market continues to be generally hard though some lines are softening or moderating; however, it is not clear whether the rate and exposure increases will continue into the foreseeable future as economic conditions are difficult to predict.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key factors affecting results of operations
Subsubsection Title: Seasonality
Subsubsection Text: We experience some seasonality in the volumes of (re)insurance policies we place and, consequently, in our commission and fees, as most (re)insurance policies renew on the first day of the year. Like many of our competitors, we have also historically transacted less business in the last quarter of the calendar year than in other months. Accordingly, commission and fees for the first fiscal quarter tend to be slightly lower than the rest of the year. While our aggregate revenue varies from quarter to quarter in part as a function of the foregoing, our compensation expenses, selling expenses, administrative expenses, and depreciation and amortization expenses generally tend to be more uniform throughout the year, with the exception of a step-up in spending following an acquisition. We recognize contingent revenue throughout the year and cash receipts tend to follow close to or shortly after. In the case of some of our business lines, such as treaty reinsurance or DUAL, the cash collection cycle may be longer and varies up to 24 months. Under the terms of our Existing Facilities, we are generally required to make monthly interest and quarterly principal payments on outstanding borrowings. As a result of our principal and interest payment obligations, in general, a significant portion of our total cash flows generated from operations are utilized for debt service.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key factors affecting results of operations
Subsubsection Title: Currency Fluctuations and Hedging
Subsubsection Text: We operate globally and as a result, are exposed to fluctuations in currency exchange rates. This exposure arises where revenue is received in currencies different from the currency of costs. A significant amount of our revenue is denominated in GBP (31% for the year ended September 30, 2023), USD (35% for the year ended September 30, 2023) and EUR (21% for the year ended September 30, 2023), while our costs are incurred in a number of currencies and weighted towards GBP. Therefore the Group generates most of its profits in USD and EUR but is loss-making in GBP. The Group’s debt servicing costs are in USD and EUR and the profits generated in USD and EUR are used to service this debt. While there is a hedging program to buy GBP-sell USD to give some certainty over cash flows, the USD and EUR profits are largely unhedged to act as economic hedge over the Group’s debt leverage given the Group’s debt is largely in USD or EUR. Therefore if the USD/EUR debt fluctuates in value in GBP terms due to foreign exchange, there is a compensating movement in the USD/EUR profits to maintain leverage. Furthermore, as we present our consolidated financial statements in GBP, we are required to translate the assets, liabilities, income and expenses of all operations that use a functional currency other than GBP. We translate into GBP at then-applicable exchange rates, exposing us to translation risk (i.e., the risk that exchange rates will impact the value of our income, assets, liabilities and expenses reported in GBP even if the value has ----- not changed in the underlying currency). Currency translations could significantly affect the comparability of our results between financial periods and could result in significant changes to the carrying value of assets, liabilities and shareholders’ equity.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key factors affecting results of operations
Subsubsection Title: Interest rate risk
Subsubsection Text: As of September 30, 2023, 94% of the Group’s debt bore interest at variable rates. The Existing Facilities bear interest at floating rates of interest per annum equal to EURIBOR or SOFR (LIBOR historically), as applicable, as adjusted periodically, plus a spread. These interest rates could rise significantly in the future and our interest expense would correspondingly increase, thus reducing cash flow. As for September 30, 2023, the Group estimates that, through the combination of the natural hedge and interest rate derivatives (swaps and cap), a weighted average of 67% (2022: 61%, 2021: 36%) of the notional amount of the Existing Term Loans was hedged for the period to March 2024. This further decreases to a weighted average of 66% (2022: 41%, 2021: 18%) of the notional amount of the Existing Term Loans being hedged for the period to March 2025 and 8% for the remaining period to maturity on November 2, 2027.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Key factors affecting results of operations
Subsubsection Text: Our results of operations have been, and may continue to be, affected by the key factors set forth below as well as other factors, many of which are beyond our control. For trends affecting our business and the markets in which we operate, see also “Risk Factors,” “Summary—Our Industry” and “Business.”

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Material acquisitions
Subsubsection Text: The historical financial information presented in this document is affected by the material acquisitions that have changed our scope of consolidation and may make it more difficult for investors to evaluate the historical performance of our business period over period. In addition to these material acquisitions, a number of smaller acquisitions were made which further impacts the year-on-year comparisons. The results of each of these acquisitions and disposals are included in the Financial Statements from the date the relevant transaction was completed and are further detailed in the notes to the Financial Statements. Our Financial Statements for the year ended September 30, 2023 include, among others, the following acquisitions in comparison with the Financial Statements for the year ended September 30, 2022: - 6 months of activity of March R.S., acquired on March 22, 2023 and consolidated into our broking business in Europe. The acquisition of the Spanish insurance broker reflects Howden’s growth strategy in Europe, expanding Howden Iberia’s client offering. Since its acquisition, March R.S. has contributed revenue of £11 million and an Operating Loss of £0.2 million to the Group for the year ended September 30, 2023. - 9 months of activity of TigerRisk Partners, acquired on January 9, 2023, which has since been consolidated into our Howden Tiger division. Since its acquisition, Howden Tiger has contributed revenue of £171.4 million and an Operating profit of £16.1 million to the Group for the year ended September 30, 2023. Our Financial Statements for the year ended September 30, 2022 include, among others, the following acquisitions in comparison with the Financial Statements for the year ended September 30, 2021: - 12 months of activity of Align Financial Holdings LLC and its controlled subsidiaries, acquired on October 1, 2021 and consolidated into our MGA business in the US. Since its acquisition, Align has contributed revenue of £84.3 million and an operating profit of £10.2 million to the Group for the year ended September 30, 2022. - 5 months of activity of the Aston Lark Group, acquired April 21, 2022 and consolidated into our broking business in the UK and Ireland. Since its acquisition, Aston Lark contributed revenue of £91.8 million and an operating profit of £3.7 million to the Group for the year ended September 30, 2022. - 4 months of activity of 93% of the economic interest in Assiteca S.p.A and its controlled subsidiaries, Italy’s third largest brokerage company, acquired on May 6, 2022 and consolidated into our non-UK broking business. Since its acquisition, Assiteca has contributed revenue of £17.8 million and an operating loss of £11.6 million to the Group for the year ended September 30, 2022. ----- If the acquisitions that completed during the fiscal year ended 2021 had been made on October 1, 2020, the consolidated income statement under IFRS for the year ended September 30, 2021 would have reflected revenue of £1,147.9 million and operating profit of £56.8 million. If the acquisitions that completed during the fiscal year ended September 30, 2022 had been made on October 1, 2021, our consolidated income statement under IFRS for the year ended September 30, 2022 would have reflected revenue of £1,843.4 million and operating profit of £220.2 million. If the acquisitions that completed during the fiscal year ended September 30, 2023 had been made on October 1, 2022, our consolidated income statement under IFRS for the year ended September 30, 2023 would have reflected revenue of £2,442.9 million and operating loss of £16.3 million. As a general matter, following an acquisition of a business or group of assets, our results of operations are impacted by the results of the newly acquired business or operations, the purchase accounting for the acquisition, any debt incurred to acquire the business or operations and expenditures made to integrate the newly acquired business or operations.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Financing: Debt Transactions
Subsubsection Text: We have historically financed our M&A activities, capital expenditures, New Initiatives and some share buybacks partly through debt financing. However, our leverage profile has remained largely consistent from a total net leverage ratio of 5.6x as of the year ended December 31, 2022 to 5.1x as of September 30, 2023. Pro forma for the Transactions, we expect that our Ratio of Pro Forma Adjusted Total Net Debt to Pro Forma Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA will decrease to 5.31x.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Financing: Equity Transactions
Subsubsection Text: The Group remains well supported by its institutional investors and has raised close to £1.7 billon of cash equity in the last three years. General Atlantic has been invested for over 9 years and CDPQ for over 6 years. In the year ended September 30, 2023, the Group raised an amount of £300.0 million and, separately, $906.0 million through investor subscriptions for new share capital to support other M&A activity and other growth initiatives. In the same financial year, over 1,800 employee shareholders acquired equity with post-tax income. In the year ended September 30, 2022, institutional shareholders subscribed for £300.0 million of new share capital in support of the acquisition of Aston Lark. In addition, funds from the PIK Notes issuance were injected into the Group as equity totaling £609.1 million. In the year ended September 30, 2021, £415.3 million of net proceeds were raised from a share issuance to Hg. Another £103.5 million was raised in a follow-on offering for a total investment in our Group of £518.8 million.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: 2021 Cash Flow Statement Comparatives
Subsubsection Text: Following the acquisition of all of the subsidiaries and primary operations (other than certain holding company operations) by HGH Finance from HGH Limited, on January 25, 2022, the 2022 Financial Statements represent the continuation of the Group previously consolidated at the level of HGH Limited. The 2022 Financial Statements were prepared on this basis with comparatives presented as if the Group consolidated its financial statements at the level of HGH Finance as at October 1, 2020. As a result of this, the consolidated cash flow statement for the year ended September 30, 2021 presented in this Offering Memorandum presents the HGH Limited consolidated cash flow statement for the year ended September 30, 2021; however, the relevant accounting entries and respective amounts have been restated in accordance with the classification for the year ended September 30, 2022. See “Summary—Summary Historical _Financial Data and Other Information—Consolidated Cash Flow Statement Data.”_ Other than this, there are no other material differences between the financial information of HGH Limited and HGH Finance as consolidating entities. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Fees and commissions
Subsubsection Text: We earn commissions for placing (re)insurance cover. Commission revenue is recognized when earned, which generally is on the effective date of the associated policies when control of the policy transfers to the client. This is usually on the later of the policy commencement date or the placement date of the policy. Where there is uncertainty, such as quota share treaty reinsurance or in the case of profit commissions, an estimate is made and revised as there is more certainty in the outcome. In addition, an estimate is made for future cancellations and mid-term adjustments based on historical data. Commission revenue is recognized net of any wholesale broker commissions and any other third-party deductions such as other commission sharing arrangements. Fee revenue is recognized as services are performed. If there are other services within the contract (e.g., claims administration and/or the provision of payment instalment plans), we estimate the stand-alone price for each separate performance obligation, and the corresponding apportioned revenue is recognized over the period of time which the customer receives the service and as the performance obligations are fulfilled.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Other operating income
Subsubsection Text: Other operating income consists of fees earned on advisory and consulting services and fiduciary income, being interest earned on insurance premiums that are held in a fiduciary capacity, in insurance cash and cash equivalents or insurance investments in money market funds, until disbursed. Advisory services relate to non(re)insurance activity such as employee benefits, mortgage products and capital market advisory.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Insurance income
Subsubsection Text: Insurance income consists of premium received, including any reinstatement premium, from a third-party coverholder, gross of acquisition costs. In 2021 the Group took on insurance risk for the first time in a protected cell company structure to take advantage of insurance market conditions. This activity was ancillary to the Group’s core offering and this retro reinsurance vehicle is now in run-off.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Other Operating costs
Subsubsection Text: Other Operating costs consists of employee costs, selling and administrative expenses, business generation costs, business transformation costs, legacy costs, costs of certain regulatory matters and related redress payments, and costs related to acquisitions and refinancing.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Insurance expense
Subsubsection Text: Insurance contract expenses consist of claims expenses and insurance acquisition costs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Impairment losses on financial assets and/or contract assets
Subsubsection Text: Impairment losses on financial assets and/or contract assets relates to credit adjustments on insurance and trade receivables based on lifetime expected losses, aged insurance and trade receivables balances less than 365 days overdue based on management’s assessment, unless a specific provision has been created.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Depreciation and amortization
Subsubsection Text: Depreciation and amortization charges represent the depreciation of tangible assets and right-of-use assets, and the amortization of intangible assets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Dividend income
Subsubsection Text: Dividend income is recognized when the right to receive payment is established on minority investments held by the Group. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Gain/loss on disposal
Subsubsection Text: Gain/loss on disposal represents gain arising on disposals of operations not qualifying as discontinued operations, calculated as the excess of sale proceeds over the book value of an asset following its disposal.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Finance income
Subsubsection Text: Finance income represents interest income on own cash and cash equivalents and loan receivables, and, in the case of the year ended September 30, 2021, gains arising from a favorable debt modification which will unwind over the life of the underlying debt.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Finance costs
Subsubsection Text: Finance costs represents interest expense on borrowings, unwind of capitalized issuance costs and the aforementioned favorable debt modification on borrowings, unwind of discount on provisions, unwind of discount on financial liabilities (including leases), fair value movements on interest rate derivatives, to which hedge accounting had not been applied, foreign exchange movements on cash, cash equivalents and borrowings, and the reclassification from other comprehensive income of net losses on interest rate derivatives to which hedge accounting has been applied.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Fair value through profit or loss
Subsubsection Text: Fair value through profit or loss represents fair value movements (including unwind of discount) on deferred and contingent consideration arrangements, put options held by non-controlling interests of certain subsidiaries and investments held at fair value through the income statement.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Income tax expense
Subsubsection Text: Income tax expense consists of current and deferred taxes calculated in accordance with the relevant tax laws in force in the jurisdictions in which we operate. As of September 30, 2023, the rate of corporation tax in the UK was 25%. We are also subject to tax rates in the other countries in which we operate, ranging from 12% to 31% as of the same date.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The following is a summary description of certain line items from our income statement. For more information see the notes to the Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.
