Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Year ended September 30, 2023 compared to year ended September 30, 2022
Subsubsection Text: _Fees and commissions_ Fees and commissions increased significantly by £623.3 million, or 40.1%, from £1,555.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to £2,178.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2023. This increase was driven in large part by the impact of acquisitions (being both the post-acquisition results of acquisitions made in the year ended September 30, 2023 (£186.2 million), the largest of which relate to TigerRisk, as well as the impact of acquisitions in the year ended September 30, 2022, the largest of which relates to Aston Lark and Assiteca (£214.0 million)). The £214.0 million represents the increase in Aston Lark and Assiteca revenue and other M&A from 2022 to 2023. The residual increase in fees and commissions relates to growth of other businesses in the Group’s perimeter that had been in existence as at September 30, 2022. _Americas_ Fees and commissions increased in the Americas by £191.2 million or 45.3%, from £421.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to £613.1 million for the year ended September 30, 2023. This was partly due to organic growth through local initiatives, and partly driven by the acquisition of TigerRisk in January 2023 (£136.2 million). The primary drivers of organic growth in the region was due to new business and market conditions. Aside from the acquisition of TigerRisk, there was no other material M&A activity. _UK_ In the UK, fees and commissions increased significantly by £208.8 million or 45.6%, from £458.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to £667 million for the year ended September 30, 2023. The primary driver for this was the impact of Aston Lark results following its acquisition in April 2022, and a number of other acquisitions made in the UK such as Media Insurance Brokers and Reich Group during 2023, which in aggregate totaled £120.6 million. Revenue growth was also driven by good organic growth due to improving market conditions across motor and home insurance products in particular. _Northern Europe_ Northern Europe saw growth of £75.4 million or 30.9% during the year ended September 30, 2023, from £244.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to £319.6 million for the year ended September 30, 2023. This was achieved largely due to investments both through acquisitions made in both 2022 and 2023 and investment in New Initiatives. _Asia_ Asia also experienced growth in fees and commissions, increasing by £19 million or 13.1%, from £145.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to £164.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2023. There were two main drivers for this growth; organic growth in the region and the continued recovery of Howden High Net Worth, the Group’s high net worth business in Asia, which was impacted by the closure of borders in Asia during the Covid-19 global pandemic. ----- _Middle East_ Fees and commissions increased in the Middle East by £9.1 million or 12.3%, from £73.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to £82.8 million for the year ended September 30, 2023. The drivers behind this were organic growth and local initiatives. No acquisitions were made in the region during the year. _Australasia_ Australasia had growth of £22.2 million or 39.7%, from £55.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2022 to £78.1 million for the year ended September 30, 2023. This was primarily driven by an increase in New Initiatives in the region as well as good underwriting conditions for the MGA business. _Southern Europe_ Fees and commissions also saw growth of £93 million or 80.7% in Southern Europe, increasing from £115.3 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to £208.3 million for the year ended September 30, 2023. This was primarily driven by the acquisition of Assiteca in May 2022 and March RS in March 2023 as well as a number of smaller acquisitions across 2022 and 2023. _Eastern Europe_ Eastern Europe experienced growth in the year of £6.6 million or 25.6%, from £25.8 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to £32.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2023. This was because of organic growth in the region due to new business and positive market conditions. M&A activity in Eastern Europe was limited unlike in the other regions. _Africa_ Fees and commissions in Africa decreased by £2 million or 13.3%, from £15 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to £13 million for the year ended September 30, 2023. This was driven by local market conditions in what is the Group’s smallest geography by location of end client. _Other operating income_ Other operating income increased significantly by £102.5 million, or 148.1%, from £69.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to £171.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2023. This increase was driven by fiduciary income arising from increasing interest rates (£31.3 million) and an expansion in non-insurance placement activities such as mortgage and real estate advisory following the acquisition of SPF in August 2022, capital advisory services following the acquisition of TigerRisk in January 2023 and premium financing arrangements. _Insurance income_ Insurance income decreased by £5.6 million, or 93.3%, from £6 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to £0.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2023. The decrease was driven by the timing of premium recognition over the period of underlying cover of policies, which had expired by September 30, 2022, with some reinstatement premiums recognized in the year ended September 30, 2023. _Other operating costs_ Other operating costs increased by £753.8 million, or 60.3%, from £1,249.3 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to £2,003.1 million for the year ended September 30, 2023. The increase in operating costs was due to the enlarged footprint of the business following a number of acquisitions, the largest of which were Aston Lark and Assiteca in 2022 and TigerRisk in 2023 with an overall impact of £358.4 million from the annualization of M&A for the year ended September 30, 2022 and the impact of M&A for the year ended September 30, 2023. Within operating costs there was also a change in net foreign exchange loss of £76.0 million. Finally, there continues to be strong investment in New Initiatives largely relating to headcount ----- and set-up costs, integration of M&A and other Group investment programs, which all contributed to an increase in other operating costs. See “—Key income statement items”for further detail in relation to operating costs. _Insurance expense_ Insurance expense decreased by £13.7 million, or 137.0%, from a charge of £10 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to £3.7 million gain for the year ended September 30, 2023. This was due to a downward revision in the expected ultimate claims settlement. _Impairment losses on financial assets and/or contract assets_ Impairment losses on financial assets and/or contract assets decreased by £4.8 million, or 55.2%, from £8.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to £3.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2023. The movement between September 30, 2021 and September 30, 2022 was impacted by heightened risk of credit risk arising from global economic conditions as a consequence of rising interest rates, inflationary pressures, the Russia-Ukraine conflict and other political developments. However the change in credit risk profile between September 30, 2022 and September 30, 2023 was not as significant as in the prior year. _Depreciation and amortization_ Depreciation and amortization expense increased by £211.8 million, or 120.3%, from £176 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to £387.8 million for the year ended September 30, 2023. This increase in the expense was driven by the amortization of acquired intangibles from acquisitions both in the current year and in the prior year as well as £127.7 million accelerated amortization of acquired brand assets which were rebranded to one global Howden brand on October 1, 2023. _Dividend income_ Dividend income increased by £1.2 million, or 300%, from £0.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to £1.6 million for the year ended September 30, 2023. This was driven by the underlying performance and timing of dividends of minority equity investments. _Gain/loss on disposal_ Gain on disposal increased by £3.8 million, or 1,900%, from £0.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2022 to £4 million for the year ended September 30, 2023. This was driven by the disposal of certain non-core operations. _Finance income_ Finance income increased significantly, by £17.1 million, or 462.2%, from £3.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to £20.8 million for the year ended September 30, 2023 due to increased interest returns on cash holdings and investments in money market funds arising from rising interest rate environment. _Finance costs_ Finance costs increased significantly by £75.9 million, or 30.1%, from £252.3 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to £328.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2023. This increase is driven by the increase in interest rates and the increase in borrowings to fund the Group’s expansion plans, which increased by £826.8 million for the year ended September 30, 2023, to £4,534.5 million, from £3,707.7 million as at September 30, 2022. In addition, the relative strengthening of the GBP since September 2022 due to market conditions drove an £95.3 million gain in the foreign exchange gains on USD and EUR denominated borrowings when translated back to GBP, which partially offset the increase in finance costs. _Fair value through profit or loss_ Fair value through profit or loss increased by £12.6 million, or 59.7%, from £21.1 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to £33.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2023. The increase was due to upward revaluation of contingent consideration and put option on non-controlling interests due to improved forecasts. ----- _Income tax expense_ Income tax expense decreased significantly by £56.6 million, or 602.1%, from a charge of £9.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, to a £47.2 million gain for the year ended September 30, 2023. This was driven by a net release of deferred tax liabilities. The deferred tax movements relate to release of deferred tax liabilities on intangible assets as these are amortized and other short term timing differences. _Loss after tax from continuing operations_ Loss after tax from continuing operations was £328.8 million for the year ended September 30, 2023, compared to £92.1 million for the year ended September 30, 2022.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Year ended September 30, 2022 compared to year ended September 30, 2021
Subsubsection Text: _Fees and commissions_ Fees and commissions increased significantly by £557.5 million, or 55.9%, from £997.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £1,555.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. This increase was driven in large part by the impact of acquisitions (being both the post-acquisition results of acquisitions made in the year ended September 30, 2022 (£209.8 million)), the largest of which relate to Align, Aston Lark and Assiteca, as well as the impact of acquisitions in the year ended September 30, 2021, the largest of which relates to A-Plan (£111.6 million in revenue contribution for the period under consideration). The residual increase in fees and commissions relate to organic growth of other businesses in the Group’s perimeter that had been in existence as at September 30, 2021. _Americas_ Fees and commissions increased in the Americas by £167.1 million, or 65.6%, from £254.8 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £421.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. This was partly due to local initiatives, and partly driven by the acquisition of Align in October 2022 (£84.3 million). The primary drivers of organic growth in the region were due to new business and market conditions. Aside from the acquisition of Align, there was no other material M&A activity. _UK_ In the UK, fees and commissions increased significantly by £206.5 million, or 82%, from £251.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £458.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. The primary driver for this was the impact of A-Plan results following its acquisition in March 2021, and the acquisition of Aston Lark in April 2022. _Northern Europe_ Fees and commissions in Northern Europe increased by £52.8 million, or 27.6%, from £191.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £244.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. This was achieved through local European initiatives. _Asia_ Asia also experienced growth in fees and commissions, increasing by £34.2 million, or 30.8%, from £111 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £145.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. The two main drivers for this growth were general growth in the region and, secondly, the recovery of Howden Private Wealth (formerly known as IPG), the Group’s high net worth business in Asia, which was impacted by the closure of borders in Asia following the Covid-19 global pandemic. _Middle East_ Fees and commissions increased in the Middle East by £18.4 million, or 33.3%, from £55.3 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £73.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. The drivers behind this were local initiatives. No acquisitions were made in the region during the year. ----- _Australasia_ Fees and commissions in Australia increased by £12.3 million, or 28.2%, from £43.6 million for the year ended September 30, 2021 to £55.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. This was primarily driven by an increase in New Initiatives in the region. _Southern Europe_ Fees and commissions in Southern Europe increased by £54.7 million, or 90.3%, from £60.6 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £115.3 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. This was primarily driven by the acquisition of Assiteca in May 2022. _Eastern Europe_ Fees and commissions in Eastern Europe experienced growth in the year of £5 million, or 24%, from £20.8 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £25.8 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. Performance in the region grew purely from new business and market conditions, as there was little M&A activity unlike in certain other regions. _Africa_ Fees and commissions in Africa increased by £6.5 million, or 76.5%, from £8.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £15 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. This was due to improvement of business in the region caused by new business and market conditions. _Other operating income_ Other operating income increased significantly by £27.7 million, or 66.7%, from £41.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £69.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. This increase was driven by growth and an expansion in non-insurance placement activities such as insurance comparison related products and mortgage and real estate advisory. _Insurance income_ Insurance income increased by £1.4 million, or 30.4%, from £4.6 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £6 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. This increase was driven by the timing of premium recognition over the period of underlying cover of policies. _Other operating costs_ Other operating costs increased by £374.1 million, or 42.7%, from £875.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £1.2 billion for the year ended September 30, 2022. The increase in operating costs was due to the enlarged footprint of the business following a number of acquisitions, the largest of which were A-plan in 2021 and Align, Aston Lark and Assiteca in 2022, as a result of which our headcount increased and costs associated with New Initiatives and M&A activities also increased. In addition, these acquisitions led to a ramp-up of the Group’s need for back office support, which had an overall impact of £253.3 million from the annualization of M&A for the year end September 30, 2021 and the impact of M&A for the year ended September 30, 2022. See “—Key income statement items” for further detail in relation to operating costs. _Insurance expense_ Insurance expense decreased slightly by £0.3 million, or 2.9%, from £10.3 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £10 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. Insurance expense has been broadly flat year-on-year; however, a downward change in claim movements accounted for the small decline during the year ended September 30, 2022. _Impairment losses on financial assets and/or contract assets_ Impairment losses on financial assets and/or contract assets increased significantly by £7.9 million, or 987.5%, from £0.8 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £8.7 million for the year ended September 30, ----- 2022 as a result of the increased size of the Group. In addition, there was a heightened risk of credit risk arising from global economic conditions as a consequence of rising interest rates, inflationary pressures, the Russia-Ukraine conflict and other political developments. _Depreciation and amortization_ Depreciation and amortization increased by £75.8 million, or 75.6%, from £100.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £176 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. This increase in the Group’s depreciation and amortization expense was driven by the amortization of acquired intangibles from acquisitions both in the current year and in the prior year. _Dividend income_ Dividend income decreased by £0.2 million, or 33.3%, from £0.6 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £0.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. This is driven by the underlying performance and timing of dividends of minority equity investments. _Gain on disposal_ Gain on disposal stayed largely consistent throughout the period under review and there were no material disposals during the periods under review. _Finance income_ Finance income decreased significantly by £52 million, or 93.4%, from £55.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £3.7 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, as a result of a one-off gain of £53.5 million arising in the year end September 30, 2021 due to a favorable debt modification of the Existing Term Loans to reduce the interest charge and extend the tenor of the borrowings. _Finance costs_ Finance costs increased significantly by £178.2 million, or 240.5%, from £74.1 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £252.3 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. This increase was driven by a £2,127.2 million increase in borrowings to fund the Group’s expansion plans. In addition, the relative weakening of the GBP in September 2022 due to market conditions drove an increase of £98.8 million in the foreign exchange losses on USD and EUR denominated borrowings when translated back to GBP. _Fair value through profit or loss_ Fair value through profit or loss decreased significantly by £12.5 million, or 37.2%, from £33.6 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £21.1 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. This decrease was driven by the change in equity structure of the group following the acquisition of all the subsidiaries and operations from HGH Limited by HGH Finance and the restated comparatives. _Income tax expense_ Income tax expense decreased significantly by £17.6 million, or 65.2%, from £27 million for the year ended September 30, 2021, to £9.4 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. This decrease was driven by an increased current tax charge of £13.2 million due to an underlying increase in trading profits, offset by deferred tax movements of £30.8 million. The deferred tax movements relate to release of deferred tax liabilities on intangible assets as these are amortized and other short term timing differences. _Loss after tax from continuing operations_ Loss after tax from continuing operations was £92.1 million for the year ended September 30, 2022, compared to £20.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The following is a discussion of our cash flow from operations, cash flow from investing activities and cash flow from financing activities for the periods under review. ----- In our primary business activity as a (re)insurance intermediary, we handle significant amounts of fiduciary cash that is collected from customers and passed on to insurers. Movements in such fiduciary cash balances are included in the cash flow under IFRS reporting, thus reflected below. Cash flows from operating activities correspond to loss after tax, plus income tax expense, plus fair value through profit and loss, less movement due to foreign exchange, plus acquisitions costs, less dividend income, plus net finance costs, plus depreciation and amortization, plus share based payments, plus goodwill and intangible assets impairment, plus employee services post business combination, less the gain on sale of subsidiaries and other non-current assets, adjusted for the increase or decrease in the following assets and liabilities: non-current trade and other receivables, insurance investments, insurance receivables, current other receivables accrued income and prepayments, cost of fulfillment asset, insurance payables, current trade and other payables, deferred income, non-current trade and other payables, provisions, and insurance underwriting balance. Cash flows from investing activities correspond to purchases of property, plant and equipment and intangibles assets, investment in subsidiaries (net of acquired cash, associates and joint ventures), issue/repayment of loan receivables, proceeds from disposal of operations, purchase or disposal of investments held at fair value through profit and loss, dividend income and transactions with equity holders (largely the issuance of loans to employee shareholders of the HGH Limited). Cash flows from financing activities correspond to fluctuations from borrowings, proceeds from issue of share capital, acquisition of non-controlling interests, dividends payable to non-controlling shareholders, financing derivatives, transactions with former equity holders (funding of share buybacks of HGH Limited), lease principal repayments and settlement of deferred consideration obligations. The following table presents a summary of our cash flow for the years ended September 30, 2021, 2022 and 2023. Please note that certain line items in the consolidated cash flow statement for the year ended September 30, 2021 have been restated in the consolidated financial statements of HGH Limited and HGH Finance for the year ended September 30, 2022. Such restated amounts have therefore been extracted from the unaudited comparative column in the HGH Limited financial statements for the year ended September 30, 2022, such figures also being consistent with the equivalent figures in the 2022 Financial Statements. The restated line items within the restated consolidated cash flow statement for the year ended September 30, 2021 have not been audited by Deloitte LLP.

Subsubsection Title: Net cash generated from operating activities
Subsubsection Text: The net cash inflow from operating activities decreased by £157.1 million to £7.4 million in the year ended September 30, 2023 from £164.5 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. The decrease was due to interest costs, which increased by £152.7 million due the rising interest rate environment and an increase in borrowings raised during the year to fund corporate activities such as acquisitions and investment in New Initiatives. The investment in New Initiatives also consumed cash while the relevant books of business were built. The net cash inflow from operating activities decreased by £33.7 million to £164.5 million in the year ended September 30, 2022 from £198.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2021 (restated). The decrease was ----- due to interest costs, which increased by £111.6 million due to an increase in borrowings raised during the year to fund corporate activities such as acquisitions and investment in New Initiatives, partly offset by an increase in cash from operations. This movement includes the impact of the presentation reclassification of two line items, which together accounts for a decrease of £23.4 million in cash from operating activities. Specifically, acquisition costs were reclassified from investing activities to operating activities, contributing to a £26.3 million decrease of cash inflow from operating activities from September 30, 2021. The settlement of deferred consideration obligations and acquisition of NCI which have service obligations was also reclassified from financing activities to operating activities and contributed to £2.9 million decrease in cash outflow in 2022.

Subsubsection Title: Net cash used in investing activities
Subsubsection Text: The net cash outflow from investing activities increased by £93.3 million to £1,241 million in the year ended September 30, 2023 from £1,147.7 million in the year ended September 30, 2022. The increase was due to a net increase in investment in financial instruments of £165.5 million, which are largely money market funds not classified as cash and cash equivalents under IFRS and an increase of £35.7 million investment in property, plant and equipment and intangible assets due to the various Group transformational IT programs in front end trading systems and general increase in the size of the Group. These were partially offset by a net reduction of £118.6 million spend on acquisition of subsidiaries, net of cash acquired. The net cash outflow from investing activities increased significantly by £858.1 million to £1,147.7 million in the year ended September 30, 2022 from £289.6 million in the year ended September 30, 2021 (restated). The increase was primarily due to increased acquisition activity in the year led by Aston Lark Group (cash consideration of £654 million) and Align (cash consideration of £377.8 million) along with a number of smaller M&A. This movement includes the impact of the reclassification of two line items which together accounts for a net movement of £25.7 million decrease in the cash outflow from investing activities. Acquisition costs were reclassified from investing activities to operating activities, contributing to a £26.3 million decrease of cash outflow from investing activities from September 30, 2021. Loans granted were reclassified from financing activities to investing activities, contributing to a £0.6 million increase in cash outflow from September 30, 2021.

Subsubsection Title: Net cash generated from financing activities
Subsubsection Text: The net cash inflow from financing activities decreased by £29.4 million to £1,654.2 million in the year ended September 30, 2023 from £1,683.6 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. The decrease was due to a mix of financing activities—a decrease in inflows from external borrowings by £133.7 million, an increase in outflows from settlement of deferred consideration by £56.8 million, partially offset by an increase in inflows from equity raised by £133.4 million. The net cash inflow from financing activities increased significantly by £1,393.5 million to £1,683.6 million in the year ended September 30, 2022 from £290.1 million for the year ended September 30, 2021 (restated). The increase was due to an increase in bank borrowings which increased by £1,452.3 million and £493.8 million of proceeds from the issue of share capital to fund corporate activities such as acquisitions and investment in New Initiatives. Loans granted was reclassified from financing activities to investing activities, contributing to a £0.6 million increase in cash outflow from September 30, 2021.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity describes the availability of liquid resources and ability of a company to generate sufficient cash flows to meet the cash requirements of its business operations, including working capital needs, capital expenditure, debt service obligations, other commitments, contractual obligations and acquisitions. As of September 30, 2023, our unrestricted own cash and cash equivalents (net of bank overdrafts) and debt proceeds held in cash or money market funds, amounted to £817.8 million. Our restricted cash balances of ----- £139.3 million as of September 30, 2023 (including £31.9 million investment in money market funds) pertains to £81.1 million of cash and money market funds held in the retro reinsurance cells in our Guernsey vehicles and £58.2 million held in entities locally for regulatory reasons and to satisfy orderly wind down obligations. We do not expect such restrictions on cash to impact the overall liquidity of the Group; restricted cash; for the avoidance of doubt, restricted cash is not included in any calculations of net debt, net leverage or similar credit metrics. In addition, there is £630 million of capacity under our New Revolving Credit Facility, £75 million of which was drawn subsequent to September 30, 2023 for short-term working capital purposes but intended to be repaid shortly following the Issue Date. The Board monitors the forecast levels of borrowings and leverage ratios to ensure it remains within its risk appetite. The Group also has a number of put options granted to several non-controlling shareholders and key senior management in relation to their minority shareholding. If one or more put options were exercised, we would be required to fund a payment in cash to the relevant option holder in accordance with the relevant agreement. In such circumstances, depending on the amount, the payments may be made in several installments over a period in order to preserve liquidity. In 2023, the Group drew an additional £1,000 million of fresh equity from its institutional investors to fund M&A and expansion plans. This follows over £700 million of fresh equity from its institutional investors in the preceding two years. We currently have, and, following the completion of the Transactions, will continue to have, substantial debt. After giving effect to the Transactions as of September 30, 2023, our Total Debt is expected to amount to £5,603 million. After giving effect to the Transactions, the Group’s main borrowings mature in 2030 to 2033 and will be refinanced at an appropriate time in the future. We expect that, following the completion of the Transactions, our primary sources of cash will be cash flows from operating activities and cash balances and borrowings under our debt facilities, including the New Credit Facilities and the Notes. We anticipate continued support from our Sponsors in the form of additional equity funding to maintain the Group’s leverage and risk profile within sustainable parameters. Historically, our principal uses of cash have been, and we expect that they will continue to be, operating expenses, working capital requirements, capital expenditures, acquisitions and costs related to New Initiatives, integration costs and deferred consideration arrangements, and debt service payments. Although we believe that our expected cash flows from operating activities, together with available borrowings will be adequate to meet our anticipated general liquidity needs and debt service obligations, we cannot assure you that our business will generate sufficient cash flows from operations to meet these needs or that future debt or equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to fund our liquidity needs, including making payments on the Notes or other debt when due. If our cash flows from operating activities are lower than expected or our capital expenditure requirements exceed our projections, we may be required to seek additional financing, whether equity or debt, which may not be available on commercially reasonable terms, if at all. Our ability to arrange financing generally and our cost of capital depends on numerous factors, including general economic conditions, the availability of credit from banks, other financial institutions, and capital markets, restrictions in instruments governing our debt, and our general financial performance. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes—Our Substantial Leverage and Debt Service Obligations Could _Adversely Affect Our Business and Prevent Us from Fulfilling Our Obligations With Respect to the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral.”_ We believe that, based on our current level of operations, our cash on hand, cash flows from operating activities and the availability of borrowings under the New Revolving Credit Facility will be sufficient to fund our operating expenses, capital expenditures and debt service payments for at least the next twelve months.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: As of September 30, 2023, the Group’s financial liabilities includes borrowings, lease liabilities, trade and other payables totaling £7,488.1 million (2022: £5,983.4 million, 2021: £3,076.6 million) of which insurance payables comprised £1,923.4 million (2022: £1,460.5 million, 2021: £978 million). As at September 30, 2023 there is also contingent consideration, minority put option and financial derivatives totaling £242.1 million (2022: £265.1 million, 2021: £206.3 million) put options in respect of minority interests and Group shares and ----- derivative financial instruments. The future commitments include earn-outs due on recent acquisitions and the future liability on put options. The table below summarizes our contractual obligations as of September 30, 2023, including interest but excluding utilization fees, unamortized transaction costs and other accrued interest expenses and financial liabilities related to our put options. The table does not reflect amounts that may be drawn under the New Revolving Credit Facility, interest thereon, and any utilization fees payable thereunder.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s primary areas of capital expenditure include purchase and construction of property, plant & equipment; internally generated assets and research & development; and purchase of intangible assets. Total capital expenditures for the year ended September 30, 2023 were £108.2 million (2022: £72.5 million, 2021: £47.6 million). We expect our capital expenditures for the next 12 months to be broadly in line with the year ended September 30, 2023 due to continued investment plans to support the growth objectives of the Group. Incremental capital expenditures are subject to approval by the Board.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Information Regarding Market and Operating Risks
Subsubsection Title: Credit Risk
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s principal financial assets exposed to credit risk are insurance receivables, trade and other receivables. The amounts presented in the statement of financial position are net of allowances for doubtful receivables. An allowance for impairment is made where there is an identified loss event which, based on previous experience, is evidence of a reduction in the recoverability of cash flows. The Group has no significant concentration of credit risk, with exposure spread over a large number of counterparties and clients. The credit risk on liquid funds and derivative financial instruments is limited as the counterparties are the Group’s bankers with high credit ratings assigned by international credit rating agencies. In respect of managing credit risk arising over trade and other receivables, the subsidiaries across the Group maintain credit control teams as appropriate to manage the credit risk and in some business units, a variable element of remuneration of employees is linked to cash collection. The Group applies the lifetime credit risk model to insurance receivables. The Group monitors the ageing of insurance receivables based on whether it is current or not and days past due. Management provides for all balances more than 365 days overdue and for all remaining balances a provision for impairment losses on financial assets and/or contract assets is created based on prior experience of bad debt unless a specific provision is created due to there being an identified loss. An example of an event triggering a specific provision for impairment losses on financial assets and/or contract assets would be a counterparty in known distressed financial situation. The main input in determining ----- the lifetime credit loss is the average historical bad debt experience rate based typically over the last three years. The Group applies the 12 month credit loss model to other receivables unless there has been a significant increase in credit risk. The main input is the likelihood of a default occurring in the next 12 months based on past experience and current market conditions given the majority of the other receivables are due within 12 months. The total expected credit loss provision on insurance receivables as of September 30, 2023 was £23.3 million (2022: £21.6 million, 2021: £12.4 million). The increase is predominantly driven from net additional recognition of provision following recoverability review as well as the overall increase in size of Group driven by acquisitions and organic growth. The bad debt expense recognized in respect of insurance and trade receivables as of September 30, 2023 was £3.9 million (2022: £8.7 million, 2021: £0.8 million).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Information Regarding Market and Operating Risks
Subsubsection Title: Interest Rate Risk
Subsubsection Text: The Group’s exposure to interest rate risk is on the interest payable on the Group’s variable rate borrowings, including overdrafts, and interest receivables on banking deposits held in the ordinary course of business. As a result, the Group is subject to a certain degree of interest rate risk due to fluctuations in the prevailing levels of market interest rates. The Group is not subject to interest rate risk in relation to the fixed rate borrowings. The exposure for the Group, as at September 30, 2023, of financial assets and financial liabilities to interest rate risk is shown by reference to floating interest rates (i.e. giving cash flow interest rate risk) when the interest rate is due to be re-set and fixed interest rates (i.e. giving fair value interest rate risk) when the financial instrument is due for repayment. The Group’s largest exposure to interest rate risk relates to the Existing Dollar Term Loans where the USD portion has interest payable based on SOFR (LIBOR historically) and the EUR portion has interest payable based on EURIBOR. While there is a partial natural hedge with USD and EUR denominated insurance cash and investments earning floating SOFR (LIBOR historically) or EURIBOR interest, the Group has entered into interest rate swaps and interest rate caps to manage the interest rate risk. It is estimated that through the combination of the natural hedge and interest rate derivatives (swaps and cap), a weighted average of 67% (2022: 61%, 2021: 36%) of the notional amount of the Existing Term Loans are hedged for the period to March 2024. This further decreases to a weighted average of 66% (2022: 41%, 2021: 18%) of the notional amount of the Existing Term Loans hedged for the period to March 2025 and to 50% (2022: 8%) for the remaining period to November 2027. The total fair value of the interest rate swaps and caps was £73.7 million as at September 30, 2023, of which £56.4 million was recorded in current derivative financial instrument assets and £17.3 million was recorded in non-current derivative financial instrument assets. The total fair value of the interest rate swaps was £81.9 million as at September 30, 2022, of which £42.2 million was recorded in current derivative financial instrument assets, £42 million was recorded in non-current derivative financial instrument assets and £2.3 million was recorded in non-current derivative financial instrument liabilities. The interest swaps and the intrinsic portion of the interest rate caps have been designated as hedging instruments in cash flow hedges on inception of the hedging instruments. The swaps and caps are recognized and measured at fair value on our consolidated statement of financial position, with fair value movements on the swaps and intrinsic portion of the caps are recognized in the cash flow hedge reserve via the consolidated statement of comprehensive income, as long as the requirements for hedge accounting are met and are effective. Amounts are recycled from the cash flow hedge reserve as and when the hedged forecast transaction occurs. Fair value movements in relation to time value of the interest rate caps are recognized in the cost of hedging reserve and amortized into the consolidated income statement over the life of the instrument. Historically, some interest rate hedges have been terminated as they no longer met the risk management objectives due to mismatch between variable interest rate risk and hedging instrument or an economic relationship was no longer able to be demonstrated between the hedged item and hedging instruments. On termination date, the balance in cash flow hedging reserve is recycled over the remaining life of the derivative ----- as the underlying forecast transaction is still expected to occur and the changes in fair value of the derivative is recorded in the consolidated income statement. For the year ended September 30, 2023, a loss of £6.6 million (2022: £74.9 million gain, 2021: £2.3 million loss) excluding tax was recognized in other comprehensive income. A gain of £37.6 million (2022: £7.7 million loss, 2021: £11.1 million loss) was recycled from equity to profit and loss. A total gain of £3.6 million (2022: gain of £17.6 million, 2021: loss of £0.6 million) was recognized in finance costs from hedge ineffectiveness arising from credit risk and changes in fair value of swaps, where the hedging relationship has been terminated. A 50 basis points change in reference interest rates did not have a material impact for the years under review. In respect of LIBOR transition, all tranches of the Group’s Existing Dollar Term Loans and Second Lien Facility, which had USD LIBOR as the reference rate have transitioned to Synthetic US Dollar LIBOR as at September 30, 2023. Interest rate derivatives, which had USD LIBOR on the floating rate of the swap have been amended to be based on Term SOFR plus the ISDA credit adjustment (“ISDA CAS”) or Compound SOFR plus ISDA CAS. Synthetic LIBOR will cease to be published on September 30, 2024 and further transition will be required.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Information Regarding Market and Operating Risks
Subsubsection Title: Insurance risk
Subsubsection Text: The three key components of insurance risk are underwriting, reinsurance and reserving. - Underwriting: Poor claims experience could lead to larger losses than anticipated. The Group has issued reinsurance to a third party coverholder providing capacity to a retrocessional binder, with the coverholder delegating underwriting authority to a subsidiary of the Group. The retro binder covers a range of risks where there are detailed historical records over claims; however, there is no certainty the claims pattern will repeat for the future. This detailed dataset, allied with a subsidiary of the Group having delegated underwriting authority helps ensure the quality of underwriting despite the Group not previously taking on insurance risk. The Group’s losses are limited to the collateral placed for the reinsurance contract. Scenarios were modelled based on catastrophe models, which evaluate expected results over a significant timeframe and not for any one year. Based on these models, it is anticipated that there is a 2% chance for the complete exhaustion of collateral when the cover was issued. - Reinsurance: As this is the first time the Group has taken on balance sheet risk and the low risk of complete utilization of collateral, no reinsurance has been taken. Once there is sufficient certainty over the claims development, reinsurance may be considered to effectively lock in performance and minimize deterioration of results. - Reserving: Reserving risk arises where insurance liabilities are insufficient. To manage this risk, actuarial analysis is deployed to project the ultimate claims ratio as well monitoring for claims made and incurred claims but not yet reported on a regular basis. Reserving exercises include expert input from the underwriter and independently from actuarial resources within the Group, with additional external review where appropriate. The selected reserves were within a range of possible outcomes from known, specific events considered with potential to result in higher or lower total claims to be paid. The upper and lower bounds or the range would have increased/ decreased the claims liability by £19.0 million and £11.8 million respectively. For claims made, it is anticipated that the amount and timing of claims payments is typically resolved within three years.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Information Regarding Market and Operating Risks
Subsubsection Title: Foreign currency risk
Subsubsection Text: Foreign exchange risk arises where a subsidiary’s assets, liabilities, income and expenses are denominated in currencies other than the subsidiary’s functional currency. The Group’s policy is to: align the Existing Facilities’ servicing costs in USD/EUR and operating profits in USD/EUR and monitor, and where appropriate, to hedge foreign currency transaction exposures. For the latter, this is most prevalent in certain subsidiaries where the costs are largely denominated in GBP but revenue is earned in a number of foreign currencies. In this situation, foreign exchange contracts to sell foreign currencies and buy GBP can be entered into to cover a proportion of the forecast foreign currency receipts. The amount forward sold is considered based on amounts after debt servicing in currency and acceptable impact on leverage for extreme movements in foreign exchange. ----- In the current and prior year, the Group entered into a series of foreign exchange forwards to buy GBP-sell USD to hedge foreign exchange risk arising in a GBP functional currency subsidiary which had USD income. These forwards were designated as hedging instruments in a cash flow hedge to hedge the foreign exchange risk arising from the revenue recognition and subsequent arising receivable. As at September 30, 2023, some of these forwards with a carrying value of £0.2 million had not yet expired. In addition, the Group designated a portion of the EUR Term Loan and USD Term loan as hedging instruments in net investment hedges of EUR and USD foreign operations. The hedging instruments were recorded in non-current borrowings. The hedged risk is the foreign exchange risk arising on the value of the Group’s net investment in assets and liabilities in USD and EUR functional currency entities. The net gain or loss under this arrangement is recognized in other comprehensive income. The fair value changes and net effect on other comprehensive income in the year ended September 30, 2023 was a loss of £31.6 million (2022: £56.5 million gain, 2021: £9.9 million gain).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Provisions
Subsubsection Text: The Group is involved from time to time in the ordinary course of business in certain claims and legal proceedings relating to the Group’s operations, including employee related matters. Judgement is exercised over whether the recognition criteria of IAS 37 have been met, particularly when legal proceedings have commenced but a court hearing or trial is a number of years away.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Recognition of internally generated assets
Subsubsection Text: Judgement is exercised over when the IAS 38 recognition criteria for internally generated intangible assets have been met, Howden Group Services and in the trading divisions in enhancing the Group’s IT capabilities and reporting, as well as implementation costs for cloud based software solutions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Control assessment of non-wholly owned subsidiaries
Subsubsection Text: The Group has a number of non-wholly owned subsidiaries. For these subsidiaries, the rights of the relevant non-controlling interests and of the Group are set out in shareholders’ agreements. Judgement is exercised over assessing whether the rights of the non-controlling interests are protective in nature or not. Where rights are assessed to be protective in nature, they do not prevent the Group controlling and consolidating the entity.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The Board has made judgements and estimates that affect the application of the Group’s accounting policies and reported amounts on the carrying amounts of assets, liabilities and income statement for the year ended September 30, 2023.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Macro-economic, geo-political and global events
Subsubsection Text: Future forecasts feed into a number of areas such as going concern review, impairment review and the valuation of customer relationships and brands arising on acquisition. In forming these forecasts, considerations are made over the impact of global inflationary pressures, monetary policy tightening, the ongoing military conflict in Ukraine, the recent events in the Middle East and the potential regional instability resulting from these events, and trade tensions between the United States and China. Accordingly, these are key sources of estimation uncertainty when forecasting the impact on our clients, general insurance market and economic backdrop. See sections below for more analysis on: (i) fair value of customer relationships and brands on acquisition; (ii) impairment of assets; and (iii) contingent consideration and put options.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Fair value on acquisition
Subsubsection Text: Customer relationships and brands are measured at fair value on acquisition with number of key assumptions including forecasts, client retention rate, economic life of the intangible assets and discount rates to use. The ----- Group uses the 12 month hindsight period to reassess whether these assumptions were appropriate or whether further information has emerged over conditions as at acquisition date. Intangible assets recognized on acquisition as of September 30, 2023 was £740.2 million (2022: £759.0 million, 2021: £270.2 million) for the most recent period. A reasonable change to assumptions and estimates used in determining the recognition of assets would have resulted in assets being recognized in the range of £666.2 million to £814.2 million.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Impairment of assets
Subsubsection Text: In the annual impairment review of goodwill, the recoverable value is determined using board approved forecasts, long-term growth rate beyond the approved forecast period, operating margins, discount rates and trading multiples. Results of the sensitivity analysis are shown in note 12 to the Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Contingent consideration and put options
Subsubsection Text: The carrying value of consideration and put options depend on future performance and are therefore reliant on the accuracy of forecasts and discount rates to be applied. Arrangements which mature a number of years later, uses long dated forecasts are inherently less likely to be accurate than near term forecasts. As at September 30, 2023, these had a carrying value of £242.1 million (2022: £253.0 million, 2021: £140.7 million) and disclosure of sensitivity analysis applied to the carrying value of contingent consideration and put options is the notes to the Financial Statements.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Provisions
Subsubsection Text: As set out in the notes to the Financial Statements, a total legal provision of £84.7 million (2022: £46.6 million, 2021: £32.5 million) relating to various matters has been recognized based on our analysis of most likely outcomes and amounts due in worst case scenarios following consultation with internal and external legal counsel. In the worst case scenarios, the amounts claimed by the third parties are in excess of £84.7 million. Following the year-end, payments totaling £56.5 million have been made to finalize matters that were provided in full at the year-end. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Below are considered the estimates which have the most impact on the carrying value of assets and liabilities as at September 30, 2023. The estimates which have most risk of material adjustment to the carrying value of assets and liabilities in the next financial year relate to contingent consideration and put options, insurance accounting and provisions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We are the largest privately held (re)insurance intermediary by revenue outside of North America and the leading broker in the UK based on geographic footprint and the size of our product portfolio. Our mission is to provide best-in-class retail, specialty and wholesale broking services, reinsurance, risk management and capital markets expertise as well as highly reputable underwriting solutions. We serve clients all over the world with over $38 billion in gross written premiums placed as of September 30, 2023, combining the capabilities of a global brokerage firm with the personalized values of an employee-owned business supported by long term, growth oriented financial partners. Our global headquarters are in London, United Kingdom, and we have offices in more than 50 countries across Europe, Asia Pacific, the Middle East, Africa, the United States and Latin America, combined with a network of partners which enables us to cover over 100 countries and territories globally. We believe that we are one of the few players with an operating model that combines a global platform with strong local presence. Our personal, service-oriented approach, delivered through our office network, branches and digital and online channels, and backed-up by data and analytics, has led to high levels of client satisfaction, driving high retention rates and strong organic growth. In addition to the strong organic growth, we expanded our global network through a selective and disciplined acquisition program investing in likeminded, entrepreneurial insurance businesses. The successful execution of our combined organic growth and acquisition strategy has led to sustained and significant growth. We generated IFRS Revenue of £2,350.6 million, Adjusted Revenue of £2,442.8 million, Loss after tax of £328.8 million, and Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA of £780.2 million for the year ended September 30, 2023, compared with IFRS Revenue of £1,630.4 million, Adjusted Revenue of £1,841.2 million, Loss after tax of £92.1 million, and Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA of £598.9 million for the year ended September 30, 2022. See “Summary—Summary Historical Financial Information and Other Data” for additional details.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Insurance Distribution Value Chain
Subsubsection Text: The insurance industry comprises the following functions: Retail Brokers:_ They assist clients, including individuals, businesses, and public institutions, to identify their insurance needs and secure appropriate insurance policies. The broking process involves negotiating policy terms and placing the client’s risk with a suitable insurer, either directly or via an underwriting agency or a wholesale broker. Wholesale Brokers:_ They function as intermediaries between retail brokers and insurance carriers, typically in specialty lines of insurance. Wholesale brokers focus on the more complex or high-risk coverage areas and typically do not have direct contact with the insured, and instead provide access to insurance carriers and ----- products that a retail broker might otherwise not have. In some cases, wholesale brokers also serve as intermediaries between underwriting agencies and insurance carriers. Reinsurance Brokers:_ They facilitate the transfer of risk from an insurance carrier to a reinsurer, aiding in the diversification and management of the insurer’s risk exposure. Underwriting Agencies:_ They serve as intermediaries between insurance companies and brokers or customers. These agencies may act as MGAs, which issue and administer policies, handle claims, and oversee renewals on behalf of insurance companies. They carry out most of the traditional insurer activities, including underwriting and pricing, except for providing capital and incurring liabilities for claims. Their performance is measured by underwriting results. Their profitability may also be influenced by “loss-sharing” agreements with insurance companies, which are contingent on the agencies’ underwriting performance. The diagram below illustrates the entire insurance distribution value chain:

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Key Products

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: We provide retail insurance brokerage, wholesale insurance brokerage, reinsurance brokerage, and Managing General Agency (“MGA”) services as well as advisory and consulting service to businesses, individuals and insurance carriers across the world. We assist our clients in devising appropriate risk mitigation strategies through insurance products and enable the placement of insurance policies with insurance carriers and reinsurers. We do not assume underwriting risk for the insurance policies we assist in placing and the compensation model for our services typically involves commissions based on premium levels or fees for services rendered. Consequently, the performance of the insurance brokerage sector is dependent on the economic performance of the broader insurance and reinsurance markets, reflected in the premiums placed. The volume of premiums placed is dependent on the insurance rates and the underlying amount of coverage purchased. The amount of coverage purchased is typically correlated to the overall GDP level and macroeconomic factors underlying each specific client industry and/or risk class. Insurance rates are cyclical in nature and vary between “hard”markets, where premium rates are increasing, and “soft”markets, where rates are declining.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: P&C insurance encompasses a wide array of coverage options tailored to meet diverse commercial needs. It is generally categorized into traditional P&C and specialty lines. Traditional P&C lines include coverage for commercial property, general commercial liability, workers’ compensation, and other products that provide broad protection against common risks faced by businesses in various sectors. Specialty line products are tailored to mitigate risks faced in specific industries, such as natural resources, marine, energy, fleet, real estate, and construction, as well as complex functional risks, including cyber, financial lines, professional indemnity, directors and officers. Specialty lines also include transactional lines, which are designed to mitigate risks in business transactions, particularly in mergers and acquisitions, with products such as warranty and indemnity insurance, tax liability insurance, litigation buyout insurance, and contingent liability insurance.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: The personal lines sector of the insurance market caters to individuals, providing a range of non-life insurance products. This includes general coverage options such as accident and health, household, motor, travel, and personal accident insurance. Additionally, the market also addresses the needs of niche segments or individuals with unique risk profiles through specialist non-life insurance products, which cater to specific interests or higher-value assets such as jewelry, art, and vintage cars.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Advisory and Consulting Services
Subsubsection Text: Advisory and consulting services offer specialized expertise in employee benefits, mortgage products and capital market advisory. These services include comprehensive advice in real estate and mortgage advisory, as well as strategic advice in mergers and acquisitions, capital raising, and insurance-linked securities for insurance carriers and insurance service companies. Employee benefits brokers and consultants provide businesses with access to medical, life, and disability insurance, along with retirement planning services. They advise on plan design and offer single-source solutions for program management and administration, allowing businesses, especially in the middle market, to outsource these functions effectively.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Reinsurance products help insurance underwriters, including carriers and MGAs, by securing protection from another insurer. It is designed to redistribute risk, thereby assisting insurers in managing large-scale claim ----- liabilities. It is primarily categorized into treaty reinsurance and facultative reinsurance. Treaty reinsurance involves comprehensive agreements covering a broad range of risks under long-term contracts, offering consistent risk management over extended periods. Facultative reinsurance is tailored to specific, individual risks, providing customized solutions through detailed underwriting on a case-by-case basis.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: A leading player in a large and resilient market
Subsubsection Text: Enduring demand for insurance products within both corporate and individual sectors, partially driven by regulatory imperatives, coupled with continued growth and increasing complexity of risks makes the insurance sector a large and resilient end market. As illustrated in the chart below, the P&C insurance market is large with $869 billion of direct premiums written in 2022, and has displayed resilience amidst economic fluctuations, growing at a CAGR of 4.4% from 1996 to 2022, with only two years of negative year-over-year growth. Notably, during the COVID-19 pandemic, the sector experienced a 9.5% annual growth rate. Source: S&P Global Market Intelligence We are the largest privately held (re)insurance intermediary by revenue outside of North America, having placed over $38 billion in written premiums annually as of September 30, 2023. Our global presence encompasses offices across 50 countries, and in collaboration with our Howden One network, we maintain an extensive service network spanning over 100 countries and territories. In the growing insurance market, our market position has increased over time. According to AM Best, our rank improved from the 10[th] to the 6[th] largest private insurance intermediary by revenue between 2018 and 2022. We are at the forefront in the markets and sectors that we service, recognized as one of the largest MGAs outside North America, the number one independent broker in the London market, and the fourth-largest global reinsurance broker. ----- Source: AM Best

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Independent with high employee ownership and entrepreneurial culture, attracting top industry talent
Subsubsection Text: Employee ownership has remained a fundamental pillar of our corporate ethos since our inception three decades ago, under the leadership of our founder David Howden. This entrepreneurial spirit and people-first approach have been instrumental in fostering a vibrant corporate culture. Out of a total workforce of approximately 15,500 individuals, about 4,500 employees are shareholders, and around 2,600 of them participate in equity incentive schemes. Together, they hold approximately one-third of the Group’s equity, establishing our workforce as the largest and most significant shareholder group. Attracting, nurturing, and retaining high-caliber talent is a core aspect of our operational strategy, resulting in a high producer retention rate. Our commitment to employee equity ownership has played a pivotal role in attracting and retaining industry-leading professionals. As of September 30, 2023, our team has grown to around 15,500 individuals across 50 countries. We successfully on-boarded a significant number of employees in New Initiatives in recent years, totaling approximately 1,120 employees in New Initiatives as at September 30,2023. They made up approximately 30% of the Group’s Organic Revenue Growth for the year ended September 30, 2023, contributing about 4% to the Group’s Organic Revenue Growth of 13% Growth in this period.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Robust Organic Revenue Growth outperforming listed peers in recent years
Subsubsection Text: Over several years, we have consistently delivered high Organic Revenue Growth, driven by our entrepreneurial culture, industry and product specialisms, presence in high growth markets, strategic hiring of talented insurance professionals, cross-selling within our existing client base, and strong relationships with insurance carrier. This has led to a consistent outperformance versus our listed peers, underpinned by the success of our non-transactional business and New Initiatives. For example, for the years ended September 30, 2021, 2022 and 2023, our Organic Revenue Growth was 19%, 19% and 13%, respectively, compared to Organic Revenue Growth of 10%, 8% and 9%, respectively, of our listed peers (representing the weighted average organic growth rate of public intermediary peers: Marsh McLennan, Aon, Willis Towers Watson, Arthur J. Gallagher & Co., Brown & Brown Insurance, Baldwin Risk Partners and Ryan Specialty). ----- Source: Company information We have identified various growth drivers to maintain this level of Organic Revenue Growth, primarily through winning business from large U.S. global brokers, strategic global recruitment initiatives driven by our equity model and our global footprint, the exploration of new product lines, and the pursuit of untapped market segments.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Disciplined M&A strategy focused on cultural fit and complementing our footprint
Subsubsection Text: Our growth, particularly in new markets and product lines, has been accelerated by a selective and disciplined M&A strategy, focusing on acquiring firms that share our commitment to employee ownership and complement our culture. From October 1, 2015 through September 30, 2023, we completed over 100 Bolt-on Acquisitions and Transformational Acquisitions, accounting for approximately £1,040 million of acquired revenue. The majority of these transactions are the result of bilateral negotiations, although we also selectively participate in competitive auctions. The majority of our M&A activity by volume focuses on small to medium-sized bolt-on acquisitions that bolster our existing regional capabilities. From October 1, 2015 through September 30, 2023, our M&A approach resulted in the successful completion of 97 Bolt-on Acquisitions, with over 50% of these deals valued at less than £5 million whereas about 60% of acquired EBITDA comes from deals with multiples below 10x pricing EBITDA. See “Presentation of financial and other information—Non-IFRS Financial Measures.” Source: Company information Large strategic deals for transformative growth have been focused on expanding geographical footprint and product capabilities. For example, the acquisitions of A-Plan Group and Aston Lark expanded our personal ----- lines offering and products for micro SME, SME and mid-sized corporates within the UK. The recent acquisition of Marsh R.S. strengthened our position in southern Spain and improved our capabilities to cover large corporates in Spain. The acquisition of Assiteca significantly increased our presence in Italy by adding a further 20 offices. The acquisition of Align has moved DUAL to one of the largest MGAs globally. The acquisition of TigerRisk strengthened our position in the global reinsurance market, placing us among the world’s top reinsurance brokers. It also complemented our offering of facultative reinsurance by adding treaty reinsurance and capital advisory capabilities in the U.S. and the UK. During the financial year ended September 30, 2023, we enhanced our treaty reinsurance offering and improved our footprint in the Netherlands, France, Switzerland, Belgium and Denmark through strategic M&A activity. Acquired entities are integrated into the Group and generally rebranded to Howden to maximize the scale benefit and global coverage of our brand. This also delivers cultural and operational alignment and helps to achieve the anticipated synergies on a timely basis. Prior to completion, management and operational structures are agreed as well as targeted revenue and cost synergies. Whilst the bulk of anticipated synergies are revenue focused, we have been successful in achieving planned cost synergies. We often structure our acquisitions with incentives schemes, including “earn-outs”and company incentive shares for key management of the acquired firms to encourage alignment, retention and long-term commitment.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Diversified platform across geographies and routes to market supported by a strong specialty focus, capable of serving sophisticated clients globally
Subsubsection Text: Our diversified platform features a comprehensive suite of insurance products and services, including personal and commercial lines, wholesale distribution, and underwriting services. We serve a wide-ranging client base, which comprises SMEs as well as large corporations, ensuring that our business is not dependent on any single client segment. The geographic distribution of our Adjusted Revenue enhances our resilience, with operations across 50 countries and a network that covers over 100 countries and territories. As is illustrated in the figure below, for the year ended September 30, 2023, our Adjusted Revenue was well-distributed with 36% generated in the UK & Ireland, 27% in the Americas, 22% in Europe, and 15% in other regions. Source: Company information

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Highly recurring revenue and high cash flow conversion
Subsubsection Text: A key aspect of our financial strength is the highly recurring nature of our revenue streams, which are anchored by consistently high retention rates across our product lines. This predictability is a result of our commitment ----- to superior client service and relationships. Our revenue retention rate has averaged around 90% for the year ended September 30, 2023. In addition, our business generates considerable Management Operating Cash flow, primarily driven by high Adjusted Consolidated EBITDA margins combined with limited requirements for working capital and Maintenance CapEx. In the year ended September 30, 2023, we delivered an Operating Cash Conversion rate of 83%, consistent with our historical rates when normalized for the TigerRisk acquisition.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Board consistency and experienced management team with aligned incentives through significant equity ownership
Subsubsection Text: Our Group is guided by a seasoned leadership team with consistent composition over the past 9 years and an entrepreneurial approach to business, led by our founder David Howden and supported by a board of directors and executive committee with significant industry experience. Our people first approach and entrepreneurial culture is further enriched by significant employee ownership, with approximately one-third of our shares held by around 4,500 employees, resulting in a high producer retention rate.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Conservative leverage profile and financial policy
Subsubsection Text: We have maintained a disciplined financial policy, evidenced by our conservative leverage profile which has remained in line with historical levels as we have grown our business through acquisitions. This has been achieved due to the strong EBITDA growth, the high cash conversion of our business, and the support of our institutional investors who backed our growth through additional equity funding five times since 2018. For the financial year ended September 30, 2023, shareholders invested approximately £1,000 million of equity to fund our M&A activities. Our strong organic growth has also helped to maintain our leverage profile. Despite active M&A activities, our gross leverage ratio improved from 6.6x for the financial year ended September 30, 2022, to 6.1x for the financial year ended September 30, 2023, and our net leverage ratio decreased from 5.6x to 5.1x, respectively.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Drive sustained Organic Revenue Growth
Subsubsection Text: Our Organic Revenue Growth strategy is multifaceted and designed to reinforce our presence across various markets and specialties and establishing our Group as a key competitor to the big 3 brokers. Howden UK & Ireland (“UK&I”), including UK&I Retail and Specialty, is our largest broking division with the broadest geographic footprint in the UK, providing services to corporates, personal lines clients and high net worth individuals. It offers diversified products, including P&C, employee benefits, and specialty products, backed by an extensive branch network for local service. In this region, our strategy involves working towards a fully integrated platform, which will service a wide range of clients and enable us to cross-sell services, particularly to legacy Aston Lark and A-Plan Group clients. Furthermore, we are expanding existing UK based specialisms into our businesses throughout Europe and increasing our presence in the large corporate sector. Additionally, there are opportunities to grow our consumer and commercial branch network, filling geographic gaps and extending our reach. In Europe, we have established a strong local presence in over 20 countries and mid-market corporate segments. Our European strategy emphasizes using our scale and expertise to win tenders, cross-selling specialty lines to clients via our pan-European retail operations, developing our large client segment, and attracting top industry talent. During the financial year ended September 30, 2023, we rolled out a single brand globally for most of our Group businesses to enhance global brand recognition and foster a cohesive identity. A further key element of our growth strategy is to leverage our expertise in specialty product placement and access to the global insurance markets, especially the London market, to support our retail insurance brokerage ----- clients. Our entrepreneurial team members actively seek opportunities to cross-sell specialty products to our clients across the globe. Howden Tiger ranks among the top four global reinsurance brokers, serving clients in over 30 countries. It emerged from the merger of Howden Re, specialized in facultative reinsurance and MGA services in the UK and Europe, and TigerRisk, which focused on treaty reinsurance in the US and Europe. For Reinsurance, our attention is centered on the seamless integration and realization of the synergies following the TigerRisk acquisition. We have become a credible alternative in the global reinsurance market for both talent and clients. DUAL, our underwriting division, is one of the largest international MGAs with a presence across 21 countries and 45 locations. We have built long-term relationships with more than 70 carriers globally. Our existing portfolio is extensive, encompassing financial lines, P&C, marine, energy, transactional risks, treaty reinsurance and specialist lines. Within our DUAL segment, our strategic focus includes attracting leading underwriting talent, establishing a presence in new geographies, and setting up new product lines or expanding product capabilities.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Expand through New Initiatives
Subsubsection Text: Our New Initiatives strategy focuses on lateral hiring to enter new markets and expand our capabilities in new product lines. We are an employer of choice for entrepreneurial talent, given our differentiated founder-led culture, significant employee ownership, global presence and access.
