We successfully on-boarded a significant number of employees in New Initiatives in recent years, totaling approximately 1,120 employees in New Initiatives as at September 30, 2023. These employees hold considerable growth potential that will be realized as they become fully integrated into Howden. For the year ended September 30, 2023, our New Initiatives made up approximately 30% of the Group’s Organic Revenue Growth, contributing about 4% to our Organic Revenue Growth of 13% in this period.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Execute disciplined M&A strategy
Subsubsection Text: Our disciplined M&A strategy has been an important element of our growth strategy. From October 1, 2015 through September 30, 2023, we completed over 100 acquisitions, accounting for approximately £1,040 million of acquired revenue. We will continue to focus on both Bolt-on and Transformational Acquisitions to build scale, enter new markets, or reinforce existing capabilities. We have been adept at identifying and reviewing M&A targets that match our entrepreneurial culture and have strong growth potential, as well as matching our strategic goals. We will maintain a disciplined approach in acquisitions, seeking to acquire targets at attractive valuations while aligning incentives through effective use of earn-outs and equity incentives, and seamlessly integrating acquired businesses.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Improve operational efficiencies
Subsubsection Text: To boost operational efficiency, we focus on leveraging technology and streamlining processes. Specifically, we are standardizing our trading platforms to generate efficiencies. We have also implemented Software-as-aservice (“SaaS”) applications for a scalable, global back-office system that improves reporting and control, as well as streamlining processes and costs. Our “On-Net” program is integrating group companies onto unified infrastructure to boost security and scalability. These investments are made with a disciplined approach to expense management, ensuring cost efficiency.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Insurance
Subsubsection Text: Our insurance broking business provides both retail and specialty insurance-related products and services through a network of subsidiary and associated companies organized along geographical regions. Our retail broking business employs over 12,000 people across 46 countries and accounts for $10,800 million in gross written premium. Our specialty broking business employs approximately 1,500 people and accounts for $5,500 million in gross written premium, including $4,100 million in gross written premium in the London market alone. _Retail Howden UK&I Retail_ Our largest division within retail broking is Howden UK & Ireland Retail (“UK&I Retail”), on account of which we have the broadest geographic footprint, and are one of the leading players in the UK market. In particular, UK&I Retail is one of the largest independent brokers in the UK. UK&I Retail is a leading broker offering a full suite of insurance products to companies (P&C, fleet with a specialty division providing employee benefits), consumers (mainly motor and home, life and private medical insurance) and mortgage and debt advisory to both commercial and retail clients. The business has a number of differentiators that enable it to compete effectively in its target markets in particular: - Multiple niche specialisms on a retail and wholesale basis providing services to multiple industries and consumer groups. - High net worth focus including the ability to provide complex financing solutions. - Leading employee benefits consultancy with growing international client footprint. - Extensive branch network providing unique reach and access for clients and insurers, enabling local clients (personal lines and commercial) to access local service and advice. This is a different approach from our competitors, which often access clients directly online or via price comparison sites. Core client segments include retail consumers, high net worth individuals, SMEs and large corporate clients. The breadth of our product line allow us to meet our clients’ needs, generating meaningful cross-selling opportunities. The business has a track record of growing organically, with multiple growth levers through winning new clients, cross-selling, strong client retention and margin expansion. We bolster our retention rates through client service and advocacy, and by distributing to target segments avoiding more price-led online personal lines distribution. ----- There are a large number of growth levers to underpin continued organic growth at a similar level. In particular, strategic hires in the UK and Ireland, targeting new specialisms and market segments, plus rolling out existing UK specialisms into Ireland and expanding the Irish presence in the large corporate sector. There are also further opportunities for consumer and commercial branch openings to extend the network, filling geographical white space. In addition to organic growth, Howden UK&I Retail has delivered significant growth through selected M&A across the commercial and personal lines pillars, with multiple acquisitions since January 1, 2019 across the heritage A-Plan and Aston Lark businesses. Howden UK&I employs approximately 4,800 people across 211 sites in the UK and Ireland and accounts for $2,800 million in gross written premium, with approximately 1.2 million policyholders. _Howden Europe_ Howden Europe has a strong local presence in over 20 countries in Europe. We believe that we are one of the leading pan-European brokers with significant positions in countries such as Spain, Italy, Germany, Sweden and Norway and strong positions in Greece and Finland. We also have a fast growing presence in key target geographies such as France, Switzerland and the Netherlands. In Europe, we offer a full suite of services with client-tailored products varying slightly between jurisdictions, but with an overarching country strategy of widespread territorial coverage paired with market leading specialty capabilities. We have a strong presence across all key European operations in SME and mid-market segments, where the strategy is to further penetrate through specialties such as employee benefits and cyber insurance products, while building up strong capabilities to improve our position in the large and complex environment. In Germany, we have a strong presence in the large commercial and corporate segment with market leading positions serving corporate fleets and leasing companies, clients in the sport, leisure and entertainment sectors, as well as marine and financial lines. In Italy, we have a significant presence within the SME and mid-market segments, served via our network of over 20 branches, in sectors such as marine, sport, leisure and entertainment, food and agriculture, and provide them with specialty products such as employee benefits, trade credit, bonds, and financial lines. Similarly, in Spain, we have a strong penetration in the mid-market segment through our network of more than 30 local offices and we are increasingly engaging larger clients with complex exposures and operations in various territories who are in need for advisory services, in addition to procuring insurance. We also offer specialty products such as employee benefits (to both companies and self-employed) and global credit for the real estate, cyber, life sciences and the manufacturing and technology sectors. In Israel, we service a wide variety of clients in sectors such as tech, life science, commercial and retail, real estate and construction, service providers (including, among others, accountants, law firms, engineers), financial institutions (investment houses, private equity and venture capital funds) as well as employee benefits. Our product capabilities include financial lines, construction, P&C, claims management and cyber. Howden Europe employs approximately 3,500 people in 20 countries and accounts for $4,800 million in gross written premium. _Howden Asia and Howden Pacific_ Howden Asia operates as a retail/specialty broker across six countries in East Asia (Singapore, Thailand, Philippines, Malaysia, Hong Kong and Indonesia), with a leading position in Malaysia and Singapore. It also operates a market leading high net worth wealth planning intermediary, Howden Private Wealth (formerly known as IPG), with hubs in Hong Kong, Singapore, Kuala Lumpur, Dubai and Zurich. We offer our clients a full suite of retail products, including commercial lines, specialty products (such as financial lines, cyber, M&A and Takaful Insurance, a type of Islamic insurance), personal lines and employee benefits. In addition, Howden Private Wealth focuses on providing bespoke high-quality life insurance and wealth planning solutions to our affluent clients across Asia and EMEA. ----- Our primary client sectors include large and SME corporate clients, as well as high-net-worth individuals, primarily accessed via private banks and wealth managers. Howden Asia employs over 900 people across six countries and accounts for $2,000 million in gross written premium. Howden Pacific relates to our operations in Australia and New Zealand. In Australia and New Zealand, our products cover financial lines, corporate risks, commercial lines, private clients, people risk, risk consulting, alternative risk transfer and claims management. Our specialty offering is developing and is intended to cover marine, transport and logistics; natural resources/climate change, construction, mining, education, healthcare, sport and entertainment. Our core clients are across all segments including individuals and SMEs to corporates in the upper middle market. Howden Pacific employs over 250 people across 8 locations and accounts for $141 million in gross written premium. _International Growth Markets_ Our fourth largest retail division combines our operations in India, Latin America (Mexico, Brazil, Chile, Peru, Colombia), the Middle East and Africa (being United Arab Emirates, Oman, Bahrain, South Africa and Tanzania) (together, “International Growth Markets”). In India, we offer a full suite of commercial products to clients in large construction projects, financial and casualty lines to large and mid-size technology and pharmaceutical companies, and property insurance to large manufacturers and oil and gas companies. In Latin America, our core client segments vary according to geography. In Mexico, we provide motor / car insurance broking as well as servicing large corporate risks including employee benefits. In Brazil, we provide employee benefits solutions to medium to large corporates as well as general lines such as P&C and logistics. In Colombia, we provide retail broking services focused on mid-sized corporates and government business as well as certain large corporate accounts. In Chile, we also focus on employee benefits for large corporate accounts. In the Middle East and Africa, our core client segments include SMEs and large corporates, for which we provide a range of products including employee benefits, P&C and specialty lines for the energy, marine, construction and financial industry. International Growth Markets employs over 1,200 people across 11 countries and accounts for approximately $674 million in gross written premium. _Specialty (Howden Specialty)_ Howden Specialty is one of the leading providers of broking services. With over 66,000 clients, we are the leading specialty provider in the UK market. We provide advice and service to a wide range of UK retail and international clients on a direct basis and to clients of non-UK based brokers accessing insurance capacity in London and in other global markets such as Dubai, Bermuda, Singapore, and Miami. Howden Specialty serves clients in a number of industry and product specialisms, including natural resources, logistics, professional service firms, financial institutions, construction, sport and entertainment, property and casualty, real estate, health care and fine art and specie (e.g. valuable and collectable coins). Product specialisms include cyber, directors, and officers liability and professional indemnity insurance. Howden CAP is a strategic insurance brokerage and advisory business that sits within Howden Specialty serving primarily institutions in the financial services industry. Howden CAP provides products related to credit and political risk, tax and contingent risk, legal and technical claims, climate and transition risks as well as risks related to M&A and surety. For example, for M&A, transactions we provide warranty and indemnity ----- broking solutions which protect parties from financial loss arising from breaches of warranties and certain indemnities given by a seller to a buyer under a sale and purchase agreement. xTrade sits within Howden Specialty and is a digital platform which allows insurance brokers within Howden Group as well as third parties to place risk via its digital platform. The platform supports mainly the placement of small and medium sized risks with insurers. Howden Specialty employs approximately 2,000 people and accounts for $5,500 million in gross written premium.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Reinsurance (Howden Tiger)
Subsubsection Text: Howden Tiger is a leading risk, capital and strategic adviser to the global insurance and reinsurance industry providing reinsurance, capital markets and strategic advisory services. _Reinsurance_ Howden Tiger is a top four global reinsurance broker serving clients across more than 30 countries. It is the result of the merger between Howden Re (which primarily focused on facultative reinsurance and services to managing general agencies (“MGAs”) in the U.S. and Europe) and TigerRisk (which primarily focused on treaty reinsurance in the UK and Europe) in January 2023. Facultative reinsurance involves insuring large single risk exposures of insurers whereas treaty reinsurance involves insuring a collection of insurance policies. The business provides services across a wide range of business lines including property, casualty, cyber, facultative, retrocessional, legacy liability, aviation and space, marine, energy and specialty, credit surety and political risk, professional liability, health and life and medical and lawyers’ public liability, and has strong trading relationships with the world’s largest reinsurers. Howden Tiger uses a range of data and technology tools to service its clients including Tiger CQ (a portfolio analysis tool) and Nova (a data visualization tool). Howden Tiger employs over 700 people and accounts for approximately $18,500 million in gross written premium. _Capital Markets & Advisory_ Howden Tiger Capital Markets & Advisory (“HTCMA”) is a leading insurance-focused investment banking group acting as a risk, capital and strategic advisor to the global insurance and reinsurance industry. The business covers a range of insurance carrier and insurance services companies and offers expertise in M&A, capital raising, general strategic advice and Insurance-Linked Securities. HTCMA has more than 30 employees and has advised more than 120 transactions since 2016. _Howden Tiger SabRE_ SabRE Global is a leading MGA and program business offering brokerage services to MGAs, with expert teams proficient in sourcing insurance and reinsurance capacity within the U.S. and UK markets.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Underwriting (DUAL)
Subsubsection Text: DUAL, our underwriting division, is one of the largest MGAs globally, operating across 21 countries in 45 locations. MGAs are granted delegated authority by insurance companies to underwrite risks within a defined category of business on their behalf, and earn a commission for their services, along with a profit commission which represents a share of underwriting profits when the risks underwritten perform at or better than an agreed loss ratio. DUAL is one of the world’s largest international underwriting agencies and has built strong long-term relationships with a wide range of more than 70 carriers. Acting on behalf of major (re)insurance carriers, we are involved in most parts of the insurance lifecycle, providing access to global distribution and bringing ----- diverse, innovative and specialist products through a combination of local underwriting expertise and application of flexible technological solutions. It applies leading-edge data, digital and analytics capabilities to its underwriting discipline. DUAL’s portfolio offering is broad, ranging from financial lines, property, general liability, marine and energy, transactional risks, treaty reinsurance and specialist lines such as cyber and bloodstock. DUAL employs over 1,500 people across 21 countries in 45 locations and accounts for $3,800 million in gross written premium through a network of more than 11,000 distributors.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Title: Other Activities
Subsubsection Text: _Howden Markets_ As our market-facing function, Howden Markets engages with global insurers and reinsurers to coordinate our placement strategy into the global marketplace. Through data analytics, consulting, placement advisory and carrier management services, Howden Markets aligns the needs of the market with the capabilities of the businesses. Howden Markets also provides certain of our businesses, such as DUAL, Howden Tiger and our International Growth Markets, with strategic capacity services. _Howden Group Placement_ Howden Group Placement plays a key role within our Group, acting as the primary advocate for our clients in collaboration with our trading teams. This team works closely with our network of chief broking officers and related roles across the business, ensuring a coordinated and strategic approach to (re)insurance market activities, thereby enhancing our day-to-day trading operations, driving effective deployment of our capacity. Howden Group Placement serves as a central hub for various functions, including handling requests for proposals, managing critical and complex placements, facilitating C-suite escalations, addressing new capacity requirements for significant product portfolios and providing support for the design and placement of insurance facilities, panels, and portfolios—additionally, it assists in executing placement initiatives launched by our broking businesses. Howden Group Placement also plays a critical role in our strategic partners’ engagement, actively supporting regular quarterly business reviews, collaborating on placement and product initiatives, monitoring service performance and providing feedback. Furthermore, Howden Group Placement’s global reach enables us to handle escalations, critical coverage requests, disputed claims and dispute resolution (errors and omissions) matters, irrespective of jurisdiction. _Climate Risk and Resilience_ In March 2021, Howden set up a Climate Risk and Resilience team focused on helping corporate, financial sector and government actors across the globe understand the impact of risks like climate change, crisis resilience and the transition to a low carbon world. We help our clients to de-risk and adapt to these major new risks using science, analytics, consultancy and insurance-related solutions. Since inception the team has grown to approximately 57 people. The current focus of the team is developing consulting, analytics and climate related insurance products to meet our clients’ risk management and transfer needs.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Our Group is structured around three main business divisions: (i) insurance broking, comprising both retail broking and specialty broking, (ii) reinsurance broking (through Howden Tiger) and (iii) underwriting (through DUAL). Up to the year ended September 30, 2023, the Group had only two reporting segments: Howden Broking Group (which comprised of insurance and reinsurance broking) and DUAL. Howden Broking Group was removed as a reporting division from October 1, 2023. ----- We also benefit from a highly diversified platform across geographies and specialties. The below chart displays the breakdown of Adjusted Revenue by region in each of our three main business divisions.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: Howden One Network, our retail broking partner network of like-minded, independent experts, adds depth and flexibility to the ways we deliver for clients with international exposures. Combining our Howden One Network partners with the 50 international offices where we already operate through our Howden network, our reach expands to over 100 countries and territories worldwide across Asia, the Pacific region, Europe, Latin America, the Middle East and Africa as well as North America and the Caribbean. Our Howden One Network partners are chosen after a comprehensive due diligence process and trusted to advise our multinational clients given their localized knowledge and expertise. ----- The Howden One Network is coordinated by an experienced central team, which helps incorporating common values, a unified set of standards, and an operational framework that fosters mutual success. Our central team and our strategically appointed coordinators allow us to optimize the engagement of our partners and to keep them informed about market developments, including our network standards and protocols.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS
Subsubsection Text: _The following discussion of our financial condition and results of operations should be read in conjunction with our historical consolidated financial statements and the notes accompanying those statements appearing elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. The results described below are not necessarily indicative of the results to be expected in any future periods. This discussion contains forward-looking statements based on our current expectations, which are inherently subject to risks and uncertainties. Actual results may differ significantly from those projected in such forward-looking statements due to a number of factors as a result of a variety of risks and uncertainties, including those described in this Offering Memorandum under “Cautionary Statement Regarding Forward-Looking Statements” and “Risk Factors.” We undertake no obligation to update or revise any forward looking statement._

Section Title: M&A
Subsubsection Text: Through New Initiatives, we also employ lateral hiring initiatives to establish our presence in a new geography, set up a new product line or expand our product capabilities. We have been advancing our New Initiatives since 2019 with new hires joining from a range of reputable insurance intermediaries. Our New Initiatives have been geographically diverse (including UK, Europe, South East Asia, Middle East, Italy, Latin America and North America) as well as covering a range of specialisms (including construction, aviation, reinsurance (treaty and facultative), warranty and indemnity). Our New Initiatives capitalize on the loyalty that clients commonly exhibit towards their current brokers, leading to the addition of a significant number of employees in recent years. In the year ended September 30, 2023, we had approximately 1,120 employees in New Initiatives, which made up approximately 30% of the Group’s Organic Revenue Growth for the year ended September 30, 2023, contributing approximately 4% to our Organic Revenue Growth of 13% in this period.

Section Title: M&A
Subsubsection Text: We invest heavily in technology, data and analytics in order to provide innovative solutions for our clients as well as delivering IT capabilities internally to support our growth. ----- We are standardizing our trading platforms to generate efficiencies, implement a standard data model and mitigate end of serviceable life risk. We have also adopted leading software-as-a-service applications to create a scalable and global back-office application suite that can be rolled out to all businesses, supporting enhanced reporting and control, as well as streamlining processes and costs. We also have an ‘On-Net’ program which focuses on bringing Group companies onto common infrastructure platforms to enhance security, reliability and scalability benefits. Technology plays an increasingly important role in every aspect of the design and delivery of our products and services. We integrate insurance experience and digital expertise that create digital products and services for clients. Notable products include Nova and Rethink, which deliver digital solutions and data insights to clients and insurers to help inform decision making. As part of our growth strategy, we recently launched Howden Ventures, an end-to-end platform that accelerates the launch and growth of new insurance products by bringing together funding, capacity, expertise, governance and distribution. Howden Ventures is backed by a £10 million Howden Fund and a £500 million binding authority agreement, which provides pre-syndicated capacity to allow start-ups to trade once they have developed a product to test with the market. Howden Ventures is a division of DUAL, which provides critical infrastructure as an MGA incubator and connects Howden Ventures with the distribution network and expertise of the Howden Group. Recently, Howden Ventures acquired a stake in CetoAI, a marine software-as-a-service start-up that repurposes data produced by sensors connected to the ships’ alarm monitoring systems to provide fuel usage, carbon emissions and machinery maintenance analytics. Our investment in CetoAI is designed in the short term to fund a pilot which will underwrite a small portfolio of marine hull risk where CetoAI devices are installed and, in the long term, to create a MGA focused on ship-related risks. _Clients_ We serve a broad range of clients, from individuals to extensive global corporations, and we are committed to identifying and capitalizing on opportunities to cross-sell specialized products globally. Our expertise encompasses not only traditional P&C products but also extends to emerging sectors like cybersecurity, M&A, as well as climate risk and resilience solutions. Our client base is large and diversified, and no material part of our business depends upon a single group of clients. We therefore believe that the loss of any one client would not have a material adverse effect on our operations. _Sustainability and ESG_ As we continue to grow as a Group, it is important that we continue to grow responsibly. In 2023, we created a new governance structure to support our increasing work on all aspects of ESG, and to help us respond to increasing stakeholder and regulatory demands that continue to evolve across geographies. Our Sustainability Committee became a sub-committee of the board of directors of HGH Limited and was expanded to focus both on the climate-related impacts on the Group and the impacts of the Group on the climate (i.e. double materiality focused), and was renamed to reflect this as ‘The ESG & Sustainability Committee’. Our commitment to sustainability and ESG actively involves our colleagues in managing our impact on the environment and our local communities, as well as the actions we take to be a diverse and inclusive workplace. Our innovations, such as the Red Cross volcano catastrophe bond or micro-insurance in Tanzania, are designed to help support vulnerable communities, transition to a low carbon economy, and facilitate economic growth and resilience. We assist in mitigating the financial obstacles commonly encountered by sustainable energy projects. For example, there is a risk that the carbon credits being produced are not sequestering the correct amount of carbon dioxide, due to fraud or negligence by the project developers: Howden holds the distinction of being the first broker to provide insurance coverage addressing this concern, available in both the regulated market and the voluntary carbon market. We also believe in the pivotal role of insurance in facilitating essential funding during critical times, including to humanitarian organizations. For example, parametric insurance, built on pre-agreed triggers that result in pre-agreed payments, can provide the immediacy and reliability of funding needed to prevent a disaster from ----- turning into a crisis, and reduce the overall financial and, more importantly, human cost. We have deployed parametric insurance to support vulnerable communities in Fiji, Tonga and Vanuatu, by developing and launching the Pacific region’s first parametric micro insurance products in partnership with UNCDF (the UN Capital Development Fund). Additionally, we have played an active role in assisting humanitarian organizations, for example by acting as a broker to provide insurance cover to a UN-led mission in Yemen to remove oil from a vessel to avert an environmental disaster. We also completed a review of the environmental impacts of our operations and identified two primary impact areas (i.e. (i) energy and emissions, and (ii) waste and recycling), and two secondary impact areas (i.e. (i) water and liquid waste, and (ii) biodiversity and nature), on which we will focus our efforts going forward. We further built out our central specialist team to manage environmental sustainability across the Group, whilst also implementing a net-zero and environmental data and reporting platform. Furthermore, the Group continues to work with the relevant regulators to ensure that all aspects of its business comply with local ESG rules and regulations. We also provide additional protection against the social and economic shocks of climate change through our charitable foundation, the Howden Foundation, which was established in 2014.

Section Title: M&A
Subsubsection Text: Attraction, development and retention of talent at all levels remains a core objective of our Group. We believe that our commitment to employee equity ownership, paired with the increasing power of our brand and the reputation of our business, has enabled us to attract some of the best talent in the market, which is evidenced by the appointment of a number of well-respected, senior market experts in the recent years. We are dedicated to cultivating and maintaining a diverse workforce that mirrors society across our organization. Our aspiration revolves around establishing an inclusive workplace environment that is devoid of both deliberate and unintentional biases, where every employee’s worth and appraisal hinge on their individual performance and contributions. Founded, and led by David Howden for the past 30 years, and supported by a board of directors and an executive committee comprised of experienced, long-serving members, our Group is headed by an entrepreneurial management team with unwavering focus on long-term value creation through organic growth and M&A investments. Employee ownership remains integral to our corporate culture and stands as a significant distinguishing factor, as our most substantial shareholder base consists of our workforce, with approximately 4,500 employees currently owning around one-third of the Group’s shares. We track employee engagement through our global people survey and see consistent levels of employee engagement (75% for the year ended September 30, 2023). The average number of persons employed by the Group during the year ended September 30, 2023 was approximately 15,500 located in 50 international offices. We have on-boarded approximately 800 new employees in the last year to enhance our capabilities, with a particular focus on strengthening our expertise in areas such as reinsurance, cyber risk, energy transformation, climate risk and resilience, as well as expanding our presence in new countries, notably in Europe. We consider relations with our employees to be in good standing, and there are no pending employment-related class action lawsuits. The agreements we enter into with employees and consultants who have access to proprietary information generally contain confidentiality and non-disclosure provisions, and agreements entered into with most members of our executive management team include non-solicitation and some members of our executive team include non-compete covenants that are in force for a six month to one year period after the cessation of employment. Furthermore, shareholders’ agreements entered into with our employee shareholders include non-solicitation and non-compete covenants that are in force for a period of two years after the cessation of employment.

Section Title: M&A
Subsubsection Text: From time to time, we are involved in lawsuits as well as subject to various legal proceedings, claims, threats of litigation, and investigations in the ordinary course of business. Proceedings initiated against us may include, ----- amongst other things, legal disputes initiated by clients or policyholders stemming from insurance placement or claims handling, notably in situations where substantial insurance claims have been denied by insurance providers. Such cases are relatively rare for a business of our size and have typically been consistently resolved expeditiously with the assistance of our errors and omissions insurance carriers. Additionally, from time to time we are involved in legal actions initiated by rival insurance intermediaries, typically arising where several individuals have joined our Group from these competing entities. These cases are typically resolved through confidential agreements in the early stages of the litigation process. On October 10, 2023, HGH Limited (and certain other companies in our Group) and Guy Carpenter & Company Limited (and certain other companies within the Guy Carpenter/Marsh McLennan Group, (the reinsurance broking arm of Marsh McLennan Companies, Inc.)) reached an agreement for settlement in the amount of £56.5 million (inclusive of Guy Carpenter’s costs) in respect of claims commenced by Guy Carpenter against the Group in the High Court of England and Wales. The claims related to alleged breach of employment obligations (including post termination restrictive covenants) within the employment and other agreements of 37 individual reinsurance brokers based in the UK and Europe who ceased employment with Guy Carpenter and were employed by our Group. We may be involved in various other legal proceedings and subject to claims from typical business activities, including alleged errors and omissions related to our insurance brokerage services and standard employment matters. Some of these claims receive partial coverage through insurance or contractual indemnification provisions, while others fall outside the purview of insurance and are self-insured. Regarding self-insured risks, we continually assess and, when necessary, adjust our insurance coverage based on the most current information available. Based on the most recent information available, we are of the opinion that these existing or potential claims, whether considered individually or in the aggregate, will not significantly impair our financial performance, cash flow, or overall financial standing. Nevertheless, it is essential to acknowledge that these proceedings, along with other claims, inherently carry uncertainties, and our assessment of these matters may evolve in the future. Moreover, as industry practices and legal, judicial and social conditions change, unexpected and unintended issues related to claims and coverage, including reinsurance coverage, may emerge. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we are not aware of any other legal, administrative, judicial, regulatory, tax or arbitral proceedings or investigations (including any pending or threatened proceedings or investigations) that are likely to have, or have had, individually or in the aggregate, a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. The outcome of legal proceedings and investigations, however, can be extremely difficult to predict with certainty, and we can offer no assurances in this regard. See also “Risk Factors—Risks related to our Business and Industry—Our results of operations, financial condition, _cash flows and reputation may be materially adversely affected by legal proceedings, claims, and investigations.”_

Section Title: M&A
Subsubsection Text: As a global insurance intermediary with established operations in the UK, Americas, Europe, Middle East, Asia and Pacific regions, we are subject to various regulatory requirements and obligations including data privacy laws (such as the UK Data Protection Act 2018, EU’s GDPR or Australia’s Privacy Act 1988), financial crime laws, tax laws, employment laws, environmental, health and safety laws. Given our size, we are also subject to additional laws and regulations that apply to larger companies, such as the European Union Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (EU Directive 2022/2464). We are also subject to local regulation that applies to our insurance intermediation activity, including the UK Financial Services & Markets Act 2000, the European Union Insurance Distribution Directive and the Singapore Insurance Act. Additionally, as a UK headquartered business, the Group is subject to certain UK legislation that has extra-territorial effect such as the UK Bribery Act and any international sanctions imposed by the UK government. Such laws and regulations are promulgated and enforced to varying degrees by supranational and national authorities and regulators such as the European Commission and the FCA and state, regional and local authorities. The regulatory environment in which we operate can have a material effect on our business and activities. -----

Section Title: M&A
Subsubsection Text: Our strategic acquisitions have enhanced our human capital, product capabilities and geographic footprint. Since our founding, we have partnered and acquired firms with offices across 50 countries to grow to over 350 offices and approximately 15,500 employees. These firms represent a diverse mix of specialties and geographies, allowing us to better service both existing and prospective clients. We seek individuals and companies that share our values and can integrate into our Group, placing a strong emphasis on employee ownership. We primarily engage in one-on-one negotiations during our acquisition discussions and participate only in select competitive auction processes. The majority of M&A activity by volume relates to small- to medium-sized insurance intermediaries in the UK, Europe, Asia Pacific, Middle East and Latin America. Smaller acquisitions in these countries are typically “bolt-on” in nature, strengthening existing capabilities in these regions. Acquisitions may be in the form of asset or portfolio transfers, particularly in the UK. Since October 1, 2015, we have completed over 97 Bolt-on Acquisitions and 7 Transformational Acquisitions which have contributed an estimated £1,040 million of revenue and £365 million of EBITDA (which excludes small UK&I Bolt-on Acquisitions, minority acquisitions, and asset deals, and which reflect pricing revenue and EBITDA). In recent years, we have also made a number of larger strategic acquisitions. In March 2021, we acquired A-Plan Group, one of the UK’s largest personal and commercial lines insurance brokers. We subsequently expanded our operations in the UK through the acquisition, in April 2022, of Aston Lark, one of the UK’s largest independent insurance brokers specializing in commercial and private client insurance and employee benefit advice. We have now combined these businesses under the Howden brand, providing a fullspectrum UK offering covering personal lines, SME and large corporate broking, MGA activity and data, analytics and technology. We further strengthened our position in the reinsurance and capital advisory business through the acquisition in January 2023 of TigerRisk, the fourth largest reinsurance broker globally. This business merged with Howden Re and is now collectively rebranded as Howden Tiger. Other notable medium-sized acquisitions include Align in 2021, one of the largest independent MGAs in North America, as well as Assiteca in 2022, which was a public-to-private transaction involving one of the largest insurance intermediaries in Italy.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: David Howden is the Group Chief Executive Officer and founder of the Howden Group. He founded the
Subsubsection Text: Group in 1994, originally as a wholesale broker employing just three people. As Chief Executive, David Howden’s focus is on leading the Group’s activities as well as directing and implementing the Group’s strategic growth and direction. David Howden started his career as a broker at Alexander Howden in 1981, before founding the Group in 1994. He has been the fundamental driving force behind its expansion into an international insurance group offering wholesale, retail and reinsurance broking and underwriting.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: Dominic Collins is the Group’s Executive Chairman since 2015. Mr. Collins previously served as chairman at
Subsubsection Text: The R K Harrison Group, as Chief Executive of Lloyd Thompson and as Chairman of JLT Risk Solutions, JLT UK and JLT International. Mr. Collins also was a director of Jardine Lloyd Thompson Group from its formation in 1997.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: Mark Craig has been the Howden Group’s CFO since December 2019. He previously led the Group’s M&A
Subsubsection Text: team, Debt Capital Market Activity and Treasury team. Mr. Craig qualified as a Chartered Accountant with PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP. He has over twenty five years of lending and advisory experience working in M&A, leveraged finance and debt advisory. Mr. Craig joined Howden Group from KKR where he was investing KKR’s European and Global lending funds.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: John Bernstein heads the Group’s Sustainability Committee. Mr. Bernstein is a partner of the sustainable
Subsubsection Text: investment firm Generation Investment Management, where he chairs the investment committee of the growth equity business. Previously, Mr. Bernstein was head of General Atlantic in Europe, Middle East and Africa. Mr. Bernstein holds an M.A. in economics and law from Downing College, Cambridge University, and is qualified as a barrister. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: Ralph Friedwagner is a Managing Director and Operating Partner in CDPQ’s Private Equity team.
Subsubsection Text: Mr. Friedwagner has over 20 years of private equity experience as an operating executive, investor, and board director across a range of sectors, including financial services, business services, technology, and industrials. Prior to joining CDPQ, he was a partner at Montagu Private Equity and a CEO of a PE-backed company. Mr. Friedwagner holds a Master’s in Industrial Engineering from Karlsruhe Institute of Technology and UC Berkeley, and an MBA from UCLA Anderson School.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: David Hodgson is Vice Chairman of General Atlantic, where he has been part of the investment team for over
Subsubsection Text: 30 years. He also serves as a director for a number of public and private companies, including Alignment Healthcare, Amherst Pierpont Securities and TriNet. Mr. Hodgson serves as chairman of the boards of trustees of Johns Hopkins Medicine, The Johns Hopkins Health System Corporation and The Johns Hopkins Hospital. Mr. Hodgson graduated from Dartmouth College and Stanford Business School.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: Andrew Land is a Partner at Hg, where he leads investments for the Saturn fund and chairs the Hg Realisation
Subsubsection Text: Committee. He has spent the last 24 years in European private equity across a range of sectors and has sat on multiple boards. He holds an LL.B (Hons) from the University of Edinburgh and an MBA from INSEAD.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: Luis Muñoz-Rojas is a founding Director of DUAL International and previously served as a director of GyC
Subsubsection Text: América, a reinsurance broking subsidiary of Gil y Carvajal (now part of Aon). Mr. Muñoz-Rojas has over 30 years of experience in the insurance business.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: James Parry-Crooke is a Director at CDPQ and focuses on private equity investments in the financial services
Subsubsection Text: sector. Prior to joining CDPQ in 2018, Mr. Parry-Crooke was an investment banker with Rothschild & Co in London. Mr. Parry-Crooke graduated with a Masters in Engineering Science from Oxford University.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: Caroline Woodworth is a Managing Director at General Atlantic and focuses on investments in the
Subsubsection Text: firm’s Financial Services sector. Before joining General Atlantic in 2015, she was a senior associate at J.C. Flowers & Co and an Investment Banking analyst in the Financial Institutions group at Citigroup. Ms. Woodworth holds a degree in Economics and Political Science from Middlebury College.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: Clement B. Booth has over 50 years of experience in the insurance business and currently serves as member of
Subsubsection Text: the Supervisory Board of Munich Reinsurance Company AG. He previously served as a member of the board of management of Allianz SE, as Chairman and CEO of Aon Re International and Member of the Board of Management of Munich Reinsurance Company AG. Mr. Booth has served on the boards of numerous companies around the world.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: Kelly Jean Lyles has over 35 years of experience in underwriting and general management in global commercial
Subsubsection Text: insurance and currently serves as a non-executive board member in several insurance companies, including Convex Group Limited, Convex Insurance UK Limited and RisingEdge Limited. She previously held multiple leadership roles at AIG and XL Catlin. Ms. Lyles holds a Bachelor of Science in Business Administration from Villanova University.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: Mark Stephen is Chair of the Audit & Risk Committee and Remuneration Committee. Mr. Stephen has over
Subsubsection Text: 30 years of experience of advising and working with insurance boards. He was previously a Partner at PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, where he was the UK insurance industry leader. Mr. Stephen is a chartered accountant and graduated from the University of London (Royal Holloway College).

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: Andrew Moore is the Group Company Secretary. Mr. Moore joined the Howden Group in 2003. Previously, he
Subsubsection Text: served in company secretary roles in other companies, such as Windsor Life Assurance, Boxclever and the R K Harrison Group. Mr. Moore holds a Bachelor of Laws from the University of Wolverhampton.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: Rebecca Scott has served as the Group Chief Risk Officer of Howden since 2022. Ms. Scott joined the Howden
Subsubsection Text: Group in 2014. She has previously held numerous roles in the Group, including Head of Internal Audit and Chief Operating Officer, and is a member or Chairperson of many of Howden leadership teams and committees. Ms. Scott holds a Bachelors of Laws and is a qualified chartered accountant, and has previously held positions as a partner at chartered accountancy firm Mazars LLP and chief risk officer at a Lloyd’s Managing Agency.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: Richard Clapham has served as the Group Chief Executive Officer of DUAL Group since January 2017.
Subsubsection Text: Mr. Clapham joined the Howden Group in September 2016 and has over 40 years of insurance industry ----- experience, having led the professional indemnity division of Markel International for five years and served as underwriting director at XL Catlin for over a decade.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: Timothy Ronda is the Chief Executive Officer of Howden Tiger, Howden’s global reinsurance brokerage
Subsubsection Text: business. Before joining Howden, Mr. Ronda was President of TigerRisk Partners, LLC, a business acquired by Howden in 2023. Prior to his time at TigerRisk Partners, Mr. Ronda served as president of the United States division of Aon plc’s reinsurance brokerage business and global geographic leader of Aon plc’s global reinsurance brokerage business. Prior to his roles at Aon, Timothy Ronda served in a variety of roles at Benfield and Guy Carpenter. Mr. Ronda holds a B.S. in Business Administration and Accounting from Washington & Lee University.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: Carl Shuker is the Chief Executive Officer of Howden UK&I and has held this position since August 2023.
Subsubsection Text: Previously, Mr. Shuker held the position of Howden Group Executive Committee Chief Executive Officer. Mr. Shuker started his insurance career at A-Plan in 1981, where he served among other roles as the deputy chief executive officer in 2000 and group chief executive officer from 2008 to 2021, when A-Plan was acquired by the Group. Mr. Shuker holds an MBA from Henley Management College and is also ACII (Advanced Diploma in Insurance) qualified.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: Luigi Sturani is Chief Executive Officer of Howden Broking Europe, a position he has held since June 2021.
Subsubsection Text: Mr. Sturani previously held the roles of chief executive officer, specialty EMEA and managing director and head of global property and casualty, crisis management over a fifteen year span at Aon. Mr. Sturani also served as managing director of Willis for twelve years prior to joining Aon.

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Title: Sarah Hughes joined Howden in February 2020 as Global Practice Leader of its financial lines practice, and
Subsubsection Text: was subsequently appointed as Chief Executive Officer of Howden Specialty in October 2023. Sarah has over thirty-five years of insurance experience having previously held the positons of chief executive officer, financial lines and senior partner—financial lines group over a nine year span at JLT Specialty Limited, as well as a nearly twenty year term as executive director at Aon. -----

Section Title: MANAGEMENT
Subsubsection Text: Set forth below are the names of the current members of the board of directors of HGH Finance (the “Board”), which exercises primary governance and strategic functions for the Group, and some of the key executive officers of the Group, along with their positions and business backgrounds. The Board consists of directors representing both institutional and employee shareholders.

Section Title: SECURITY OWNERSHIP
Subsubsection Text: The Group operates share incentive schemes (the “Employee Share Schemes”), the objective of which is to assist us in the attraction and retention of talent by providing eligible employees, officers and senior managers (the “Scheme Participants”) with the opportunity to acquire and hold D, E, F and G shares of £0.00001 each (the “Incentive Shares”) in HGH. The Incentive Shares are subject to financial performance targets and a hurdle relating to the value of the A shares (the “Hurdle”), and ordinarily vest at the end of a four or five-year vesting period. At the end of the relevant vesting period, to the extent the performance criteria has been met, the Incentive Shares convert into a number of A Shares determined by reference to the A share price at the time. Any Incentive Shares which do not meet their performance criteria convert to Deferred Shares and are repurchased for £1p in aggregate. D, E and G shares do not have voting rights. D and G shares do not have dividend rights, while E and F shares participate in dividends in excess of £0.20 per A share. HGH currently chooses to re-invest its profits for future growth rather than pay dividends to shareholders. _Internal Share Offer_ Our Board may make an invitation to Shareholders to sell some of their A Shares and to all eligible employees to purchase A Shares from time to time through an internal market (the “Internal Share Offer”or “ISO”). Our Board determines the terms and conditions of each ISO, subject to Investor Consent (as defined in the HGH Articles of Association), including but not limited to: (i) the price per A Share applicable for all sales and purchases in the ISO; (ii) the maximum number of A Shares that may be offered for sale and the minimum number of A Shares that may be purchased; (iii) the last date for acceptance of the ISO invitation; (iv) the manner in which the ISO invitation may be accepted; and (v) any conditions which must be satisfied or circumstances which must exist before all or any of the A Shares are transferred. HGH has established an employee benefit trust (the “EBT”) for the benefit of the Group’s current and former employees and some of their relatives and dependents. Facilitating the ISO transactions is one of the objectives of the EBT. The trustee of the EBT is Apex Group Fiduciary Services Limited (the “EBT Trustee”). Each ISO is facilitated by Howden Employee Jersey Holdings Limited (“HEJH”). HEJH is a wholly owned subsidiary of the EBT Trustee and sells and acquires A Shares to and from shareholders as part of each ISO. HEJH also holds Incentive Shares which have been purchased from Scheme Participants who have left the Group. The following table sets out the Incentive Shares held by HEJH as of September 30, 2023.

Section Title: SECURITY OWNERSHIP
Subsubsection Text: As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, approximately 68% of the share capital of Howden Group Holdings Limited (“HGH”) was owned by the Sponsors and 32% by management, employees and other shareholders, directly or indirectly. Shares in the capital of HGH that are held by shareholders who are not Sponsors, employees, officers or managers of the Group comprise, in the aggregate, less than 1% of voting rights. The Howden Group Foundation, a registered charity in England and Wales (no.1156286), holds A, D, E, F and G shares. Certain members of the Board affiliated with our Sponsors may be deemed to beneficially own the equity interests owned by the Sponsors, as applicable. The primary share class with full voting and dividend rights are the A ordinary shares of £0.01 each (the “A shares”) which are held by the Sponsors, our founder, management and employees.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: In the year ended September 30, 2023, deferred consideration totaling £2.6 million was payable to members of our key management, and a contingent consideration of £1.8 million was payable to an entity connected to an institutional shareholder in relation to the acquisition, in the year ended September 30, 2022, of a protected cell company from Saturn 2, a fund managed by Hg. No deferred/contingent consideration was paid during the year ended September 30, 2023.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: In the year ended September 30, 2023, loans totaling £0.6 million were extended to members of key management, including David Howden, or companies in which they have an ownership interest. These loans are interest bearing. A total of £2.3 million was outstanding as at September 30, 2023.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: In the year ended September 30, 2023, we issued one ordinary share with a nominal value of £1 to HGH Midco 2, the direct parent of HGH Finance, for a total consideration of £742 million. Additionally, we received a capital contribution of £452.2 million from HGH Midco 2, comprising £300 million in cash to HGH Finance and the remainder attributed to share capital issued by HGH Limited for our M&A activities. In the year ended September 30, 2023, we also issued £5.2 million of loan notes to HGH Midco 2 with an annual interest rate of 7.5%. Loan notes and preference shares payable to HGH Midco 2 amounted to £79.6 million in the year ended September 30, 2023. Other payables due to HGH Limited amounted to £53 million, and other receivables from HGH Limited amounted to £110.8 million, consisting mainly of transactions related to HGH Limited shares. -----

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Text: We enter into transactions with certain related parties or our affiliates from time to time and in the ordinary course of our business. We believe that these agreements are on terms no more favorable to the related parties or our affiliates than they would expect to negotiate with disinterested third parties. Our transactions with related parties that are affiliates are governed by the affiliates’ transaction covenants as stipulated in our Amended and Restated Credit Agreement and the Indentures. For more information see the notes to the Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS
Subsubsection Title: General
Subsubsection Text: HIG Finance 2 and Hyperion Refinance are party to that certain (x) Amended and Restated Credit Agreement, dated as of December 20, 2017 (the “Existing First Lien Credit Agreement”), as amended, restated, amended and restated, supplemented or otherwise modified prior to the date hereof, by and among HIG Finance 2 and Hyperion Refinance, the other parties party thereto and Morgan Stanley Senior Funding, Inc., as administrative agent and (y) that certain Second Lien Credit Agreement, dated as of October 1, 2021 (the “Existing Second Lien Credit Agreement”), as amended, restated, amended and restated, supplemented or otherwise modified prior to the date hereof, by and among HIG Finance 2, the other parties party thereto and Wilmington Trust, National Association, as administrative agent. The Existing First Lien Credit Agreement is comprised of a euro-denominated and dollar-denominated term loan facility and a sterling denominated revolving facility. In connection with the transactions contemplated hereby, the Existing First Lien Credit Agreement will be amended by the Fourteenth Amendment, dated as of the date of the Indentures (the “Fourteenth Amendment” and the Existing First Lien Credit Agreement as amended thereby, the “First Lien Credit Agreement”). Pursuant to the Fourteenth Amendment, (i) Hyperion Refinance will incur additional term loans in an aggregate amount equal to (x) $3,435 million and (y) €660 million (the “Fourteenth Amendment Incremental Term Loans”) and (ii) the revolving facility will be upsized by an additional £270 million, with total commitments equal to £630 million (the “Revolving Facility”). The maturity date (i) for the term loans will vary by tranche with the earliest maturity date set at April 18, 2030 and the latest maturity date set at seven years after the effective date of the Fourteenth Amendment and (ii) for the revolving loans is the earlier of (x) six and a half years after the effective date of the Fourteenth Amendment and (y) if more than an aggregate principal amount equal to the greater of £170,000,000 and 20.0% of Pro Forma Consolidated EBITDA (to be defined in substantially the same manner as defined in the Senior Secured Notes and as defined in the First Lien Credit Agreement) of any certain Term Loans or other secured Indebtedness for borrowed money secured by the same collateral with liens that rank pari passu with the liens securing the Revolving Facility (“Springing Maturity Trigger Debt”) remain outstanding on the date that is 91 days prior to the maturity date of such Springing Maturity Trigger Debt, the date that is 91 days prior to the maturity date of such Springing Maturity Trigger Debt. The First Lien Credit Agreement will permit the incurrence of incremental revolving loans and incremental term loans which may be in the form of additional term loans or additional revolving loans in the amount of (x) a fixed amount equal to the greater of £860 million and 100% of Consolidated EBITDA (to be defined in substantially the same manner as defined in the Senior Secured Notes and as defined in the First Lien Credit Agreement) and (y) an unlimited amount so long as (i) if secured by a lien on the collateral that is pari passu with the lien securing the First Lien Credit Agreement, the first lien net leverage ratio does not exceed 5.25:1.00, (ii) if secured by a lien on the collateral that is junior to the liens securing the First Lien Credit Agreement, the secured net leverage ratio does not exceed 6.00:1.00 and (iii) if unsecured, the total net leverage ratio does not exceed 6.75:1.00 or the fixed charge coverage ratio is not less than 2.00:1.00.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS
Subsubsection Title: Interest Rates and Fees
Subsubsection Text: Loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement will bear interest at a rate equal to the applicable benchmark rate for SOFR Loans, ABR Loans, Australian Bill Rate Loans, CDOR Rate Loans or RFR Loans (each as defined in the Existing First Lien Credit Agreement) or the base rate plus the applicable margin. ----- The applicable margin for the term loans and revolving loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement will vary by tranche for the term loans and with the revolving loans being subject to a pricing grid that steps down based achievement of certain first lien net leverage ratio levels. The Fourteenth Amendment Incremental Term Loans will bear interest at a rate and floor to be determined and the Revolving Loans will bear interest at a rate and floor to be determined. In connection with the Fourteenth Amendment, the term loans under the Existing Credit Agreement due April 18, 2030 will be refinanced and repriced. The revolving commitments will be subject to a commitment fee based on undrawn amounts equal to (i) 0.50% if the first lien net leverage ratio is greater than 4.75:1.00, (ii) 0.375% if first lien net leverage ratio is equal to or less than 4.75:1.00 but greater than 4.25:1.00 and (iii) 0.25% if first lien net leverage ratio is less than 4.25:1.00. The letters of credit are subject to customary letter of credit participation and issuing bank fees.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS
Subsubsection Title: Repayments and Prepayments
Subsubsection Text: _Amortization_ The term loans under the First Lien Credit Agreement will require amortization payments at a rate equal to 1.00% per annum. _Mandatory Prepayments_ Mandatory prepayments will be required under the First Lien Credit Agreement in connection with certain asset sales in an aggregate amount greater than the greater of £130 million and (ii) 15.0% of Consolidated EBITDA in an amount equal to a required percentage based on the first lien net leverage ratio ((i) if the first lien net leverage ratio is greater than 4.25:1.00, 100%, (ii) if the first lien net leverage ratio is less than or equal to 4.25:1.00 and greater than 3.75:1.00, 50% and (iii) if the first lien net leverage ratio is less than or equal to 3.75:1.00, 0%). Instead of making such mandatory prepayment, Hyperion Refinance or its subsidiary may reinvest in the business (subject to the same reinvestment rights as the Senior Secured Notes) within 540 days year or enter into a binding contract within such 540-day period and reinvest within 180 days thereafter. Mandatory prepayments will also be required after delivery of annual financial statements with respect to a required percentage of excess cash flow in excess of a de minimis amount equal to the greater of (i) £130 million and (ii) 15.0% of Consolidated EBITDA. Lastly, mandatory prepayment are also required with 100% of net cash proceeds received in connection with debt incurred that is not permitted under the First Lien Credit Agreement. _Voluntary Prepayments_ Voluntary prepayment of term loans and revolving loans will be permitted without premium or penalty other than the call protection on the Fourteenth Amendment Incremental Term Loans noted below and other than redeployment costs for breaking any interest rate contract prior to the expiration of such interest period. Revolving loans may be paid down and re-borrowed. There will be a 1.00% premium on any Fourteenth Amendment Incremental Term Loans prepaid within six months from the date incurred in connection with any Repricing Transaction (as defined in the First Lien Credit Agreement).

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS
Subsubsection Title: Guarantees; Security
Subsubsection Text: The obligations under the First Lien Credit Agreement will be guaranteed by the Issue Date Guarantors and the Post-Closing Guarantors. All obligations of the borrowers and guarantors under the First Lien Credit Agreement will be secured by the by senior priority Liens (subject to Permitted Liens and certain other exceptions) on the Collateral (as defined under “Description of Senior Secured Notes — Security for the Senior Secured Notes.”), which will also secure the obligations under the Senior Secured Notes and all other Equal Priority Obligations on an equal priority basis (but without regard to control of remedies). ----- The First Lien Credit Agreement will be guaranteed by each “Material Subsidiary” being each wholly owned restricted subsidiary of HGH Finance incorporated in a Guarantor Jurisdiction (as defined in the First Lien Credit Agreement) which has EBITDA representing 5% or more of Consolidated EBITDA (subject to certain adjustments) of the HGH Finance and its restricted subsidiaries (subject to certain exclusions) subject to compliance with a guarantor coverage test requiring guarantee support from guarantors represent at least 80% of Consolidated EBITDA (subject to certain adjustments) (as defined in the First Lien Credit Agreement). Guarantors included in such calculation and that may be required to be joined to the First Lien Credit Agreement shall be located in (i) the United Kingdom, the United States, Germany, Italy, Spain, Australia, Ireland, Switzerland, New Zealand, Netherlands, Belgium, France and Luxembourg, (ii) the jurisdiction of incorporation of any additional borrower and (iii) any other jurisdiction (other than an “excluded jurisdiction”) in which the restricted subsidiaries organized in such jurisdiction have, in the aggregate, EBITDA representing 7.5% or more of Consolidated EBITDA (excluding any pro forma adjustments). The security interests required to be collateral and pledged under the First Lien Credit Agreement will be subject to agreed security principles, including the below: - Guarantee or security interests will not be required (x) from any non-wholly owned material subsidiaries or (y) from any joint ventures; - Unrestricted subsidiaries shall not be required to give guarantees or security interests; - No security interest will be required over investments/shares in: - a subsidiary that is not a Material Subsidiary or required to become a Guarantor to satisfy the guarantor coverage test (except to the extent a security interest therein can be perfected by the filing of a financing statement or similar filing under applicable law), - any specified subsidiary (i.e. subsidiaries that have revenues less than 2.5% of the consolidated revenues of Hyperion and its subsidiaries), - any captive insurance Subsidiary, - any unrestricted subsidiary, - any not-for-profit subsidiary, or - any special purpose entity used for any securitization, receivables and/or factoring facilities or arrangements; - Any assets of the grantors that are subject to third party arrangements that prevent those assets from becoming subject to a security interest (to the extent that such prohibition was not created in contemplation of this requirement and is consistent with the business practices of the Hyperion and its restricted subsidiaries) will be excluded from the collateral; - Note that Hyperion must use commercially reasonable efforts to obtain consent from such third party unless Hyperion determines in good faith that such action could jeopardize the relationship of Hyperion with the third party; - A subsidiary will not be required to give guarantees or enter into security documents if - it is prohibited by or lacks legal capacity as a result of, any applicable contractual requirement, applicable law or similar rules or legal principles or any retention of title, claims or similar matters from guaranteeing or securing the obligations or - such action would require governmental (including regulatory) consent, approval, license or authorization - Note that Hyperion must use commercially reasonable efforts to structure a guarantee or enter into security documents in a way that would avoid or address such restrictions (or to obtain such consent, approval, license or authorization); - A subsidiary will not be required to give guarantees or enter into security documents if Hyperion (in consultation with the Administrative Agent) determines that doing so could reasonably be expected to conflict with the fiduciary duties of the directors and managers of the relevant entity, the consequence ----- of doing so would adversely affect the ability of Hyperion and/or its subsidiaries to satisfy applicable law, doing so would reasonably be expected to, result in material adverse tax consequences to Hyperion or its subsidiaries or doing so would result in a risk of personal or criminal liability for such subsidiary or any of its officers, employees, members of management, consultants, directors or managers; - Note that the relevant subsidiary must take commercially reasonable actions (including obtaining any required resolutions or consents from its board of directors or equivalent governing body), pursuant to its organizational documents to permit it to give the guarantee or enter the security documents; - Any subsidiary or assets where the cost, burden or other consequences of providing a guarantee or security interest in, or perfection of, such subsidiary or assets outweigh the benefits to be obtained by the secured parties (in the reasonable judgment of Hyperion and the Administrative Agent) will be excluded from the guarantee or collateral; - The maximum guaranteed or secured amount may be limited to minimize stamp duty, notarization, registration or other applicable fees, taxes and duties where the benefit to the secured parties of increasing the guaranteed or secured amount is disproportionate to the level of such fee, taxes and duties as determined in good faith by Hyperion and the Administrative Agent; - Where there is material incremental cost involved in creating a security interest over all assets owned by a loan party in a particular category (including, for the avoidance of doubt, receivables, real estate, intellectual property), if the cost, burden or other consequences of providing a guarantee or security interest in, or perfection of, such asset class outweigh the benefits to be obtained by the secured parties and, where such security interest is to be given in light of the agreed security principles, only the material assets in that category shall be subject to such security interest; - If after giving regard to other provisions of the agreed security principles, a subsidiary would be able to provide a guarantee of the obligations of some but not all of the borrowers, (i) the borrower representative and the Administrative Agent shall negotiate, in good faith, amendments to the First Lien Credit Agreement and the applicable guarantee agreement to reflect the limited nature of such guarantee and (ii) the Administrative Agent and the lenders shall enter into a customary agreement providing for a customary collateral allocation mechanism, which agreement shall be in form and substance reasonably satisfactory to the borrower representative; - Perfection of security interests, when required by the loan documents, and other legal formalities will be completed as soon as reasonably practicable and, in any event, within the time periods specified in the loan documents; - So long as no enforcement event shall have occurred and be continuing, the giving of a guarantee, the granting of a security interest or the perfection of the security interest granted will not be required if it would have a material adverse effect on the ability of the relevant subsidiary to conduct its operations and/or business in the ordinary course; - Information, such as lists of assets, will be provided upon the creation of the security at the reasonable request of the Administrative Agent, to the extent such lists are required, in the reasonable opinion of the Administrative Agent, by local law to be provided to perfect or register the relevant security interests, but such information or lists shall not be provided on an ongoing basis; - Except to the extent required by the First Lien Credit Agreement, additional insured, co-insured, loss payee or other endorsements shall not be made on the insurance policies; - Subject to these agreed security principles, a grantor shall grant security over all of its intellectual property; - “Parallel debt” provisions will be used where necessary and such provisions will be contained in the First Lien Credit Agreement; - No control agreements or arrangements shall be required with respect to cash, deposit accounts, securities accounts or commodities accounts or letter of credit rights; and - Any security over bank accounts shall be subject to any prior security interests in favor of the account bank which are created either by law or in the standard terms and conditions of the account bank, in ----- each case as permitted under the First Lien Credit Agreement. The notice of security may request these are waived or subordinated by the account bank but the applicable loan party shall not be required to change its banking arrangements if these security interests are not waived or subordinated or only partially waived or subordinated (and shall not be required to use more than commercially reasonable efforts to procure such waiver or subordination).

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS
Subsubsection Title: Representations and Warranties, Covenants
Subsubsection Text: The representations and warranties will be customary for similar transactions and are subject to materiality qualifiers. The negative covenants will include (i) limitations on indebtedness, (ii) limitations on liens, (iii) limitations on fundamental changes, (iv) limitations on asset sales, (v) limitations on restricted payments, (vi) limitations on transactions with affiliates, (vii) limitations on negative pledges, (viii) limitations on amendments of organizational documents and restricted debt documents, (ix) limitations on changes of tax residence and (x) limitations on withdrawal of cash on deposit in the locked account. The First Lien Credit Agreement will contain a maximum first lien net leverage ratio financial covenant set at a level equal to 7.50:1.00 which will be tested when the principal amount of loans and letter of credit exposure (other than (a) undrawn letters of credit that have been cash collateralized and (b) undrawn letters of credit that have not been cash collateralized in an aggregate amount of up to £63 million at any time outstanding) in each case outstanding under the Revolving Facility exceeds 40% of the commitments under the Revolving Facility.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS
Subsubsection Title: Events of Default
Subsubsection Text: Events of Default will be limited to customary events of default with notice and grace periods, including inaccuracy in any material respect of representations and warranties, payment default for failure to pay interest, principal or fees and expenses, default in the observance of covenants, default in material indebtedness, bankruptcy, ERISA events, security and guarantee documents ceasing to be in full force and effect and a change of control.

Section Title: DESCRIPTION OF OTHER INDEBTEDNESS
Subsubsection Title: Description of Local Law Loan Documents
Subsubsection Text: Certain members of the Group are party to foreign-law-governed finance agreements, including loan facilities in Spain, France, Italy which are either unsecured or secured by the assets of the borrower. Some notable arrangements include: - Programme Applying to a Common Secured Term Bond Loan of up to Euro 20,500,000 by and among, Howden Hellas Insurance and Reinsurance Brokers Societe Anonyme, as issuer, Howden Broking Group Limited, MIRB Insurance and Reinsurance Brokers LTD, as guarantors and Piraeus Bank S.A., as bondholder agent, and the other parties thereto, dated as of February 28, 2022. The amount of the loan is €20,500,000 and is secured by the assets of the issuer, Howden Agents S.A. - Financing Agreement Euro 70,000,000.00 in favor of Assiteca S.p.A, as borrower organized by Banca IMI S.p.A., as bank arranger and Intesa Sanpaolo S.p.A., as issuing bank, and the other parties thereto, dated as of June 29, 2020. The amount of the loan is €70,000,000 and the loan is unsecured. - Loan between Howden Canineberg GmbH and Sparkasse Cologne Bonn, dated as of December 12, 2016. The total amount of the loan is €3,550,000 and is secured by (i) a guaranty by Howden Germany HoldCo GMbH, (ii) a surety from Howden Safety International GmbH and (iii) an assignment of receivables from limited partner shares in Erwin Himmelseher Assekuranz-Vermittlung GmbH & Co. KG. - Loan between Howden Iberia S.A., as borrower and Allianz Compania De Seguros Y Reaseguros, as lender, dated as of June 21, 2017. The total amount of the loan is €2,600,000 and secured by rights over the insurance policy of Howden Iberia S.A. - Loan between Howden Iberia S.A.U, as borrower and Allianz Compania De Sugros Y Reaseguros, as lender, dated as of July 5, 2021. The total amount of the loan is €4,000,000 and is guaranteed by Howden Group Holdings Limited. ----- - Two Credit Agreements between Guian S.A. (now known as Howden Assurances SA), as borrower and Banque Populaire, as lender, dated as of January 9, 2019 and April 24, 2019, respectively. The total amount of the loans is €900,000 and they are both secured by a pledge of business of Guian S.A. - Loan Contract between Seasecure, as borrower and Credit Lyonnais, as lender dated as of March 23, 2020. There are two loans in the amount of (i) €200,000 and (ii) €185,000 and the loan is unsecured. - Personal Loan Policy between March Risk Solutions (now known as Howden Risk Solutions, S.A.U.), as holder and Banca March, as lender, dated as of July 5, 2021. The total amount of the loan is €3,000,000 and it is unsecured. - Loan between Theoreme, as borrower and BNP Paribas, as lender, dated as of November 12, 2019.
